Japanese police arrested 64-year-old former school principal Yuhei Takashima on charges of photographing obscene acts with a 13 or 14-year-old girl in Manila, seizing 147,600 photos from his activities. Takashima told police he paid for sex with more than 12,000 women and girls, some as young as 14, during repeated visits to the Philippines over 25 years, starting when he worked at a Japanese school in Manila from 1988-1991.

A Brazilian online football store claims to be selling next season's Chelsea kit, which features the new 'Yokohama' sponsor and can be purchased with Gareth Bale's name on the back, despite the Welsh player currently being at Real Madrid where he has struggled this season. The website has published three alleged Chelsea kits without the Adidas emblem, and amid reports linking Bale with a return to the Premier League, the Brazilian store is capitalizing on transfer speculation by offering the kit with his name. The site also sells kits with Didier Drogba's name, even though his Chelsea contract expires at the end of the season and he hasn't signed a new deal.

Police in Akron, Ohio have charged 44-year-old Clarence Taylor with faking his own kidnapping after he was found tied to a tree last fall in a bizarre incident. Taylor's 45-year-old girlfriend called police when he went missing, and he was later discovered bound to a tree, claiming he had been robbed and left there for days, but police found inconsistencies in his story. Taylor now faces falsification charges and remains at large after a warrant was issued for his arrest.

Rita Wilson and an ensemble of actresses appear in a satirical new video created by the Make it Fair Project that ironically promotes gender equality by pretending to be sad that men don't completely dominate the film industry. The actresses highlight stark gender inequality statistics, noting that men hold 80-95% of influential positions in Hollywood and other industries, with only 80% of films written by men and 88% of leading roles going to men. The tongue-in-cheek PSA, created by an all-female crew, uses dark humor to draw attention to systemic gender disparities across entertainment, government, and corporate leadership while calling for change.

Spanish researchers suggest that a warming climate 1.4 million years ago enabled the earliest humans (hominins) to migrate from Africa into Western Europe for the first time. The study found that colder, drier conditions had previously prevented these distant human ancestors from settling in southeast Spain, but when temperatures warmed above 13°C (55°F) and humidity increased, hominins were able to inhabit the region and spread across Europe. The research, based on analysis of ancient tools found at the Barranco León site in Spain, indicates that early human migration was primarily constrained by climate rather than cultural or geographical factors.

Former NFL running back Lawrence Phillips, 39, who is serving a 31-year sentence at Kern Valley State Prison in Central California, is suspected of killing his 37-year-old cellmate Damion Soward. Soward, who was serving 82 years to life for first-degree murder, was found lifeless in their shared cell on Saturday morning. Phillips, a former Nebraska college football star who played for several NFL teams before being jailed in 2005, is now under investigation by prison officials along with the coroner and district attorney.

Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final defeat to Aston Villa has put manager Brendan Rodgers under scrutiny, with the club's ambition to be Champions League regulars and Premier League contenders looking distant after a disappointing campaign. Of the 17 players Liverpool have signed over the last two summers at considerable cost, only three have delivered, highlighting serious transfer committee failures that compound Rodgers' tactical struggles in crucial matches. With multiple players leaving this summer and questions about the squad's character and resolve, Rodgers faces enormous pressure to provide the right answers and signings to restore Liverpool's progress toward their lofty ambitions.

Google released an April Fools' Day prank a day early by combining Google Maps with Pac-Man, allowing users to play the classic game on real-world street layouts. To play, users simply pull up Google Maps on their desktop browser, click the Pac-Man icon, and their map suddenly becomes a Pac-Man course with streets serving as the game paths. This continues Google's tradition of impish April Fools' Day pranks involving Google Maps, which have previously included features like a Pokemon Challenge and treasure map.

Rangers boss Stuart McCall has been reassured that the club's removal from the London Stock Exchange's AIM market will not affect his squad's promotion push, despite the news rocking fans and the club announcing six-month losses of £2.6million. McCall was surprised to learn that Rangers will have to pay Newcastle United £500,000 if they win promotion to the Premiership as part of the loan deal for five Newcastle youngsters, but he remains focused on the team's charge for the play-offs. Rangers will give newly-crowned Scottish Championship winners Hearts a guard of honour when they visit Ibrox on Sunday in a match crucial for the hosts' hopes of overtaking Hibernian in second place.

The US Internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for operating what critics call a "coercive scheme" using the new '.sucks' domain, charging celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies around $2,000-$2,499 annually to prevent damaging websites from being created with their names. Vox Populi began accepting registrations in March for domains like Youtube.sucks, Visa.sucks, and Bankofamerica.sucks, with the threat that these domains would be available to the general public for just $10 starting in September if trademark holders don't pay the premium fees. ICANN has referred the matter to US and Canadian regulators to determine if the company's actions are illegal, noting that celebrities like Taylor Swift have previously had to pay to remove their names from similar domains like '.porn' and '.adult'.

Edinson Cavani's poor Champions League performance against Barcelona in PSG's 2-0 defeat has likely ended any chance of him joining Manchester United to fill their looming striker void. Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal may be wary of signing another aging South American striker after Radamel Falcao's nightmare loan spell from Ligue 1 side Monaco, and Cavani's lackluster domestic form this season (11 goals in 32 games) suggests he may not be the prolific force needed at Old Trafford.

With seven points separating Sunderland in 15th from Leicester in 20th, the Premier League relegation battle remains wide open as even Sunderland could fall into the drop zone after a bad weekend. Steve Bruce's Hull are predicted to survive on goal difference despite having the hardest run-in, while Chris Ramsey may find QPR's poor goal difference crucial as they're predicted to be relegated alongside Burnley and Leicester. The analysis suggests Hull could narrowly avoid relegation with 33 points, benefiting from their superior goal difference over QPR, while Leicester's poor form (22 points from 30 games) makes it unlikely they can mount a successful survival sprint despite having five home games remaining.

Real Madrid star Karim Benzema posted a video showcasing his rapping skills while singing along to Tupac's classic track "Check Out Time" in his Bugatti Veyron, as the team prepares for their La Liga clash against Granada at the Bernabeu on Sunday. The France forward, who has scored 20 goals in all competitions this season, recently stated his confidence that he can win the Ballon d'Or award in the future, despite the current dominance of his Real Madrid teammate Cristiano Ronaldo and Barcelona's Lionel Messi.

Vatican doctors have told 78-year-old Pope Francis that he must lose weight due to considerable weight gain since taking office two years ago, which is aggravating his sciatica condition and back pain. The medical team has advised him to limit his pasta intake to just two servings per week and take daily walks like his predecessor Pope Benedict XVI did. However, the Pope, who jokingly calls himself "the undisciplined one," continues to eat pasta daily and has previously suggested he doesn't expect his papacy to last long.

Google has released an update to its Android software that allows users to unlock their phones using voice commands by saying "OK, Google" through a feature called "trusted voice," though Google warns this method is less secure than traditional passwords. Additionally, Android phones running Ice Cream Sandwich or higher offer Face Unlock, which uses the device's front-facing camera to recognize the user's face and unlock the handset, with recent updates including a "liveness" check to prevent bypassing with static photos.

Robert Bates' lawyer released training documents on Saturday that show the Oklahoma reserve deputy had one Taser training class over six-and-a-half years and took three firearms training classes, with records showing he scored high enough on pistol qualifications 10 times to carry a handgun on duty. Bates is charged with second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris when he says he meant to use his Taser instead, and his training has become a central issue in the case amid allegations he received preferential treatment. CNN could not independently verify the authenticity of the documents, and some firearms qualification records from 2012-2013 are missing from the sheriff's office files.

Peter Tait, headmaster of Sherborne Preparatory School, has claimed that parents need to keep their distance from their children's education and trust schools and teachers instead of being "dervishes ready to battle" on behalf of their child. He argued that parents must trust those responsible for their children's education and allow natural development rather than interfering, which stems from being bombarded with parenting information. The concerns about overinvolved parents are echoed by other educators who have also attacked parents for pushing children too hard, while a separate survey revealed that teachers are increasingly suffering abuse from parents through social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the nuclear deal struck by six world powers with Iran, arguing that the agreement doesn't adequately roll back Iran's nuclear program and allows thousands of centrifuges to keep operating. While President Barack Obama endorsed the deal as better than the alternatives, Netanyahu advocated for a "third alternative" of maintaining pressure for a better agreement, claiming Iran cannot be trusted due to its history of "congenital cheating." Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein responded by saying Netanyahu should "contain himself," while the debate continues between Democrats who support the framework and Republicans who believe it gives Iran too much flexibility.

Catalans Dragons have suffered a major blow as France international winger Vincent Duport has been ruled out for the rest of the season with a shoulder injury that requires surgery. Duport suffered a ruptured tendon during the Dragons' 33-22 defeat at Hull FC on March 20, ending his campaign after scoring three tries in the first six rounds of Super League XX. Head coach Laurent Frayssinous expressed disappointment but confidence that Duport will recover, as the sixth-placed Catalans prepare for their next match against Wigan.

Police discovered the body of Samantha Fleming, a young Indiana woman who was reported missing weeks ago along with her newborn daughter Serenity, after Fleming left home with a woman claiming to be from Child Protective Services. The three-week-old infant was found unharmed at a home in Gary, Indiana, 180 miles away, where police also discovered Fleming's body wrapped in plastic and doused with bleach. The alleged kidnapper, who had prepared a nursery and told neighbors she was pregnant with twins, asked her sister to care for the baby she was passing off as her own before fleeing to Texas where she was later located by police.

Geologist Dr Danny Hilman believes that a site in West Java, Indonesia contains the world's oldest pyramid, potentially built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago, which would be up to four times older than Egypt's oldest known step pyramid that was built almost 5,000 years ago. If proven true, this 20,000-year-old pyramid would surpass even the Brazilian pyramids discovered by archaeologists in 1996 that date to around 3,000 BC, and would provide evidence of an advanced ancient civilisation capable of sophisticated engineering. However, Dr Hilman's controversial findings are disputed by other experts who question both the site's authenticity as a man-made pyramid and whether such an ancient civilization could have been advanced enough to construct such a monument.

Shocking footage has emerged showing a man stabbing a 29-year-old bouncer outside a Melbourne nightclub just before the Easter long weekend, with police expressing disgust over the unprovoked attack from behind that left the security guard with non-life threatening injuries. In a separate incident on Good Friday, another security guard was stabbed by a 24-year-old man who was refused entry to a different Melbourne nightclub, resulting in the attacker being hospitalized in stable condition while the bouncer suffered only minor injuries. Police have released CCTV footage and are seeking information about both stabbing incidents targeting nightclub security staff.

Carlisle United manager Keith Curle launched a scathing attack on his players following their dismal 3-1 defeat away at Accrington Stanley, claiming some "don't deserve to be professionals" and criticizing the lack of character and spirit in the changing room. The Cumbrians, who were relegated from League One last season, are struggling in League Two with just five games left to avoid another relegation, sitting only three points above the relegation zone. Curle even suggested staging an open forum where supporters could directly confront the players about their poor performances.

Victoria's Secret Angels Candice Swanepoel, Elsa Hosk, and Jasmine Tookes star in the brand's latest lingerie campaign promoting the new Dream Angels range, featuring romantic underwear in blush pink and white tones with lace and crystal details. The 26-year-old Candice leads the glamorous shoot where the models pose with pink striped umbrellas (given free with purchase of two bras) while showcasing the push-up bras and feminine designs. Additionally, Candice recently appeared in Max Factor's latest beauty campaign channeling Marilyn Monroe, though she admits in interviews that despite radiating confidence now, it took time for her to feel comfortable in her skin after being discovered at age 15.

Wannabe singer Kristina Karo is suing actress Mila Kunis for $5,000, alleging that Kunis stole her pet chicken named "Doggie" when they were seven-year-old children in Ukraine 25 years ago. Karo claims the theft traumatized her and that being in close proximity to Kunis in Los Angeles has brought back bad memories, forcing her to seek therapy again. The lawsuit seeks damages for emotional distress, though notably Karo lived more than 100 miles away from where Kunis actually grew up in Ukraine.

Richard Howarth, a 35-year-old father from Milton Keynes, claims he has developed an "allergy" to UKIP leader Nigel Farage that causes him to sweat, shake, and become physically sick whenever he sees Farage on TV or hears his voice. Howarth says he must immediately change the channel when Farage appears to avoid becoming ill, with symptoms sometimes lasting for hours. A phobia expert suggests Howarth's reactions sound more like a phobia than an allergy, noting it's possible to have such an avoidance reaction to a politician whose views fundamentally oppose your own.

A drunk 17-year-old named Rahul Kumar climbed over the enclosure fence at a zoo in Ahmedabad, India, and ran toward lions while shouting "Today I kill a lion or a lion kills me!" Fortunately, zoo security staff were able to rescue him after he fell into a moat before reaching the animals. Kumar was later cautioned by police and will undergo psychiatric evaluation, explaining that he was intoxicated and "thought I'd stand a good chance" against the predators.

This Easter article reveals that popular chocolate treats require significant exercise to burn off their calories - for example, one Crème egg takes 19 minutes of skipping to burn off and contains almost seven teaspoons of sugar, which is more than half the 50g the World Health Organisation recommends per day. A nutrition scientist warns that consuming too much sugar could trigger insulin resistance, explaining that "sugar causes pathological changes" and "insulin resistance puts you at a metabolic disadvantage to lose weight," potentially leading to type 2 diabetes, obesity, and other health problems. The article provides specific exercise recommendations from fitness coaches, such as two high intensity exercise classes needed to work off a Flake Easter egg, while emphasizing that overstressing the insulin system through excessive sugar consumption can cause long-term cellular damage.

The Havasupai tribe, America's smallest Indian nation with just over 600 people, lives in the hidden village of Supai located eight miles from the nearest road at the bottom of Havasu Canyon within the Grand Canyon. The tribe claimed this settlement from National Park rangers in 1975 after court battles, and now relies primarily on tourism for income, with about 20,000 visitors annually traveling by foot, mule, or helicopter to experience life in this remote canyon community. The village includes basic amenities like a cafe, stores, lodge, post office, and school, making it the only place in the US where mail is still delivered by mule.

A new malaria vaccine called RTS,S has completed final testing and could become the first licensed vaccine against malaria anywhere in the world, potentially preventing millions of cases of the deadly disease. Tests on 15,500 children in sub-Saharan Africa showed the vaccine prevented an average of 1,363 cases of clinical malaria over four years for every 1,000 children vaccinated, though its effectiveness decreased over time. Researchers say the vaccine, which took 30 years to develop, could make a substantial contribution to controlling malaria and may receive approval by October 2015.

Chilean pickpockets have become the most effective thieves operating in central London, with gangs of up to six members targeting wealthy tourists in busy shopping areas like Oxford Street and Mayfair, according to plain-clothes officers tasked with reducing theft. In one example, Metropolitan Police stopped two Chilean women wearing burkas who were spotted targeting rich Arab tourists and found them carrying €130,000, £20,000, and valuable jewelry. While statistics show that about 70% of arrested pickpockets are Romanian or Bulgarian, police note that Chilean gangs are particularly sophisticated, operating as part of organized international crime networks that move between major European cities.

The UK has introduced its first new electricity pylon design in nearly 90 years, called the T-pylon, which is about a third shorter than the traditional 165ft lattice pylons but can carry the same 400,000 volts of power. While there are currently more than 88,000 existing pylons across the UK, National Grid plans to use these new T-pylons separately rather than as replacements, with the first operational T-pylons planned for use with the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station in Somerset. The sleeker T-pylon design can be erected in just one day compared to a week for traditional pylons and is intended to be less obtrusive in the landscape.

Holly Nicole Solomon, 31, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault after hitting her husband Daniel with their SUV in a Mesa parking lot following Barack Obama's reelection in 2012. Solomon admitted to running down her husband because he didn't vote in the presidential election, telling police she blamed their family's problems on Obama and was upset about his victory over opponent Mitt Romney. She will serve three and a half years in prison after accepting a plea deal, while her husband suffered critical injuries including a shattered pelvis.

Drew Hollinshead, a 21-year-old student at Bournemouth University, received a £70 parking ticket after he stopped in a disabled parking bay to help an elderly woman who had collapsed on the pavement. Despite the emergency situation lasting less than a minute, a traffic warden issued the ticket while Hollinshead was assisting the woman. The student called the incident "ridiculous" and said he was being punished for trying to do something good, though Bournemouth Council's Parking Services stated that motorists can appeal tickets and mitigating circumstances are considered.

Workers in Pingjiang County, Hunan province, China are constructing a precarious mountain walkway thousands of feet above ground without safety harnesses or ropes, using only hard hats for protection. The men assemble scaffolding along cliff faces using rusty metal scaffolding poles and carry heavy wheelbarrows full of concrete across flimsy wooden planks to build the tourist attraction. Chinese officials hope these dangerous construction projects will draw more visitors to the mountainous region, despite the extreme risks faced by the builders who work suspended thousands of feet in the air.

Independent investigators uncovered serious failings at two NHS hospitals operated by North Pennine Acute Hospitals NHS Trust after seven babies and three mothers died within eight months, including Lisa Parkisson who died 48 hours after giving birth at Royal Oldham and newborn Thomas Beaty who died from head injuries after doctors forced him back into the womb during delivery. The investigation found notable absence of clinical leadership in maternity services, failure to adequately plan care, and below-standard risk management, though the report was kept secret from families until now. The trust delivers 10,000 babies annually and is developing an action plan to address the identified problems in their maternity services.

Ferguson held its first city election since the killing of Michael Brown, resulting in significant changes to the City Council with African-American candidates Ella Jones and Wesley Bell winning seats to make the six-member council 50% black, better reflecting the city's 70% black population. Brian Fletcher, a former mayor who launched the "I Love Ferguson" campaign, also won his race despite being seen by some as part of the old guard. The election saw higher-than-normal 30% turnout as voters sought change in how Ferguson polices its community, particularly moving away from using law enforcement as a revenue source through fines and tickets.

Australia's World Cup-winning batsman Aaron Finch underwent surgery on Tuesday for a high grade left hamstring injury sustained while playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL. The operation was successful, but the 28-year-old opener and T20 captain will be sidelined for up to three months during his rehabilitation period. Finch was scheduled to join Yorkshire county cricket at the end of May but will now miss that opportunity due to the injury.

AP McCoy won the Melling Chase at Aintree on Friday riding Don Cossack, trained by Gordon Elliott, in what was his second victory at his final Aintree meeting before retirement. The win came aboard a horse trained by Elliott, who also trains Cause of Causes - one of the mounts McCoy could have chosen for Saturday's Grand National instead of Shutthefrontdoor. Elliott indicated that Don Cossack will target the Gold Cup next season after the impressive 26-length victory over Cue Card.

Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat Business Secretary who prides himself on being the Tories' least popular Cabinet member, has surprisingly expressed willingness to work with the Conservatives for another five years and even wants to replace George Osborne as Chancellor. Despite describing "nasty and vicious stuff" from the Tories and heated confrontations with Conservative ministers, Cable says he can be "business-like" with Cameron and Osborne, whom he calls "highly intelligent guys" who "don't snarl at each other." Meanwhile, he criticizes Labour leader Ed Miliband for making "two really big mistakes" and having "very poor judgment," suggesting Cable envisions remaining in a Cameron-led government rather than working with Labour.

A survey of 2,000 workers by Sennheiser Communications found that the average British worker will sit through 6,239 meetings during their career, with 60 percent saying they find most meetings "pretty pointless." The poll revealed that 70 percent of workers constantly zone out during meetings, with the average worker switching off completely after 20 minutes, and one in five workers confessed to making mistakes due to not paying attention. Many workers admitted to daydreaming about plans like what they're having for dinner that night, with nearly half spending meeting time doodling on notepads instead of focusing on the discussion.

A math problem from the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad designed for 14-year-olds went viral worldwide, asking participants to determine fictional Cheryl's birthday from 10 possible dates after Cheryl gives Albert the month and Bernard the day respectively. Through logical deduction based on Albert's statement that he knows Bernard cannot know the birthday (ruling out May and June which contain unique dates), and Bernard's subsequent realization that he now knows the answer (eliminating duplicate dates like the 14th), the solution is determined to be July 16. The puzzle was designed as question 24 of 25 to filter out the most intelligent participants among 28,000 students from multiple countries.

Army Major John Jackson and his wife Carolyn are on trial for allegedly abusing their three young foster children between 2005 and 2010, causing broken bones, bruises, and other serious injuries through withholding food and water, physical beatings, and forcing them to consume hot sauce. This is their second trial after the first ended in mistrial when a prosecutor mentioned that one of their foster children had died, which was ruled inadmissible since they weren't charged with the death. The abuse was reportedly discovered when one of their biological children reported it to someone outside the family, and prosecutors noted that while their three biological children showed no signs of abuse, the foster children were severely underweight and injured when removed from the Jackson home.

Real Madrid are set to be without striker Karim Benzema for their crucial Champions League quarter-final second leg clash against rivals Atletico Madrid on Wednesday, as the French forward continues to struggle with a knee injury that caused him to miss Madrid's 3-1 victory over Malaga. Spanish newspapers report that Benzema, who has scored 15 La Liga goals this season, remains doubtful for the match despite earlier optimism from coach Carlo Ancelotti, with Gareth Bale and Luka Modric also likely to miss Wednesday's clash due to injuries.

The culprits behind the £60m Hatton Garden raid in London may have carried out a similarly audacious burglary two years earlier in Berlin, where thieves targeted 294 security vaults at Volksbank in Steglitz and stole over £8.3m worth of diamonds, gold, and silver. Both heists involved remarkably similar methods, including the use of heavy-duty drills to break through concrete walls, tunneling operations, disguising as construction workers, and timing the raids over holiday weekends when buildings were empty. The Berlin tunnel bank robbery, like the London raid that targeted 71 security boxes, remains unsolved with striking parallels suggesting the same criminal gang may have been responsible for both operations.

A father named Barles Charkley captured his toddler daughter Viktoria's heartbreaking reaction on camera as she watched Disney's The Lion King for the first time, specifically the tear-jerking scene where Mufasa is murdered by his evil brother Scar, leaving Simba fatherless. The video shows Viktoria's crestfallen reaction as she trembles, brushes away tears, and eventually seeks comfort from her father after witnessing one of Disney's most haunting spectacles. The emotional footage, posted to Facebook, has garnered over four million views as viewers connect with the little girl's genuine response to this classic Disney tragedy.

A couple in their 40s successfully challenged HSBC for age discrimination after the bank rejected their £250,000 mortgage application because the husband would be over 65 when the 18-year interest-only loan matured. The Financial Ombudsman Service found HSBC guilty of relying on "untested assumptions, stereotypes or generalisations" about age and ordered the bank to pay £500 compensation and reconsider the application, despite the couple having substantial equity and adequate income to cover repayments. This landmark case offers hope for other borrowers facing strict age-related lending policies, as HSBC and many lenders typically don't offer interest-only loans beyond a borrower's 65th birthday.

Dr. Kristen Lindsey, a Texas veterinarian, allegedly shot a cat with an arrow and posted a photo on Facebook showing herself holding the dead animal by the arrow's shaft, calling it her "first bow kill." The post sparked public outrage, leading to her firing from Washington County's Animal Clinic where she worked, and prompting an investigation by the sheriff's office with dispatchers overwhelmed by calls. Lindsey could face charges for animal cruelty, with activists pushing for prosecution and offering a $7,500 reward for evidence leading to her arrest and conviction.

Professor Ninian Peckitt, a 63-year-old pioneering facial surgeon who specializes in treating disfigured patients, is accused of repeatedly punching a patient in the face while attempting to correct fractures caused by an industrial accident during hospital treatment at Ipswich Hospital in February 2012. The Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service heard that Peckitt, who was working as an honorary locum consultant in oral and maxillo-facial surgery, claimed he had only "digitally manipulated" the patient's face, but witnesses testified he was actually hitting the patient. He faces being struck off the medical register for allegedly failing three patients, including Patient C who had a complex facial deformity, with medical experts stating that using external force to reduce fractures is entirely inappropriate.

Actor Ben Powers, best known for playing Thelma's husband Keith on the CBS sitcom Good Times, died on April 6 at age 64 at his home in New Bedford, Massachusetts. His on-screen wife Bern Nadette Stanis wrote an emotional Facebook tribute calling him "a great actor and great friend who is gone too soon." Powers appeared in the show's final season from 1978-1979 and also had roles in other TV shows and films throughout his career.

Darren Bent scored a stoppage-time equalizer to secure a 1-1 draw for Derby against Brentford at the iPro Stadium, after Alex Pritchard had put the Bees ahead with a brilliant strike in the 21st minute. Derby went into the game knowing they needed to win to keep their slim automatic promotion hopes alive, with Tom Ince going close twice in the opening minutes, but Brentford controlled large periods of the match after Pritchard's stunning goal. Despite missing several second-half chances, Brentford were made to pay when Bent grabbed his 10th goal for Derby in the 92nd minute to rescue a point the Rams barely deserved.

A gang of armed robbers used pink umbrellas to conceal their identities during a two-month crime spree in which they raided 13 shops in the West Midlands, stealing £145,000 in total. The gang, led by members including 21-year-old Marcus Morgan and 26-year-old Ashleigh Evans, also threatened shop workers with hammers, knives, and screwdrivers during their robberies. All four gang members were arrested and sentenced to a combined total of more than 27 years in prison after pleading guilty to conspiracy to rob.

Italian explorer Alex Bellini is seeking funding for his daring project called "Adrift," where he plans to spend a year living alone inside a ball-shaped survival capsule on top of a melting iceberg in Greenland starting in November 2016. The capsule will be equipped with sensors to detect tremors that indicate when the iceberg might flip, and features roller balls inside to minimize sudden movements if the capsule gets thrown during such events. Bellini's goal is to raise awareness about global warming and climate change theories by witnessing firsthand how icebergs melt and contribute to rising sea levels.

A photograph circulating on Snapchat is believed to show disgraced principal Andrew Barr watching pornography in his office at the elite private Geelong College. The picture, allegedly taken by a student through a window, led to an investigation and Mr Barr's subsequent resignation from his position at the school. While the investigation found that Mr Barr had not broken any law, school officials deemed his actions a serious breach of the institution's standards.

30-year-old Francis Pusok was brutally beaten by police officers more than 80 times after fleeing his home to avoid arrest on identity theft charges, leading to a two-and-a-half hour chase that was captured on helicopter video. Pusok claims he was handcuffed for 99% of the beating and that officers continued to assault him while he lay helpless on the ground, with one deputy allegedly whispering "This isn't over" at the end of the incident. Ten officers have been placed on paid administrative leave pending FBI investigation, while prosecutors have yet to decide whether to file formal charges against Pusok, who has a lengthy criminal record but whose pregnant girlfriend Jolene Bindner disputes some of the prior allegations against him.

Hizb ut-Tahrir (HT), an extremist Islamist group with UK support, has reportedly joined forces with al-Qaeda in Syria and attacked civil activists in Aleppo, with several British men linked to ISIS including "Jihadi John" Emwazi known to have contacted the group while studying at UK universities. The article also reveals that Liberal Democrat candidate Maajid Nawaz, a former HT member for 13 years who now runs a counter-extremism think tank, was filmed inappropriately touching a lap dancer at an East London strip club during Ramadan, with staff calling his behavior "outrageous." Other HT connections include 21-year-old Waheed Ahmed, son of a Labour councillor, who was arrested trying to cross into Syria and is said to be an HT member recruited at Manchester University.

Marks & Spencer is introducing the Bouea macrophylla, nicknamed the 'plango' or mango plum, as the latest tropical fruit to hit UK shelves after years of collaboration with Thai growers. The fruit features bright orange edible skin and offers the sweet taste of an Alphonso mango with a softer texture, allowing customers to enjoy mango flavor without the typical preparation hassle since the skin can be eaten. According to M&S fruit expert Shazad Rehman, this interesting new fruit joins other hybrid varieties on the market as retailers seek to offer customers unique and exotic options.

The University of Cape Town voted to remove a statue of British colonialist Cecil Rhodes after a month of student protests, with the defaced monument set to be removed today following complaints from black students who felt uncomfortable with this symbol of historical white oppression. The decision has sparked counter-protests from white solidarity groups who handed a memorandum to parliament demanding protection for their heritage, while critics argue that Rhodes, who founded Rhodesia (modern-day Zimbabwe) and believed England was the "master race," helped pave the way for apartheid through his colonial policies. The government has backed the statue's removal as part of dealing with the country's "ugly past," though they discourage violent removal of colonial symbols.

Hannah Bluck, an 18-year-old Welsh international footballer, has had her promising career halted for two years after being diagnosed with avascular necrosis, an ultra-rare condition that causes bone death due to poor blood supply and has left her shin bone dead. Doctors warned that her leg could collapse into her ankle if she continues playing, as this condition has never been seen before in a leg bone and typically affects joints like hips and shoulders. After her previous treatment stopped working, Hannah's family found hope when experts at a major orthopaedic conference in Las Vegas analyzed her MRI scan, leading to a specialist appointment in London as she continues to dream of returning to football and earning a senior Wales cap.

Paris Saint-Germain forward Edinson Cavani has rejected rumors of a rift with teammate Zlatan Ibrahimovic, insisting they have a respectful relationship and that his only concern is being played out of his preferred striker position alongside Ibrahimovic. The former Napoli forward admits they are not necessarily friends but dismisses speculation about their relationship breakdown, stating he was recruited to play as a striker with Ibrahimovic but hasn't always been used in that role. Despite being linked with a summer exit, Cavani says he is focused on finishing the season and respecting his contract, though he acknowledges "anything can happen in football."

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for next month's UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the Young Lions looking to defend their title after beating Holland on penalties in last year's final. The squad includes Chelsea youngster Jay Dasilva, Arsenal's Chris Willock (called up for the first time), and Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, with England drawn in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. England will open their campaign against Italy on May 7 in Burgas.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky, made by the Sazerac Co. and inspired by Atomic Fireball hard candy, has become America's fastest-growing liquor brand after being rebranded in 2006, with retail sales skyrocketing from under $2 million in 2011 to $130 million last year through aggressive social media marketing including #FireballFriday hashtags. The sweet, 66-proof cinnamon-flavored whisky gained massive popularity among young drinkers after Sazerac hired a brand ambassador to promote it in bars and on social platforms, though its growth has recently slowed amid increased competition from copycat products and some consumer fatigue. Despite enduring a brief recall in Europe over propylene glycol concerns, Fireball has dethroned Jägermeister as America's party shot of choice, though questions remain about whether it's a lasting trend or just a fad.

Researchers from the University of Montana found that eating fast food after a workout may be just as beneficial as dietary supplements during recovery periods between exercise sessions. In the study published in the International Journal of Sport Nutrition and Exercise Metabolism, 11 male athletes completed a 90-minute endurance workout and were then given either fast food meals or sports nutrition products, followed by a 12-mile cycling test. The researchers found that participants' performance and muscle glycogen levels were essentially the same regardless of whether they consumed fast food or supplements, suggesting that various food options can effectively support post-exercise recovery.

Gael Monfils knocked Roger Federer out of the Monte Carlo Masters with a thrilling 6-4, 7-6 victory in their last-16 encounter. The 28-year-old Frenchman displayed breathtaking athleticism and focused play, hitting 22 winners to Federer's 17 as he defeated the 17-time Grand Slam champion. Monfils' victory puts him through to his first quarter-final in Monaco, where he will face Grigor Dimitrov.

Reverend Al Sharpton delivered a sermon at Charity Missionary Baptist Church in North Charleston on Sunday, addressing the Walter Scott situation where the black driver was fatally shot by a white police officer. North Charleston Mayor Keith Summey, Police Chief Eddie Driggers, and South Carolina Senator Marlon Kimpson were among those who attended to hear Sharpton speak about the need for policing reform. Sharpton praised Mayor Summey for firing Officer Michael Slager, who has been charged with murder in Scott's shooting, and called for North Charleston to set a new tone for policing across the United States.

Stewart Brand, president of the Long Now Foundation, argues that Earth is not facing a sixth mass extinction as many conservationists claim, stating that the current extinction rate of one percent per decade is far lower than the discovery rate of new species at three percent per decade. While the five historic mass extinctions eliminated 70 percent or more of all species, Brand believes that focusing on widespread extinctions may actually be harmful and that many threatened species are recovering through conservation efforts like removing invasive rats and goats from islands. He contends that biodiversity is actually at its highest level ever and suggests that biotechnology could help reintroduce extinct species, making the extinction threat seem less cosmic and more manageable than dire warnings suggest.

ISIS has created an extensive bureaucracy in territories it controls, issuing official documents for everything from birth certificates to university curricula, all operating under strict Sharia law conditions that ban subjects like democracy and archaeology while allowing limited girls' education up to age 15. The group distinguishes itself from the Taliban by permitting vaccinations and some education for girls, and operates hospitals, universities, and other civil services to demonstrate governance capability, though entertainment and daily activities remain heavily regulated to prevent idol worship. ISIS fighters swept through Iraqi cities like Mosul and Syrian territories, establishing absolute control that ignores the Syria-Iraq border and implements policies designed to win over local populations while maintaining religious authority through detailed Islamic jurisprudence.

Milwaukee police say that Archie Brown Jr., a driver who accidentally struck and killed a 2-year-old child who ran into the street on Sunday evening in Wisconsin, was shot dead at the scene by an unidentified gunman in what appears to be a revenge killing. A 15-year-old boy was also shot during the incident and later died at the hospital, though his connection to the situation remains unclear. Police are still searching for the shooter and have not made any arrests in this triple tragedy that claimed three lives.

Bookmakers report that 90% of bets on the new royal baby's sex favor a girl, with odds further slashed after a Scottish punter placed a £2,000 wager on a princess, leading experts to believe the Duchess of Cambridge will give birth to a baby girl soon. While the official due date is April 25th, punters are betting heavily on April 18th-20th for the birth date, with Alice and Victoria being the most popular name choices for a girl, and James (sharing a name with the Duchess's brother and historical kings like James II) being favored for a boy. Royal fans and media are already gathering at St. Mary's Hospital in Paddington, with only the bookies and "maybe Prince George" hoping for a male heir.

Television presenters Holly Willoughby, 34, and Davina McCall, 47, have joined forces for their first campaign together promoting Garnier Nutrisse hair products, celebrating finding their perfect hair shades. In the campaign shoot, the two stars can be seen playfully posing together, with Holly choosing shade 10.01 as her perfect multi-tonal blonde match while Davina selected 4.3 as her ideal brunette color. Meanwhile, Davina recently renewed her wedding vows with husband Matthew Robertson in Las Vegas after 15 years of marriage.

A New York judge has ruled that Ellanora Arthur Baidoo can serve divorce papers to her husband Victor Sena Blood-Dzraku through Facebook, after she was unable to locate him through traditional means despite trying for several years. Baidoo had to prove the Facebook account belongs to her husband and that he regularly uses it, after her husband refused to make himself available for service and claimed to have no fixed address. This landmark decision establishes social media as an acceptable method for serving legal summons when other traditional service methods have been exhausted.

The Turin Shroud, believed by some to be the burial cloth that wrapped Jesus Christ's body, went on public display in Turin's cathedral for the first time in five years, with over one million people having already booked slots to view it through June 24, 2015. While researchers have dated the linen to the 13th century and cannot explain how the crucified man's image was created, the Church values the relic's symbolic value as a representation of Christ's suffering. Pope Francis decreed this latest exhibition to mark the 200th anniversary of St. John Bosco's birth and is scheduled to visit the display on June 20-21.

A four-bedroom Mayfair mansion in central London's Farm Street, built on the site of a former milking parlour that dates back to Tudor times, has gone on the market for £25 million. The recently built house was constructed in 2011 after developers demolished the original structure that once housed cows for milking on one of London's busiest trading streets. The luxury property features modern amenities including an indoor swimming pool, gym, cinema room, and a master suite that occupies the entire second floor.

BBC1 boss Charlotte Moore has confirmed that the period drama Poldark, starring heartthrob Aidan Turner as the broody Ross Poldark, will return for a second series of eight episodes after helping BBC1 deliver its strongest start to a year in a decade. The show, which follows Ross Poldark after he returns from the American War of Independence, has become a new phenomenon averaging 8.1 million viewers per episode and creating hysteria among fans particularly for Turner's shirtless scenes. The second series will adapt the third and fourth of Winston Graham's 12 Poldark books, continuing the story that has captured the nation's hearts.

Gastrointestinal illness has gripped 100 people aboard the cruise ship Celebrity Infinity, with 95 of the ship's 2,117 passengers and 5 crew members suffering from symptoms including vomiting and diarrhea, according to the CDC. Celebrity Cruises has implemented increased cleaning and disinfection procedures while the CDC has yet to determine the cause of the outbreak, and two CDC staffers are scheduled to meet the ship in San Diego on Monday. This marks the third time the Celebrity Infinity has experienced a gastrointestinal illness outbreak, with previous incidents occurring in 2006 and 2013.

UltraHaptics is developing revolutionary technology that creates tactile sensations "without touching" by using ultrasound waves to generate pressure differentials in the air, allowing users to feel invisible buttons and surfaces. This technology has significant potential when combined with virtual reality devices like Facebook's Oculus Rift, as current VR completely bypasses the sense of touch, but UltraHaptics could enable users to actually feel and interact with virtual objects. The company is working with 15-20 clients across various industries including automotive, consumer electronics, and gaming, with plans to have their first commercial product on shelves within a year.

Jodie Barden, 28, faces the heartbreaking reality of planning funerals for her two daughters, eight-year-old Ella and one-year-old Chloe, who both suffer from Cockayne Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that causes premature aging and gives patients a life expectancy of just 12 years. The syndrome is characterized by failure to gain weight, underdeveloped nervous system, and small head size, with sufferers typically dying from pneumonia before reaching their teenage years. Despite the devastating prognosis, the family is making the most of their time together while raising money for charity and planning special experiences for the girls, including trips to Australia and Disneyland Paris.

Eleven-year-old Damon Muller from Queensland has been diagnosed with Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM), a rare life-threatening autoimmune disease that causes severe muscle weakness and rashes when exposed to sunlight. Since his November diagnosis, Damon has almost doubled in size due to swelling and bloating from the high-dose steroids and chemotherapy-type drugs required to treat his condition, and he can no longer play outside freely due to severe sun sensitivity that causes dangerous rashes and throat swelling. The disease has transformed him from an active child to someone who can barely move and must stay indoors most of the time, with his family now seeking support and information about the rare condition.

Prince Harry's former girlfriend Chelsy Davy, 29, debuted a sophisticated and glamorous style at the launch party for London restaurant The Ivy Chelsea Garden on Tuesday. The Zimbabwean socialite wore a chic white chiffon top with navy trousers and tan accessories, showing a more mature fashion sense as she approaches her thirties. Davy had a six-year relationship with Prince Harry that ended in May 2010, and she is currently single after splitting from society jeweller Charles Goode in January.

Hundreds attended the funeral of nine-year-old Chloe, a French schoolgirl who was raped and murdered by Polish migrant Zbigniew Huminski after he abducted her from a playground in Calais in broad daylight on April 15. The brazen abduction happened when Chloe playfully squirted Huminski with a water pistol in front of her mother's eyes, after which he bundled her into his car and drove to woodland where he sexually assaulted and strangled her. Huminski, a career criminal who confessed to the murder soon after being arrested near Chloe's lifeless body, faces life imprisonment for the crime that shocked France and prompted thousands to march in tribute to the young victim.

Iron deficiency, particularly low ferritin levels (stored iron), can trigger hair loss in women by reducing oxygen delivery to hair follicles, and some experts recommend iron supplements to treat hair shedding, though evidence remains mixed. Since hair consists of protein, maintaining adequate protein intake through a good diet is also vital for healthy hair growth, with research showing that women with increased hair-shedding responded well to supplements containing both iron and l-lysine (an amino acid that helps iron absorption). However, dietary changes and supplements take time to show results, typically requiring 2-6 months before noticeable improvements in hair growth occur.

Meet Suma, a 36-year-old orangutan at Melbourne Zoo who suffers from arthritis, a painful condition first diagnosed in 2013 that initially required giving Suma daily pain medication. On Thursday, doctors had to anaesthetise Suma for a thorough health examination where surgeons took X-rays of her arthritic hips and ankles, and treated her with a steroid injection that will reduce her pain for months or potentially years.

New Snapchat images have emerged showing One Direction's Louis Tomlinson partying with five girls at London's Soho Hotel until at least 5:48am on Thursday morning, following his wild night out that included leaving Cirque Le Soir nightclub at 4am. The pictures show Louis in his hotel room continuing the party, and come after previous images surfaced of him appearing to roll a suspicious cigarette while sitting next to what looked like drug paraphernalia. This latest incident adds to the band's recent controversies, coming just a month after Zayn Malik left the group and following a previous video leak showing Louis and Zayn appearing to smoke marijuana during their 2014 tour.

These century-old photographs taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty show Beijing's famous landmarks and popular tourist attractions with barely any visitors, offering a rare glimpse of the Chinese capital before mass tourism. The black and white photos feature sites like the Temple of Heaven, Summer Palace, and Western Qing Tombs with only a few locals and foreigners posing casually, creating a stark contrast to modern-day Beijing which now attracts tens of millions of domestic and international tourists annually. These images provide an enchanting view of China's last imperial era, showing peaceful scenes without crowds, selfie sticks, or smog at locations that are now UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

A CoreLogic report reveals that Australian capital cities are experiencing record-breaking profits at property auctions, with only 8.6% of home resales recording a loss while 32.3% of properties are selling for more than double their original purchase price. Sydney recorded the lowest loss-making resales at just 2.4%, while Perth and Melbourne also saw extremely low resale losses of 5.5% and 5.6% respectively. The report shows that Melbourne homes are held longer than any other capital city with an average ownership period of nearly 12 years, and the total value of profit-making resales reached over $17 billion compared to only $418 million in losses.

West Brom manager Tony Pulis led his team to a 2-0 victory over his former employers Crystal Palace in a typical Tony Pulis performance, with James Morrison heading in an early goal and Craig Gardner adding a stunning 30-yard strike. Despite Alan Pardew's Palace side dominating much of the game, West Bromwich Albion's stubborn defensive style secured the three points that virtually guarantee their Premier League survival. Pulis, known for his distinctive touchline attire of cap, tracksuit and trainers, insisted he will never change his approach or style, having ended West Brom's 10-game winless away run.

Crystal Palace co-chairman Steve Parish celebrated his club's 2-1 win over champions Manchester City by posing for a photo with Palace manager Alan Pardew, England boss Roy Hodgson, and Rolling Stones founding member Bill Wyman, who is an avid Palace fan of 68 years. Parish shared the moment on Instagram, describing it as a "great moment" after the victory at Selhurst Park, where Jason Puncheon scored the winning goal. Wyman, who has supported Palace since age 10 despite spending 30 years with The Rolling Stones, was given special permission to enter the Palace boardroom without the usual dress code requirements.

The Solar Impulse 2, an experimental single-seater aircraft attempting to fly around the world using only solar power, has been grounded in China for over two weeks due to unfavorable weather conditions, as the plane requires near-perfect conditions with crosswinds under 4 knots to safely fly and land. The mission, led by pilots Bertrand Piccard and Andre Borschberg who are taking turns flying the solar-powered aircraft, aims to prove the potential of renewable energy and has been 12 years in the making. Despite the extended delays in Chongqing, the team says they are technically still on schedule as they need to wait until the end of the month for longer daylight hours before attempting the critical Pacific Ocean crossing to Hawaii.

Jordan Spieth visited the Empire State Building while proudly wearing his green jacket after his Masters triumph, where he broke several scoring records and equaled the Augusta championship record with an 18-under total. The 21-year-old's victory was fueled by last year's disappointment when he lost the lead to Bubba Watson, but this time Spieth maintained his composure through crucial moments, including a key par putt on the 16th hole that Justin Rose praised as "one of the best." Now ranked No. 2 in the world behind Rory McIlroy, Spieth has positioned himself as golf's next big star and potential rival to McIlroy, joining elite company as one of only four players to win three PGA Tour titles including a major before age 22.

Etiquette expert William Hanson has created a household audit to determine how "posh" people's homes are, inspired by scrutiny of current Prime Minister David Cameron and wife Samantha's kitchen, which has highlighted Britain's ongoing class obsessions. The audit awards points for items like cafetieres over coffee machines (which Hanson says the "pesky middle-middle classes" have fallen for), Agas, plain white toilet paper, bar soap instead of liquid, and fabric sofas over leather ones that are considered "suspect" among the upper classes. Hanson's scoring system ranges from upper class (14-18 points) down to lower-middle class (1-4 points), reflecting what he sees as the proper markers of social standing in British homes.

Andy Murray tied the knot with Kim Sears on Saturday at the 12th century Dunblane Cathedral, with thousands of fans gathering outside to celebrate the wedding day. The British tennis star and his wife were all smiles as they emerged from the wedding ceremony covered in confetti, while wedding preparations had included florists decorating the historic cathedral throughout the morning. Andy had tweeted his excitement for the day using emojis, and the minister conducting the ceremony said the whole town was excited for what he called "the nearest we'll have in recent times to a royal wedding."

Alastair Cook has been working with former England batting coach Graham Gooch on developing a more open stance, but he appears to have overdone the adjustment during the first Test against the West Indies. The article compares Cook's near-perfect stance from 2007 against India with his overly open front foot positioning against the West Indies, which forced him to play shots with his hands away from his body and contributed to his dismissal. Despite the technical struggles, the author notes that Cook looked good in practice sessions and shouldn't be written off yet.

Dani Alves looks set to leave Barcelona this summer after his agent and ex-wife Dinorah Santana confirmed the Brazilian right-back had rejected the club's final contract offer of a three-year extension. The 31-year-old defender, who has won four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice during his seven successful years at the Catalan club, was unable to agree on a new deal with Barcelona. Alves has been linked with several clubs including Manchester United and Manchester City, with his agent stating they currently have two three-year offers on the table.

Robin Ellis, the original Poldark star, was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at age 58 in 1999 despite being slim and fit, and now at 73 continues to manage the condition through diet changes and medication. Unlike his mother who had type 1 diabetes and died at 67 from complications, Robin has successfully controlled his type 2 diabetes for over two decades by eliminating refined carbohydrates and sugar from his diet, though he recently required heart stents due to artery blockages caused by high blood sugar levels. His case highlights that type 2 diabetes rates are soaring and can affect even slim people, as the condition involves the body's cells failing to respond properly to insulin rather than a lack of insulin production.

Former New England Patriots tight end Aaron Hernandez, who was convicted of first-degree murder on April 15 for killing 27-year-old Odin Lloyd in 2013, has been transferred from Cedar Junction prison to the maximum-security Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center in Shirley, Massachusetts. A state prisons official confirmed that the 25-year-old Hernandez, who was sentenced to life in prison, was moved to the facility on Wednesday, where he will be housed among more than 1,000 inmates, many serving life sentences. It remains unknown which specific cell block Hernandez will be placed in, with options including solitary confinement, general population, or the "lifers block" for those serving life sentences.

Jamie Robbins, a robber who stole £1,600 from a convenience store in Birmingham with an accomplice using a machete, handed himself into police a year after the crime because he preferred life in prison. The 35-year-old was jailed for four-and-a-half years after pleading guilty to robbery and possession of a bladed article at Birmingham Crown Court, though he had a change of heart about wanting to return to prison after discovering his girlfriend was pregnant the day before his court appearance. The case had gone unsolved until Robbins voluntarily confessed, providing full details that led to his conviction.

Injaz, the world's first cloned camel who was created in 2009 from ovarian cells of a slaughtered camel and born via surrogate mother, is now pregnant at six years old after conceiving naturally. Scientists are excited about this development as it proves that cloned camels are fertile and can reproduce like naturally-born camels, marking a significant milestone 19 years after Dolly the sheep became the first cloned mammal. This pregnancy demonstrates the success of camel cloning technology, which is valuable in the Persian Gulf region where camels are prized for racing, transport, and beauty contests.

Former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson revealed during a snooker frame with 1991 World Champion John Parrott and presenter Hazel Irvine at the BBC's World Championship coverage that he rates Cristiano Ronaldo above Lionel Messi. Ferguson believes his former United player Ronaldo is superior to Barcelona's talisman because "Ronaldo could play for Millwall, QPR, Doncaster Rovers, anyone, and score a hat-trick," while he's not sure Messi could do the same outside of Barcelona. Although Ferguson struggled during his snooker frame against Parrott, he shared anecdotes about beating former player Paul Ince at the game and discussed his love for snooker memorabilia.

The Fenerbahce team bus carrying players and coaching staff was shot at on Saturday night after their 5-1 win over Caykur Rizespor, with the driver being hit by a bullet and suffering a head injury that required hospitalization. None of the players were hurt in the attack, which occurred near Trabzon as the bus was traveling to the airport. Separately, Caykur Rizespor midfielder Ludovic Obraniak was taken to hospital with a suspected heart problem during the match but was reported to be in no immediate danger.

Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland's First Minister and SNP leader, delivered a commanding performance in a nationwide TV debate that impressed viewers outside Scotland for the first time, with Judy Murray tweeting "GSM Sturgeon" (Game, Set and Match) about her triumph. The article argues that the beguiling Sturgeon, who has been hailed as "Scotland's Queen" by young fans, could wield huge influence over the next Westminster government despite the SNP losing the independence referendum, potentially taking 45 of Scotland's 59 seats and holding the balance of power. The author warns that Sturgeon is "the most dangerous woman in British politics" because her left-wing agenda and continued push for Scottish independence could create a political crisis if she props up a Miliband government, ultimately making the union with Scotland unsustainable.

Ulster and Ireland prop Declan Fitzpatrick, 31, has been forced to retire from rugby on medical grounds after experiencing multiple concussive episodes in recent seasons that were progressively slower to resolve. Ulster said that after medical tests and consultation with a neurologist, it was recommended that retirement would be in Fitzpatrick's long-term interests for his health. The player, who won seven caps for Ireland and made 98 Ulster appearances, expressed gratitude for his nine seasons at Ulster Rugby while acknowledging the difficulty of the decision.

Oregon-based defense contractor FLIR Systems Inc. has agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle bribery charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission involving expensive trips and luxury gifts given to Middle Eastern government officials. The SEC investigation found that FLIR's Dubai office employees gave luxury watches to Saudi Arabia Ministry of Interior officials and arranged extensive travel, while the company's deficient financial controls failed to identify and stop these corrupt practices. Two former FLIR sales employees have separately agreed to settle SEC charges and pay financial penalties for their role in the scheme that helped secure multimillion-dollar contracts.

American television network Showtime has released a short promotional video taking viewers inside Floyd Mayweather Jr's training camp ahead of his $300 million mega fight against Manny Pacquiao on May 2. The video shows Mayweather working intensively in preparation for what's being called the "Fight of the Century," with the undefeated boxer stating he has "never wanted to win a fight so bad in my life." Mayweather is currently within three-and-a-half pounds of the 147 lbs welterweight limit as he prepares for the bout at MGM Grand in Las Vegas.

Diwalinen Vankar, 58, heroically fought off a 13-foot mugger crocodile with a wooden washing paddle after it attacked her 19-year-old daughter Kanta at the Vishwamitri River in west India, where they had gone to wash clothes. The crocodile clasped Kanta's right leg in its jaws and dragged her into the water, prompting a 10-minute battle where Vankar feared the crocodile would drown her daughter before she successfully freed her by repeatedly hitting the reptile's head. Kanta suffered leg injuries from the attack but has since been discharged from the hospital and is expected to make a full recovery.

This article counts down the 20 greatest shots ever seen at Augusta National Golf Club ahead of the 79th Masters, featuring shots 20-11. Notable moments include Mark O'Meara's winning 20-foot putt at age 41 in 1998, Billy Joe Patton's hole-in-one in 1954 that nearly led to the biggest Masters upset before a double bogey dashed his hopes, and Charl Schwartzel's incredible 2011 victory that featured remarkable shots including a 100-foot chip-in for birdie and a slam-dunk eagle approach.

In tonight's episode of Married at First Sight, the three newlywed couples experience serious relationship troubles during their honeymoons, with Jaclyn Methuen confessing in a web exclusive clip that she wanted to be a runaway bride and nearly left husband Ryan Ranellone at the altar because she found him unattractive. Despite some progress when Jaclyn lets Ryan playfully apply sunscreen to her bottom during their Puerto Rico honeymoon, she continues to put him in the "friend zone" by calling him "dude" and "bro." The other couples also face challenges, with Jessica Castro and Ryan DeNiro arguing over dinner in Key Largo, and Davina Kullar crying on a ski lift in Colorado while feeling disconnected from her new husband Sean Varricchio.

The Taliban has released an 11-page biography of their reclusive leader Mullah Mohammed Omar, apparently aimed at dispelling rumors of his death since he disappeared after the U.S.-led bombing campaign that routed the Taliban from Afghanistan in 2001. The biography describes Omar's early life, including how he studied at a religious school before commanding rebel groups against Soviet forces in the 1980s, and claims he still leads the Taliban's self-declared Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan through various councils and military commanders operating across the country. The publication appears to be an attempt to reassert Omar's leadership credentials at a time when ISIS has declared its own caliphate and Taliban militants continue battling the U.S.-backed Afghan government.

The NFL launched an investigation in January into the New England Patriots' use of underinflated footballs during the AFC Championship game, hiring attorney Ted Wells (who previously investigated the Miami Dolphins bullying scandal) to conduct a thorough review that has now lasted over three months. Patriots quarterback Tom Brady called the accusation of using deflated footballs "ridiculous," while head coach Bill Belichick denied any intent to compromise game integrity, and owner Robert Kraft demanded an apology if no wrongdoing is found. The Patriots could face fines and loss of draft picks if found guilty, similar to punishments recently given to other teams for rules violations.

Paul Gascoigne's daughter Bianca, a former model, was mugged by a gang of eight attackers on bikes in central London who stole her phone that reportedly contained private texts from her father. The 28-year-old was targeted while walking in Marylebone and fought back when the muggers attempted to snatch her bag after grabbing her phone. Bianca later took to Twitter to brand her attackers "lowlifes on bikes" and was said to be devastated about the private texts stored on the stolen device.

Aberdeen striker Adam Rooney, who has scored 27 goals this season and was nominated for PFA Scotland Player of the Year, is determined to prevent Celtic from celebrating their fourth successive Premiership title at Pittodrie on May 11. With Aberdeen currently eight points behind Celtic, Rooney admits that watching Celtic celebrate title glory at their home ground would be a painful experience after pushing the champions so close this season. Despite losing all three previous meetings with Celtic this season, Rooney remains optimistic about Aberdeen's future prospects and hopes the team can close the gap further next season.

Former rap mogul Marion "Suge" Knight was ordered Thursday to stand trial on charges of murder, attempted murder, and hit-and-run stemming from a deadly incident where he allegedly ran over two men with his vehicle, killing Terry Carter and injuring Cle Sloan, who refused to testify against Knight. Judge Ronald Coen lowered Knight's bail from $25 million to $10 million and dismissed one of the two hit-and-run counts, while Knight's defense argued he was acting in self-defense against an armed aggressor. Knight, who suffers from diabetes and blood clots, faces up to life in prison if convicted and is scheduled for arraignment on April 30.

Hillary Clinton's campaign staged what appeared to be a spontaneous coffee shop meeting in Iowa by having campaign staffer Troy Price recruit three Democratic Party insiders, including Austin Bird (who had previously worked on Obama's 2012 campaign and chauffeured VP Biden), Iowa College Democrats president Carter Bell, and a Planned Parenthood employee. Bird revealed that Price called them to what they thought was a strategy meeting, then drove them to the coffee shop where they participated in a "roundtable" with Clinton that was portrayed by media as an authentic interaction with ordinary Iowans. This staging is part of Clinton's broader pattern of orchestrating seemingly spontaneous campaign events during her Iowa swing, which could backfire in a state where voters expect genuine grassroots politicking.

The UK's first HIV self-testing kit, the BioSure HIV Self Test, is now on sale online with 99.7% accuracy, allowing people to discreetly test themselves at home using a finger-prick blood sample that detects HIV antibodies and provides results in 15 minutes. An estimated 26,000 people in the UK have undiagnosed HIV, with 40% remaining undiagnosed for at least four years, making early detection crucial since treatments now make HIV a manageable disease but late diagnosis significantly impacts health outcomes. While positive test results still need confirmation from healthcare professionals, this self-testing kit represents a significant step toward normalizing HIV testing and empowering people to know their HIV status conveniently and privately.

The California Department of Corrections has established several Sensitive Needs Housing Units within Level IV maximum-security facilities to protect former gang members who have chosen to leave their criminal organizations, allowing prisoners of different races and former rival gangs to coexist peacefully. These exclusive units provide a safer environment free from gang activity, where inmates can participate in programs and earn federal minimum wage, in stark contrast to the Administrative Segregation Housing Units where gang-affiliated prisoners still remain subject to 22-hour solitary confinement and extreme segregation. Among California's approximately 162,000 inmates, an estimated 97% in maximum-security facilities are gang-affiliated, making these specialized housing units crucial for those seeking to escape the cycle of prison gang violence and murders.

Direct Assist, a personal injury claims company based in Bolton, Lancashire, has collapsed after being fined £80,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office for plaguing households with nuisance calls. The company received 801 complaints between January 2013 and July last year, with the ICO finding that Direct Assist deliberately used phone numbers from lists that included people registered with the Telephone Preference Service who had not given permission to be contacted. Despite being warned 525 times by the TPS about complaints, the company continued making unsolicited calls and even told one complainant they would be called for three years until they made a claim.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has the best clean sheets percentage record in Premier League history, achieving 101 clean sheets in 189 Premier League matches (53.4%), which has twice helped him lead Chelsea to Premier League glory with a third title likely this season. Mourinho also heads the list for lowest average goals conceded per game at 0.63, beating former Chelsea manager Rafa Benitez who ranks second in clean sheets percentage at 44.9%, while Arsenal's Arsene Wenger ranks lower in both defensive categories despite his long tenure.

Authorities detained a 15-year-old girl from Cape Town, South Africa, at Cape Town International Airport after receiving information that she was attempting to leave the country to join ISIS. Police and airport security located the girl on a Johannesburg-bound flight following investigations into her social media activity, where she had been interacting with suspicious individuals and reading material suggesting interest in joining the terrorist group. The incident highlights the growing global concern about the recruitment and radicalization of young people by terrorist organizations, similar to cases involving other teens like a Virginia teen previously accused of being an ISIS recruiter.

Ben Powers, who played Thelma's husband Keith Anderson on the final season of the classic CBS sitcom "Good Times" from 1978-1979, died April 6 in New Bedford, Mass. at age 64, with no cause of death revealed. Powers also had roles on the CBS detective drama show "Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer" and appeared in several films, and attended the Rhode Island School of Design before pursuing acting and stand-up comedy.

A 39-year-old father of six, known on Facebook as Karl Kay, was killed in a cold-blooded execution-style shooting while sitting in a car in his mother's Altona Meadows driveway at 2am on Sunday. The man was shot numerous times in what police believe was a targeted attack, with Homicide Detective Sergeant Sol Solomon confirming the victim was known to police. No arrests have been made and police have not commented on whether the incident was gang-related, while the man's traumatized mother and other family members are assisting with the investigation.

Alexander Kutner visited Sir Richard Branson's luxurious Ulusaba Game Reserve in South Africa's Sabi Sands for a graduation reward safari, where he came face-to-face with a 4,500lb horned rhino while crawling under a Land Rover to photograph the endangered animals. With expert guides Trevor and Danny, Kutner's group encountered the Big Five including three rhinos, lions, elephants, buffalo, and leopards, highlighting the conservation challenges as 1,000 rhinos were killed by poachers in South Africa last year alone. The safari experience at the private game reserve offered close encounters with wildlife including cheetahs and various antelope species, providing exceptional photography opportunities in this protected wilderness area.

George Lucas dropped plans to build a Lucasfilm Ltd studio complex on his Lucas Valley Road property in 2012 after facing opposition from neighbors, but now proposes to build the largest affordable housing development in the area instead. The $200 million project would create a 224-home complex for low-income families and seniors on 52 acres of his Grady Ranch estate in Marin County, California. This is not the first time Lucas has courted controversy with his building plans, as he previously faced legal challenges over his proposed museum in Chicago.

A stunning series of photographs captured the moment a great grey owl with an impressive five-foot wingspan swooped down on a tiny field mouse in the snowy fields of Ontario, Canada. The predatory bird stalked its prey from treetops before launching a silent attack, using its superior hearing and soft feathers to glide undetected. The dramatic bird's eye view images show the grey owl making an inelegant landing in the snow while clutching the rodent with its sharp claws.

Author Martin Fletcher, a survivor of the devastating 1985 Bradford City Valley Parade fire that killed 56 people, has published a book claiming the deadly blaze was not an accident and linking then-Bradford chairman Stafford Heginbotham to eight other fires at his businesses over 18 years. Fletcher's research suggests these previous blazes resulted in insurance payouts totaling around £27 million in today's terms, challenging the official inquiry's conclusion that the fire was caused by a discarded cigarette. West Yorkshire police have said they will review any fresh evidence surrounding the tragedy, though the original judge maintains his ruling that it was an accident exacerbated by negligence.

Manchester City defender Bacary Sagna insists he has no regrets about leaving Arsenal for City last summer, despite City currently sitting fourth in the Premier League while Arsenal are second and defending FA Cup champions. The 32-year-old French international, who has made only 16 appearances this season, said he would make the same decision again even though City's Premier League title will likely go to Chelsea this year. Sagna believes Manuel Pellegrini's side will return to winning ways and finish the season strongly, dismissing concerns about potentially losing their Champions League qualifying position.

Nigel Farage suggested that Prime Minister David Cameron has been secretly using hair dye to reverse the greying process, saying he was "jealous" of how Cameron's appearance has improved while in Downing Street. Farage made these comments after shaking Cameron's hand following last week's televised leaders debate, where he complimented the Prime Minister on his appearance. While Downing Street previously denied claims in 2011 that Cameron dyes his hair, a Tory party spokesman refused to comment on the allegations when asked again.
