Australian woman Evita Nicole Sarmonikas, 29, died during a Brazilian butt lift procedure in March at a Mexican clinic, where plastic surgeon Dr. Victor Ramirez had his certification lapsed and was found to have lost another patient the year before. The clinic attempted to pressure her family into having her body cremated before an official autopsy could be conducted, but her family flew to Mexico to retrieve her body and ensure a proper investigation. Dr. Ramirez has since been suspended and the Hospital Quirurgico del Valle has been closed down due to reports of poor hygiene and unsafe practices.

Help for Heroes has launched a fundraising campaign to keep 96-year-old World War II veteran Robert Clark in his own home after Brent Council refused to continue paying for his live-in care, despite Clark having spent his £50,000 life savings contributing to the costs. The veteran, who suffered severe anxiety as a prisoner of war and survived Hitler's death march, faces being moved to a care home, which his family says would remind him of being imprisoned and cause him to "give up on life." Help for Heroes has provided an emergency grant and started a JustGiving page that has raised over £2,700 toward the £5,000 target to secure his future care at home.

FC Chernomorets Odessa, a Ukrainian Premier League club struggling with severe financial difficulties, is offering their players luxury houses worth around £67,000 near the sea to cover unpaid salary debts. The club's dire financial situation has forced them to sell their best players and slash remaining players' salaries from over £7,000 to £2,000 per month or less. If they fail to settle their outstanding debts, the club faces potential relegation and disqualification from UEFA competitions.

Kestutis Martuzevicius, a 52-year-old Lithuanian gangster accused of 22 crimes including two murders in his home country, repeatedly stalled extradition efforts for nearly five years by claiming deportation would breach his human rights due to depression and mental illness. The European Court of Human Rights ultimately rejected his "manifestly ill-founded" case, ruling that he should be extradited to Lithuania where he is wanted for crimes committed as a member of the feared Daktarai gang between 1993 and 1997. His prolonged legal battle cost British taxpayers hundreds of thousands of pounds in police time, legal fees, prison costs, and psychiatric treatment at Broadmoor hospital.

A vigilante group in North-West England is accused of posing as underage girls online to lure men, then attacking them and demanding money to keep assault videos secret. One teenager told Greater Manchester Police he was beaten up by the gang after being tricked into meeting what he thought was a 14-year-old girl in a church car park, while a second incident saw 25-year-old Andrew O'Neill assaulted in Wigan town center and losing two front teeth. Both men were subsequently arrested and charged by police - the teenager on suspicion of grooming and O'Neill, who admitted to attempting to meet an underage girl following grooming.

Real Madrid's Champions League starters, including Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale, and James Rodriguez, rested on Wednesday after playing 90 minutes in Tuesday's 0-0 draw against rivals Atletico in their Champions League quarter-final first leg, while the remaining squad members trained at Valdebebas. The team will return to La Liga action on Saturday against Malaga before facing Atletico again in next Wednesday's second leg, as they continue searching for their first win against their neighbors this season. Meanwhile, defender Dani Carvajal denied accusations that he attempted to bite Atletico striker Mario Mandzukic during the heated derby match.

David Hibbitt, a 33-year-old bowel cancer patient diagnosed with stage-three advanced bowel cancer, claims he has been cured after trying cannabis oil as a last resort when doctors told him he had only 18 months to five years to live. After undergoing traditional treatments including chemotherapy and surgery, Hibbitt decided to stop conventional treatment and use cannabis oil, and his January scan showed he was cancer-free. However, Cancer Research UK emphasizes there is no good clinical evidence that cannabis extracts can safely and effectively treat cancer in patients, though they are supporting trials to gather solid data on cannabinoid-based treatments.

President Barack Obama visited Everglades National Park in Florida on Earth Day to highlight how climate change is threatening America's national treasures, using the shrinking Everglades as evidence that climate change "can no longer be denied" and requires immediate action. Despite criticism about his gas-guzzling trip to Florida potentially undermining his Earth Day message, the White House reaffirmed Obama's efforts to reduce pollutants and said the visit would not contradict his environmental stance. Obama warned that rising sea levels and salt water intrusion are already affecting South Florida communities, emphasizing that climate change is "not a problem for another generation" but a current threat that requires political will to solve.

Real Madrid failed to activate their first option to buy 26-year-old Manchester United striker Javier Hernandez outright after the midnight deadline passed on Thursday without Madrid making a formal offer. Despite Hernandez's impressive recent form, scoring five goals in his last six games including crucial strikes against Atletico Madrid and in Madrid's 4-2 win at Celta Vigo, the exclusivity period has ended and other clubs like West Ham, Southampton, Newcastle and Lazio can now bid for the Mexican striker who faces an uncertain future.

Bonnie Doll, a Swedish gamer living in Australia since 2007, has turned her Call of Duty gaming skills into a lucrative career by live streaming on Twitch, earning enough money to quit her hospitality job. The 28-year-old Brisbane resident has gained over 45,000 followers who pay subscriptions and donations to watch her play on Xbox, with her channel receiving almost one million views. Despite facing online trolls and privacy issues including leaked personal information, Bonnie continues to work from home streaming games from 8am to 2pm on weekdays, describing herself as Australia's answer to Lara Croft in the gaming world.

YouTube is set to offer its first ad-free, subscription-based service according to an email sent to YouTube Partners, with updated Partner Program Terms taking effect June 15, 2015, that will pay creators 55% of subscription fee revenues. The Google-owned video giant has already launched YouTube Music Key beta, an invite-only subscription music service costing $9.99/month that provides ad-free music and offline viewing capabilities. Music Key matches competitors like Spotify in pricing and features but adds the bonus of music videos, representing YouTube's broader push into subscription services beyond its traditional advertising model.

Marion "Suge" Knight was rushed to the hospital for an unspecified medical emergency on Thursday after a judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges for a January hit-and-run incident that killed Terry Carter and seriously injured Cle "Bone" Sloan. Security camera footage shows Knight struggling with Sloan through his truck window before striking both men with his vehicle outside a Compton burger stand. Knight faces up to life in prison if convicted, with his defense claiming he was trying to escape after being attacked by Sloan.

Bailey Murrill, a young patient from Texas, was inexplicably paralyzed from the waist down for 11 days while being cared for in the hospital. When her favorite nurse came on shift, Bailey surprised her by suddenly getting up from her wheelchair and walking toward her, causing the shocked nurse to scream with joy and burst into tears. The heartwarming moment was captured on video by Bailey's mother Becky Murrill, though the cause of Bailey's unexpected paralysis remains unknown.

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors in London at the Ecuadorian Embassy, where he has been seeking asylum since 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden over 2010 sexual assault allegations. Swedish prosecutors had previously refused to travel to Britain but changed their approach due to an approaching statute of limitations deadline in August 2015. Assange, who denies the allegations and has not been charged, fears that Sweden would extradite him to the United States where he could face the death penalty for publishing government secrets through WikiLeaks.

Big Brother star Pete Bennett, who won the show in 2006, appeared on the Jeremy Kyle show to reveal he is now homeless and broke despite winning £100,000 prize money nine years ago. Bennett admitted to developing a severe ketamine addiction that lasted years, spending all his winnings on drugs after fame from the reality show made it difficult for him to find work or be taken seriously as a musician. Although he has since sought help for his addiction and his Tourette's Syndrome has improved significantly, Bennett continues to struggle with homelessness while attempting to rebuild his life through acting.

Borussia Dortmund returned to winning ways with a comfortable 3-0 victory over relegation-threatened Paderborn, with goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan, Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, and Shinji Kagawa. The win moved last season's Bundesliga runners-up to eighth in the table after losing their two previous Bundesliga matches, and came just three days after manager Jurgen Klopp announced he will quit the club at the end of the season. Dortmund fans held up signs thanking Klopp for his achievements as the team showed no signs of being affected by their manager's departure announcement.

North Korean defector Lee Min-bok launches balloons from South Korea carrying thousands of copies of "The Interview" and propaganda materials into North Korean territory, believing the film threatens Pyongyang's tightly controlled state media portrayal of leader Kim Jong Un as godlike. After Pyongyang fired on similar propaganda balloons recently and South Korea returned fire last October, both South Korean authorities and local residents oppose these launches, with residents fearing they are being put in the line of fire. Despite not knowing if ordinary North Koreans actually receive the materials, Lee continues the nighttime operations believing they help spread truth to a population where "if you tell the truth in North Korea, you die."

An Israeli company called Amited has designed a thermal protection phone case called Optimal that automatically regulates smartphone temperature to prevent overheating and damage from extreme cold weather. The case uses built-in micro-fans to cool phones when they get too hot from excessive use, and resistance coils to warm devices in freezing conditions, while Optimal's sensors continuously monitor subtle temperature changes via Bluetooth connectivity. The company is launching an Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign on April 9th to fund production, though prices have not yet been announced.

At least 54 people have died and 15 others are missing after the Russian commercial fishing vessel Dalniy Vostok freezer trawler sank off the Kamchatka Peninsula, according to Russia's state-run Tass news agency. More than 60 people were rescued Thursday from the waters, while over 20 fishing vessels are searching for the 15 people still missing. The shipwreck occurred swiftly within 15 minutes, with officials citing a likely collision with an obstacle that damaged the hull as the most probable cause.

This article reviews ten essential food apps that every foodie should have, ranging from free options like Love Food Hate Waste (which helps with meal planning and tracks foods in your fridge) to premium apps like Where Chefs Eat (£10.99) that features over 3,000 chef recommendations from world-renowned culinary professionals. The list includes diverse apps such as British Street Food for finding the best street food vendors in Britain, Jamie Oliver's free app with easy-to-follow recipes, and various other planning and dining apps that cover everything from wine selection to restaurant bookings.

Frances Clarkson, 53, was photographed enjoying a holiday in Barbados wearing a white bikini, while her estranged husband Jeremy Clarkson continues to battle to save his career after being sacked from Top Gear. The couple, who married in 1993 and have three children together, have reportedly been living apart for years amid allegations of Clarkson's extramarital affairs, including accusations in April 2011 of an affair with events organizer Phillipa Sage. Clarkson was dropped from the BBC show last month after he left Top Gear producer Oisin Tymon needing hospital treatment following a physical attack at a hotel, though he will not face criminal charges for the incident.

Discount supermarket Aldi is under fire for failing to adequately disclose a 0.5 percent surcharge on credit card transactions and tap-and-go payments to customers, six months after promising the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) it would notify shoppers through store signage and cashier announcements. Despite Aldi's commitment to put up signs at store entrances and registers, many stores still lack proper notification or display warnings in tiny print, leaving customers unaware of the additional charges. ASIC had taken action against Aldi for not disclosing these surcharges, which the company says it has always charged to cover credit card processing costs rather than inflating prices across all products.

In 1942, the HMS Ulster Queen, a former Irish Sea ferry converted to a battle cruiser, transported Russian bullion from Murmansk to Scotland as payment to America for wartime arms, but during the unloading process in the river Clyde, one case of precious metals accidentally slipped and fell overboard. This wartime blunder has only come to light through the secret diary of Leonard H. Thomas, one of the Ulster Queen's engineers who served on four convoys to Russia's extreme northwest, and the lost bullion may still be lying in the muddy waters of the Clyde today.

Luis Suarez's wife Sofia revealed that the Barcelona striker initially denied biting Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini during their World Cup match in Brazil, telling her he hadn't done anything wrong. The Uruguayan received a four-month ban for the incident, but Sofia told Canal 10 that Suarez maintained his innocence for 10 days before finally admitting the truth to her. Despite the controversy surrounding the bite, Suarez completed his £75million move from Liverpool to Barcelona and has since performed excellently for his new club.

Ranulfo Perez, 48, who dresses as Cookie Monster in New York's Times Square, was arrested for allegedly groping a 16-year-old girl from Wisconsin, but was later released when the teenager could not definitively identify him as her attacker. This incident is part of a growing pattern of problems with costumed characters in Times Square, with nearly 20 costumed performers arrested last year for various offenses including sexual harassment, disorderly conduct, and aggressive panhandling. Police have launched "Operation Sesame Street" to crack down on these issues and are considering requiring the characters to obtain licenses.

Marc Wabafiyebazu, 15, was arrested for felony murder after his 17-year-old brother Jean was killed during a gunfight that erupted Monday when the brothers allegedly attempted to rob Miami drug dealers during a marijuana purchase. Their mother is Roxanne Dubé, the recently appointed Canadian Consul General in Miami, and the boys had driven to the drug deal in her diplomatic-plated BMW. Anthony Rodriguez, one of the drug dealers, was also arrested on charges of felony murder and marijuana possession with intent to sell.

Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, a 42-year-old family doctor working at Custom House Surgery in East London, admitted secretly filming men in gym showers by cutting holes in Lynx shampoo bottles and concealing his iPhone inside before sliding the bottles under shower cubicles. Al-Atraqchi pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism after incidents at Pure Gym in Holloway where he was caught twice - once when a victim noticed a camera lens through the bottle and again when a fitness instructor became suspicious of the device. He now faces being struck off the medical register after a tribunal found him guilty of misconduct, with the panel expressing concerns about his poor insight and risk of repeating the behavior.

John T. Booker Jr., a former U.S. Army enlistee from Kansas, was arrested Friday and charged with attempting to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base after he believed ISIS wanted him to commit a truck bombing in the United States. Booker's Army enlistment was terminated in March 2014 after he told FBI agents he had enlisted to commit an insider attack, and he was arrested near the base with what he thought was a bomb but was actually made of inert materials by FBI informants. A second man, Alexander E. Blair, was also charged with failing to report the felony after he knew of Booker's bomb plot and even loaned him money for storage space but did not contact authorities.

Swedish scientists studying more than 10,000 families found that children aged two to 14 who experience stressful events such as death or illness in the family, divorce, or separation could be three times more likely to develop type 1 diabetes. Of the 58 children who were subsequently diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, many were among those who had been badly affected by traumatic events during their formative years. The researchers suggest that while the exact causes of type 1 diabetes remain unknown, experiencing serious life events during the first 14 years of life may be a significant risk factor for developing the condition.

Fifteen-year-old Jamar Nicholson is suing Los Angeles for $20 million after being shot in the back by LAPD Officer Miguel Gutierrez when his friend was holding a toy gun with an orange tip that officers mistook for real. Nicholson and his friend Jason Huerta were hanging out in an alleyway before school when officers from the criminal gang-homicide unit approached with guns drawn and opened fire. The teenagers' attorneys argue that the LAPD "shot first and asked questions later," while the police claim they ordered the teen with the toy gun to drop it multiple times before shooting.

A man was caught on camera sleeping on the baggage conveyor belt at Russia's Domodedovo Airport, curled up in the fetal position while other passengers tried to collect their luggage around him. The incident appeared to amuse some waiting passengers, though the swinging motion of the conveyor would have made for a less-than-comfortable snooze. This follows similar cases of passengers falling asleep on baggage reclaim systems, including an inebriated Chinese passenger who ended up going through an X-ray scanner and a Norwegian man at Rome's airport who had climbed over a check-in desk before taking his unconventional rest.

For the first time in its 100-year history, Cadbury's is set to release a special edition super bar called the Dairy Milk Spectacular, which contains seven different fillings including Dairy Milk Caramel, Fruit & Nut, Whole Nut, Oreo, Daim, and Turkish flavors, with each variety occupying one row of the seven-row chocolate bar. However, only 50 of these special edition bars have been created as part of a competition to encourage chocolate lovers to try new flavors, making them extremely limited and not available in regular stores.

Muhammadu Buhari, a 72-year-old former military leader who ruled Nigeria harshly in the 1980s, won the presidential election by running on an anti-corruption platform, marking Nigeria's first peaceful transition of power in history. The victory comes as Nigeria faces a dual crisis of widespread corruption that has made the country's poor victims of elite venality, and a bloody terrorist insurgency led by Boko Haram in the north that the dysfunctional government has failed to adequately combat. Ordinary Nigerians, exhausted by years of misrule and unable to be bought off due to falling oil prices, voted for Buhari hoping he can restore security and tackle the corruption that has plagued the country.

Disgraced comedian Daniel O'Reilly has resurrected his controversial "Dapper Laughs" persona and documented his journey to Sydney via Doha and Melbourne, filming himself chatting up air stewardesses and mocking airport cleaners along the way. O'Reilly's TV show "Dapper Laughs: On The Pull" was previously cancelled by ITV after over 60,000 people signed a petition and 44 comedians wrote an open letter condemning his sexist comedy, leading him to declare on BBC Newsnight that "Dapper Laughs is gone." Despite his previous admission that he had gotten "carried away" with success and that the controversy had "wrecked his life," O'Reilly brought back the character on Christmas Day and has now taken his act to Australia.

Nine British Muslims, including Waheed Ahmed (the 21-year-old son of Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed), were caught trying to cross into Syria from Turkey and are suspected of attempting to join ISIS. Labour MP Simon Danczuk said the family should not be welcome back in England and criticized the idea that people prepared to join terrorist organizations could return to civilian life without consequences. The group, consisting of three men, two women, and four children aged 1-11, were arrested in Turkey and are expected to return to the UK this week.

Avril Lavigne revealed she has Lyme disease, a debilitating bacterial infection contracted through a tick bite that left her bedridden for five months with severe symptoms including weakness, fatigue, and difficulty breathing, making her feel like she was dying. The 30-year-old singer struggled to get diagnosed by doctors and has since been recovering at her Ontario home with support from her family. Lyme disease affects around 65,000 people in Europe and 25,000 Americans annually, with symptoms ranging from headaches and joint pain to severe fatigue and even dementia if not treated early with antibiotics.

An Egyptian court sentenced 71 people to life in prison for their role in burning the Virgin Mary Church in August 2013, part of attacks on at least 42 Christian churches including St. George Church that targeted Coptic Christians. Additionally, two minors received 10-year prison sentences and fines for the church torching, which occurred amid broader violence following the ouster of former president Mohamed Morsy, who was himself recently convicted and sentenced to 20 years in prison on separate charges.

Australian police arrested five young men on Saturday in a major counterterrorism operation, charging two of them with conspiring to commit ISIS-inspired terrorist acts targeting police officers during the Anzac Day ceremony on April 25. The suspects, including 18-year-old Sevdet Besim who was denied bail, allegedly planned to attack during the centennial commemoration of the Gallipoli Campaign, prompting authorities to express concern about the young age of those involved in such terror plots.

Aston Villa winger Carles N'Zogbia arrived at Tuesday's training session wearing a flamboyant flowery outfit that drew ridicule from teammate Shay Given, who posted a photo on Twitter calling it "the worst ever." The incident comes as Villa manager Tim Sherwood, who became famous for his gilet-wearing fashion choices during his time at Tottenham, continues to give N'Zogbia regular playing time since his February appointment. Villa recently moved six points clear of the Premier League relegation zone with a 1-0 victory over Tottenham and will face Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final at Wembley.

British photographer Laura Stevens created a therapeutic photography project called "Another November" following her own painful breakup, directing friends and other women to pose in staged scenes that capture the emotional stages often experienced after losing love. The series shows women in intimate, melancholic moments - sitting alone at dinner, lying in bed, or studying their reflections - as they navigate feelings of loneliness, loss of appetite, and questions about attractiveness following relationship breakdown. Stevens titled the project after the month she and her partner separated, and says creating these images helped her process her own grief while providing a therapeutic outlet for the other women involved, who each brought their own stories of heartbreak to the project.

Andy Murray appeared nervous as he arrived at Dunblane Cathedral on Friday for his wedding rehearsal with long-term girlfriend Kim Sears, whom he is marrying on Saturday in his hometown. The former Wimbledon champion looked typically stony-faced before the rehearsal, while his fiancée Kim Sears appeared to be in a rush to get through the service preparations. The pair, who have been together for 10 years after meeting at the 2005 US Open, ran through their wedding service at the cathedral with friends and family ahead of their big day.

Pennsylvania police Officer Lisa Mearkle has been charged with criminal homicide for fatally shooting unarmed motorist David Kassick in the back on February 2, with stun gun video footage clearly showing Kassick lying face down on the ground when she fired two bullets into him. Mearkle's defense attorneys are trying to keep the video evidence out of court, claiming she acted in self-defense because she believed Kassick was reaching for a weapon, though the District Attorney called the video the strongest evidence showing Kassick had nothing in his hands when shot. The case stems from a traffic stop for expired stickers that escalated when Kassick fled, leading to the fatal shooting that has resulted in charges ranging from involuntary manslaughter to murder.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time Formula 1 world champion Michael Schumacher, returned to racing just weeks after a 100mph crash, making his pre-season test debut in German Formula 4 with Van Amersfoort Racing. During the test session at the Oschersleben circuit, he was pictured accidentally going off track into gravel, though he had previously finished second in world, European and German kart championships last season. His father Michael, who won the Formula 1 championship seven times, is still recovering from a December 2013 ski accident.

Bruce Jenner will chronicle his gender transition journey in a forthcoming eight-episode docu-series on E! starting July 27, following his revealing interview with Diane Sawyer. However, his six biological children (including sons Burt, Brandon, and Brody Jenner) and stepdaughter Kim Kardashian are reportedly concerned that the reality show might "de-class" what he accomplished in the well-received ABC interview, urging him to slow down on revealing too much publicly. Despite his family's worries, Bruce believes the docu-series will educate people and create empathy, and remains committed to sharing his transition journey with TV viewers.

The RSPCA is considering abandoning its controversial policy of pursuing fox hunting prosecutions after the collapse of its latest case against William Bryer of the Cattistock Hunt, leaving the animal charity with no remaining legal actions under the Hunting Act. Following criticism for spending £22.5 million on prosecutions last year, a report commissioned by the charity recommended abandoning the policy and leaving hunting prosecutions to the Crown Prosecution Service, which has more expertise. Fox hunting was outlawed in 2005, but hunts continue to operate legally through trail hunting, where scent is dragged across fields rather than chasing live animals.

Darren Stanton, a former police officer who has become the UK's top human lie detector and body language expert, appeared on ITV's This Morning to demonstrate his skills at detecting deception. Contrary to the common belief that liars can't look you in the eye, Stanton explained that liars often stare and give away their dishonesty through micro-expressions, twitching, and other body language signals. He successfully caught both presenters Amanda Holden and Philip Schofield fibbing during the show, identifying Holden's lie through a slight mouth flick and Schofield's through a raised eyebrow.

The article explains the significance of Holy Week and Easter weekend, focusing on the Easter Triduum - the three-day period from Good Friday through Easter Sunday that commemorates Jesus's crucifixion, death, and resurrection. Jesus celebrated the Last Supper on Maundy Thursday before his crucifixion on Good Friday, where he suffered and asked God why he had forsaken him, followed by Holy Saturday's period of transition, and culminating in Easter Sunday when Christ becomes a "glorified body" through resurrection. The author argues that Easter embraces the mystery of transformation and that this pattern of moving through suffering to renewal reflects universal human experiences we all encounter repeatedly in life.

Facebook has opened up its Messenger service to third-party developers, allowing apps like Camoji to create and share animated GIFs directly within conversations, where the GIFs animate inline. This represents Facebook's effort to transform its messaging service into an independent platform that can compete with fast-growing messaging apps like Snapchat and WeChat. The new Messenger Platform enables developers to create apps that function inside Messenger's 600 million user base, offering users more tools for expression and communication beyond traditional text messages.

Labour leader Ed Miliband admitted his party made mistakes on immigration and announced that everyone coming to Britain should learn English, saying communities must use a shared language to live together. He proposed a new Home Office task force to crack down on illegal exploitation of migrant workers, which he said drives low-skilled migration and holds down wages for British workers. However, Conservative immigration minister James Brokenshire criticized the plans, saying nothing Miliband is proposing would help control immigration after net migration hit 298,000 in a year.

Four terrified puppies strapped in a cage on the roof of a van were rescued in Akron, Ohio after concerned drivers called 911, prompting police to pull over Wendell Steiner and his family during their 300-mile journey from Ohio to Pennsylvania. The Mennonite family, traveling with their four children, said the puppies belonged to Steiner's father and they were transporting them because he could no longer keep them, with the cage's rear left exposed to wind during the trip. The incident drew comparisons to Mitt Romney's controversial 2012 presidential campaign story about driving with his dog Seamus strapped to his car roof, though police let the family go with a warning and the puppies were taken for veterinary care before being put up for adoption.

Louis Smith will represent Great Britain for the first time since his double Olympic medal-winning performance at the 2012 London Games, where he won pommel horse silver and team bronze, after being selected for the European Championships squad. The British gymnast, who competed for England at last year's Commonwealth Games, joins a team that includes reigning pommel horse champion Max Whitlock and other Olympic teammates. Four-time Commonwealth Games champion Claudia Fragapane leads the women's team for the championships taking place in Montpellier from April 15-19.

New York taxi driver Mohammed Dahbi was ordered to pay $10,000 in damages after discriminating against actress Kassie Thornton and TV executive partner Christy Spitzer by telling them to stop kissing in his cab and "keep that behavior for the bedroom." When the lesbian couple refused to pay the fare and got out, Dahbi verbally abused them with slurs, leading to accusations of discrimination based on the pair's sexuality. A judge ruled against Dahbi, ordering him to pay the fine, attend anti-discrimination training, and pay an additional $5,000 civil penalty to the city.

Jonas Gutierrez, a Newcastle midfielder who has twice beaten testicular cancer, was dropped from the squad following a heated disagreement with head coach John Carver and is set to be released at the end of the season despite seven years at the club. The 31-year-old Argentinian was axed after expressing frustration over his treatment, tweeting "I am tired about some things" and criticizing how Newcastle handled his illness, saying the club prioritized business interests over supporting him during his cancer battle. Gutierrez, who received a heartfelt ovation when he appeared as a substitute at Anfield, will not have his contract extended as the clause requiring eight starts this season cannot now be activated.

ISIS militants infiltrated the Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Damascus, marking their deepest penetration into the Syrian capital and seat of President Bashar Assad's power, while Jordan simultaneously closed its only functioning Nasib border crossing due to heavy clashes between rebels and government forces. The militants entered the camp from the nearby Hajar Aswad neighborhood in a coordinated attack with Al Qaeda-affiliated Nusra Front, managing to take control of large parts of the Palestinian-run refugee camp following clashes with Palestinian factions. Separately, gruesome images emerged showing ISIS militants in Mosul stoning a blindfolded couple to death after accusing them of fornication, demonstrating the terrorist group's continued brutal executions across their territory.

South Carolina mother-of-four Amanda Peake Glover died Saturday after collapsing moments after completing the Palmetto Half Marathon, leaving behind her husband Benjamin and four children. The 35-year-old fitness enthusiast and co-owner of a fitness center had just finished the race when she suddenly collapsed and was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital, though the exact cause of her death remained unclear. Glover, who was also a devoted youth ministry teacher, had completed a full marathon with her brother just one month prior to her sudden death.

Ed Balls, Labour's shadow chancellor, was left briefly stumped by a basic maths question asking what seven times six equals during a Q&A session after giving a speech in Leeds today. After a ten-second pause and nervous laughter, Mr Balls eventually answered correctly with "42" but said it was dangerous for politicians to answer such questions. This incident follows his recent confession that he relies on his mother-in-law, a maths teacher, for help with mathematics and was relieved not to be asked maths questions during live TV interviews.

Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott became the sixth English pair to score more than 100 runs together on 10 occasions, with Cook being part of three such partnerships including previous successful pairings with Strauss and Pietersen. Their opening-stand century was England's first in Test cricket for more than two years, while West Indies bowler Shannon Gabriel kept England's batsmen under pressure with deliveries reaching 94.3mph during the match.

Manhattan-based Skin Laundry offers a popular 10-minute laser facial treatment that promises to improve skin complexion and reduce wrinkles, but clients must sign an extensive 8-page waiver that includes releasing personal information to funeral directors and coroners due to potential risks like burns, scarring, and skin whitening. Despite the ominous legal documents and $100 per treatment cost, the clinic has attracted many regular customers who claim the treatment works, allowing the company to expand to six locations across California, Arizona, and New York.

Tickets for Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's weigh-in on May 1 sold out within minutes on Friday evening when 10,000 tickets went on sale at MGM property box offices in Las Vegas, with fight fans queuing around the block and overwhelming the phone lines. Friday's sale came after tickets for the main fight itself had sold out within a minute on Thursday night, with prices ranging from $1,500 to $7,500, and super-ringside tickets costing $10,000 were not released for public sale but are reportedly exchanging hands on the black market for upwards of $200,000.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio is recovering at UCLA Hospital in Los Angeles after undergoing a medical procedure on Tuesday for constant headaches she had been suffering from. The 34-year-old Brazilian supermodel had appeared in good health while partying at the Coachella festival in California on Sunday, but had scheduled the medical appointment two weeks prior. According to her spokesperson, Ambrosio is currently in good health following the procedure at the Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center.

The Oxford University Women's Boat Race team was rescued from the Thames by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) on Wednesday after their boat was swamped by choppy waters during training for the upcoming Boat Race. The crew members from Chiswick RNLI station safely returned the rowers to Putney and recovered their sunken eight, with the incident occurring just days before both the women's and men's races take place on Saturday, April 11. The RNLI noted that strong winds against the tide created successive waves that overwhelmed the boat's bilge pump, but praised the Oxford crew for handling the situation calmly and safely.

Paris Saint-Germain playmaker Lucas Moura has praised Lionel Messi ahead of PSG's Champions League clash against Barcelona, calling the Argentine star his "idol" and describing himself as "obsessed" with Messi's playing style. Despite the traditional rivalry between Brazil and Argentina, the Brazilian midfielder lauded Messi as "the best player in the world" before Wednesday night's match at Parc des Princes. PSG will face Barcelona in the first leg of their Champions League encounter, with the return match scheduled for April 21 at the Nou Camp.

Zayn Malik has been accused of cheating on his fiancé Perrie Edwards multiple times, with the most recent allegation coming from Swedish model Martina Olsson who claimed she slept with him while he was in Thailand. This isn't the first time Zayn has faced such accusations - he's been linked to cheating scandals since 2012, including claims from Australian waitress Courtney Webb and photos with Lauren Richardson. Relationship expert Tracey Cox suggests the public is more lenient on Zayn compared to Ashley Cole's similar situation with Cheryl because of his young age, but warns that Perrie may be enabling his behavior by repeatedly taking him back after each alleged infidelity.

The article discusses how recent "religious freedom" bills in Arkansas and Indiana sparked unexpected public outrage, catching governors off-guard as businesses and organizations threatened boycotts over potential discrimination against same-sex couples. Companies like Marriott International, despite having religious founders, are prioritizing business interests and launching pro-LGBT campaigns like "#Love Travels" because millennials (72% support same-sex marriage) and younger consumers increasingly reject anti-gay bias and discrimination. The piece argues that America has crossed a threshold where supporting diversity and social equality has become essential for business success and political viability, as the majority now opposes discriminatory practices.

TOWIE star Jake Hall scored a crucial goal for non-league Boston United in their 2-0 Conference North victory over Tamworth on Monday, impressing his on-screen girlfriend Chloe Lewis who was watching from the stands. Hall scored with his first touch after coming off the bench, while his co-star James 'Arg' Argent was also in attendance and excitedly tried to climb over the barriers to celebrate the goal. The match came amid recent reports linking Hall to Hollywood actress Lindsay Lohan, though both parties have denied any romantic relationship.

Lt. Colonel John Schwemmer is on his sixth tour in Iraq training Iraqi soldiers as part of U.S. military efforts to combat ISIS, while dozens of foreign volunteers, including Americans, have joined Kurdish forces and militias in Iraq and Syria to fight against ISIS. Military training efforts are being supplemented by outside agencies working with Kurdish government troops, though some organizations like the Peshmerga say they don't need foreign fighters on the front lines and prefer development assistance instead. The U.S. military maintains confidence in its training and support mission, working through Middle Eastern partners to degrade and defeat ISIS forces in the region.

Seventy years ago, British Sergeant Norman Turgel, 24, fell in love with 20-year-old Polish prisoner Gena at the liberated Bergen-Belsen Nazi concentration camp, where Anne Frank had died just months before among the 60,000 starving inmates and hundreds dying daily from typhus. With the help of British commander Major Leonard Berney, who ensured their romance survived the chaos of post-liberation activities, Norman and Gena married and had a 50-year marriage with three children before Norman's death in 1995. Their love story emerged from one of the Holocaust's most horrific sites, where British soldiers had arrested SS guards and discovered thousands of unburied corpses when they liberated the camp in April 1945.

A CNN reporter traveled to Gorkha, Nepal, near the epicenter of the devastating earthquake, where the district hospital is overwhelmed with patients suffering from injuries including deep cuts, broken bones, and spinal injuries. The hospital has set up makeshift shelters to accommodate casualties from remote mountain villages, including 10-year-old Mita Gurung who sustained facial and leg injuries when her house collapsed and remains traumatized. International medical teams, including Swiss and German aid workers, have arrived to provide emergency care and surgical support, while helicopters transport the most seriously injured to better-equipped hospitals in Kathmandu, though many patients must endure difficult journeys on old buses over winding mountain roads.

Two Australian drug smugglers, Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, are facing execution by firing squad after spending a decade on death row for their roles in a failed heroin smuggling plot as part of the "Bali Nine." The group of nine Australians were arrested in Indonesia, with some members like Renae Lawrence claiming Chan threatened their lives to force participation, though Chan denied making any threats during court proceedings. While Lawrence and others received life sentences later reduced to 20 years in prison, Chan and Sukumaran remain on death row despite Australian government appeals for clemency.

Scientists from Oxford University propose that Earth was struck by a Mars-sized body with Mercury-like composition about 4.5 billion years ago, which could explain how our planet developed its hot core and magnetic field. This collision theory also accounts for the presence of certain rare-earth elements (samarium and neodymium) in Earth's mantle that don't match typical meteorite compositions, and the same impact may have been responsible for forming the moon. The research suggests this dramatic collision provided the heat source needed to drive Earth's molten iron core dynamo, offering a new explanation for how Earth transitioned from accumulating asteroids and planetesimals to becoming the complex planet we know today.

Red Bull Formula One driver Daniel Ricciardo practiced martial arts with an instructor at Guyi Garden ahead of the Chinese Grand Prix, as part of a PR event to potentially kick-start his disappointing 2015 F1 season. Red Bull has struggled since their dominant four-year run ended in 2013, falling further behind Mercedes and rivals like Ferrari this season, with Ricciardo managing only a sixth place in Australia and tenth in Malaysia in the opening races. The martial arts training appears to be both a publicity stunt and a way for the 25-year-old Australian to find discipline and focus during what could be a frustrating season for the team.

An unidentified drone carrying small traces of radioactive material landed on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's official residence in Tokyo, prompting police and bomb squad investigations. The drone, spotted by Prime Minister's staff, was found to contain traces of a radioactive substance that Tokyo Metropolitan Police said was likely harmless caesium. The incident is suspected to be a protest against Japan's nuclear energy policies, occurring while Prime Minister Abe was attending a conference in Indonesia.

According to an internal ISIS report and expert analysis, ISIS presents itself as a global religious organization but has thrived primarily due to local Sunni grievances in Iraq and Syria, with its military backbone consisting largely of former Baathist officers from Saddam Hussein's army who use religious ideology as a tool for power and control. While ISIS poses a threat to the West through its sophisticated messaging and recruitment machine that attracts alienated young Muslims worldwide, the group's main focus appears to be building a caliphate in the Middle East rather than directly attacking America, and it may ultimately face its greatest challenges from within its own territory as populations grow disenchanted with its brutal rule. The threat ISIS poses continues to grow monthly as long as it can recruit followers globally, though no population has ever voted ISIS into power - the group maintains control solely through violence and repression.

Following a leaders' debate, internet users created numerous memes featuring the political participants, including images of Prime Minister David Cameron and deputy Nick Clegg superimposed on Gogglebox characters since they didn't attend the debate, and Labour leader Ed Miliband superimposed over London rapper Plan B with the caption "come at me bruv" referencing his direct challenge to Cameron for a one-on-one debate. Other popular memes showed Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon posing with a skeptical expression and the five debate participants reimagined as Power Rangers, with Nigel Farage notably isolated after being shunned by other politicians during the event.

A handful of Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford during Sunday's 4-2 derby defeat for allegedly mocking the Munich Air Disaster by making airplane wing gestures, referencing the 1958 tragedy where Manchester United's plane crashed in Munich killing 23 people, including former Manchester City goalkeeper Frank Swift. Despite these incidents, police praised the overwhelming majority of fans for their good behavior, with only eight arrests made at the match. The Munich Air Disaster occurred when United's plane crashed during takeoff after a European Cup clash against Red Star Belgrade.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted that the club's academy players are not ready for first-team football, suggesting City may need to purchase homegrown talent from rival clubs to meet Premier League quota requirements of at least eight homegrown players. With James Milner potentially leaving for Liverpool and Frank Lampard departing, City has been linked with moves for players like Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, Arsenal's Jack Wilshere, and Everton's Ross Barkley to fill their homegrown quota. Pellegrini emphasized the importance of bringing in the best players while acknowledging that City's youth system has struggled to produce first-team ready talent, with defender Dedryck Boyata being the only academy graduate near contention.

A 28-year-old pregnant Jehovah's Witness woman named Jenny-Lee died along with her unborn baby after refusing blood transfusions required for cancer treatment and a caesarean section, despite being diagnosed with leukaemia seven months into her pregnancy. Her family defended her decision, saying she put her baby's life above her own and believed the chemotherapy would harm her unborn child, though doctors stated that 83% of pregnant leukaemia patients go into remission with proper treatment. The case highlights the ethical and legal complexities surrounding a mother's right to refuse life-saving medical interventions that could affect both herself and her unborn baby.

Mohammad Liaqat launched a racist tirade and racially abused teachers at Mount Carmel Roman Catholic High School after Muslim pupils were banned from growing beards, even though the issue had already been resolved. Liaqat verbally assaulted and hurled racial abuse at white staff members in front of parents and children, and even physically assaulted headteacher Xavier Bowers during his rampage. After being arrested, he continued his abusive behavior at another school where he assaulted that headmaster as well, leading to his conviction on multiple counts of assault and racially aggravated behavior.

Chinese authorities arrested more than 133,000 people and seized 43.3 tons of illegal narcotics during a six-month nationwide anti-drug campaign, while also handling 115,000 drug-related crimes like robbery and 606,000 cases of drug use. According to the Ministry of Public Security, drug trafficking groups have "suffered a heavy blow," but online drug trafficking remains an increasing problem, prompting a three-month online campaign starting in April to target drug-related Internet crimes. The crackdown has extended to the entertainment industry, with Beijing authorities banning drug use and several celebrities being arrested, including Jackie Chan's son Jaycee Chan who was sentenced to six months in prison.

A new species of glass frog named Hyalinobatrachium dianae has been discovered in the mountains of eastern Costa Rica, featuring translucent skin on its underside that makes its heart, liver, and other organs visible. The creature has a distinctive metallic whistle-like call and stands out from other glass frogs with its black and white eyes and long toes. Unlike tree frogs, glass frogs have forward-facing eyes, and this newly discovered species measures just one inch long, making it difficult to spot in the rainforest canopy.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have returned to Kensington Palace as Kate's second child is due on Saturday, with Kensington Palace revealing that Prince William will take six weeks' paternity leave after completing his air ambulance pilot training early due to performing well in his modules. William had been spending time with Kate and their son Prince George at her family's home in Berkshire before moving back to London to be near the Lindo Wing hospital. Prince Harry will also return from his Australian Army deployment to present medals at the London Marathon and potentially meet his new niece or nephew.

Maurice Thibaux, a 67-year-old French resident living next to the Carriageworks venue in Sydney's inner city, stormed onto the catwalk during Sunday night's opening show of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week while Australian fashion designer Kym Ellery was taking her bow. Thibaux complained that the noise from the hardcore electronic music was so loud it penetrated his noise-cancelling headphones and felt like "a jumbo jet taking off over your head," causing his house to shake. Despite the disruption, Ellery appeared unfazed by the incident and continued her runway walk as security escorted the angry neighbor away.

FBI Director James Comey has introduced compulsory fitness tests for all 135,000 FBI agents due to concerns about expanding waistlines and declining personal fitness levels. The annual tests require agents to meet specific running, sprinting, push-up, and sit-up standards, with failures noted on performance reviews and potentially affecting job assignments. This initiative comes as the FBI's work has shifted from physical crime-fighting to desk-based cyber crime and intelligence gathering since 9/11, contributing to agents' decreased fitness levels amid America's broader obesity crisis.

Volcano Calbuco in southern Chile suddenly erupted without warning after lying dormant for over 40 years, forcing approximately 1,500 people to flee from nearby towns as thick plumes of ash clouded the sky. The volcano, considered one of Chile's three most dangerous among its 90 active volcanoes, last had a major eruption in 1961 with a minor one in 1972, and the unexpected eruption occurred around 6pm local time, creating apocalyptic scenes visible up to 100 miles away. This eruption follows another recent volcanic activity in the region, as Volcano Villarrica also erupted in March, highlighting Chile's position on the Pacific "Rim of Fire" with the world's second largest chain of potentially active volcanoes.

David Cameron defended his government's austerity and welfare policies in an Easter message after Church of England bishops criticized them as lacking moral content, insisting the Coalition had spent five years "trying to lift people up" by making work pay and encouraging responsibility. The Prime Minister responded to a Church document that complained welfare claimants were being described as "undeserving" and that austerity burdens weren't being borne by "those with the broadest shoulders," while chief whip Michael Gove claimed Christians in Britain face condescension and dismissal.

Protests are intensifying in Baltimore after Freddie Gray died from a severe spinal cord injury while in police custody, with demonstrators demanding justice and answers about what happened during the 30 minutes he was transported in a police van. An autopsy revealed Gray died from devastating spinal injuries, and while five of the six officers involved have given statements to investigators, protesters are calling for murder charges against the officers. The case has sparked broader concerns about police brutality in Baltimore, where the city has paid over $5.7 million since 2011 in settlements related to police misconduct allegations.

Brandon Afoa, a 33-year-old airport worker, was awarded $40 million in compensation for a freak runway accident at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport that occurred over seven years ago on December 26, 2007. The incident happened when Afoa was operating a tug to push aircraft and the brakes and steering failed, causing him to crash into a luggage lift and leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. After years of legal battles, a King County jury ruled in favor of Afoa, with the Port of Seattle being assigned 25% of the blame for failing to maintain a safe workplace.

Manchester United boss Louis van Gaal revealed he has an upcoming lunch appointment with Sir Alex Ferguson, hoping to discuss genuine progress as his team sits poised to potentially leapfrog Manchester City into second place in the Premier League table with a victory over Aston Villa on Saturday. After successive wins against top four rivals Liverpool and Tottenham, Van Gaal's United find themselves in a strong position to benefit from the increasingly competitive battle for Champions League qualification, with places two through four looking interchangeable as the season approaches its conclusion.

A passenger flying from Newcastle to Gatwick on an EasyJet flight was stopped by airport security after staff thought his six £1.80 tubs of pease pudding (a traditional North East delicacy) resembled Semtex plastic explosive, despite the containers being clearly marked as pease pudding. Security told the traveler that the pudding's consistency could "technically" be classed as Semtex, but he was ultimately allowed to board after being advised to pack such items in hold luggage next time. The incident highlights how airport security scanners sometimes flag unusual items, similar to previous cases where Stansted Airport confiscated furry handcuffs and Birmingham Airport seized a giant 4ft squash from another passenger.

The West Indies have named a 14-man squad for the first Test against England in their three-match series, including uncapped duo Shai Hope and Carlos Brathwaite. The 21-year-old wicketkeeper-batsman Hope and paceman Brathwaite have been retained by new coach Phil Simmons, while six players from the training camp have been dropped. Denesh Ramdin will captain the side, with Jason Holder also included in the Test squad for the series starting in Antigua.

Police say Rejean Hermel Perron has been accused of holding a kidnapped woman prisoner for five days and subjecting her to multiple sexual assaults at his Toronto home. The 27-year-old victim was freed by dog walker Peter Hamilton, who used nail clippers to cut her restraints after finding her bound, bruised, and crying for help on a veranda. Perron was arrested and charged with sexual assault with a weapon, kidnapping, forcible confinement and assault, with police believing there may be additional victims who have not yet come forward.

Jane Horrocks and her teenagers embarked on a classic American road trip along California's Pacific Coast Highway (Route 1), driving from San Francisco to Los Angeles over three weeks. The journey began in San Francisco, described as America's most European city, where they explored iconic sites like the Golden Gate Bridge and navigated the city's famous hills via cable cars. Their adventure concluded at Huntington Beach Hyatt Regency, experiencing three-and-a-half miles of uncrowded white sand known as Surf City, after traveling through diverse California landscapes including Big Sur, Santa Barbara, and various coastal towns along the scenic 500-mile route.

Lib Dem minister Danny Alexander released details of what he claimed were secret Conservative plans to cut Child Benefit and Child Tax Credits, accusing David Cameron of plotting to "slash support for families." The Prime Minister flatly rejected these claims, stating the plans were drawn up by civil servants on Alexander's orders, while Tory Chancellor George Osborne has promised £12 billion in welfare cuts but refuses to specify where they will fall. The row has created the worst dispute between the former coalition partners, with Lib Dem leader Nick Clegg backing Alexander's decision to reveal the confidential discussions and expressing frustration that Conservatives won't come clean about their benefit cut plans before the election.

Sergio Garcia insists he is focused on winning his first PGA Tour title since 2012 at this week's Shell Houston Open, rather than looking ahead to the Masters at Augusta despite the course being set up to replicate Augusta conditions. The Spanish golfer acknowledged he may never win a major championship during his golfing career but said it wouldn't make him sad, as he believes there are more important things in life than winning majors. Garcia is one of only two top-10 players remaining in the Houston field alongside Jordan Spieth, with the tournament winner earning Masters qualification if not already exempt.

The Nepali Pranksters, creators of an Internet comedy series that films people's reactions to pranks challenging cultural norms, were shooting an episode about Nepal's plastic bag ban near the Central Zoo when a magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck. The team kept their cameras rolling for 18 minutes, capturing the chaos and destruction as they moved through crowded streets, witnessed building collapses, and documented the aftermath at historic sites including the UNESCO World Heritage site Basantapur Durbar Square. What began as a routine video shoot for their hidden camera series turned into real-time documentation of one of Nepal's most devastating natural disasters.

Fashion designer Max Azria, founder of the popular BCBG Max Azria brand and chairman of the global fashion house BCBG Max Azria group, has put his lavish 30,000 square foot Los Angeles mansion on the market for $85 million. The sprawling home in Holmby Hills, which Azria purchased for $14.4 million in 2005 and renovated with an additional $30 million investment, features 17 bedrooms, 22 bathrooms, a crystal chandelier made of 150,000 crystals, and extensive amenities including a private tennis court, movie theater, and multiple themed gardens. Originally built in 1939 by architect Paul Williams for Old Hollywood stars, the mansion's backyard features a zero-edge pool, Moroccan-style bathhouse, and greenhouses, while Azria's personal office boasts a domed gold-leaf ceiling.

A 50-year-old woman named Mei Ru accidentally killed her 53-year-old husband Song Ming when she reversed over him outside a supermarket in Fuzhou, China, while they were going shopping. CCTV footage shows Song Ming getting out of the passenger side and standing behind their parked car when his wife suddenly reversed, knocking him down and running over his body. Song Ming was rushed to the hospital but died from massive internal bleeding and broken ribs, while his grief-stricken wife is being treated for shock.

NBC News has revised its account of the 2012 kidnapping of chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel in Syria, now saying he was most likely taken by Sunni rebels who deceived their victims into believing they were government forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad. The change came after the New York Times raised questions about the attackers' identities, suggesting the kidnapping was carried out by a criminal Sunni group linked to the Free Syrian Army rather than pro-Assad militants as originally reported. Engel and his crew were held for five days and may have been released through a staged "rescue" for propaganda purposes rather than being freed in an actual firefight as they were initially told.

Lidia Quilligana was arrested in Danbury, Connecticut last month after police viewed a nanny cam video that allegedly showed her choking and beating a 3-year-old girl in her care, as well as burning the child's legs, arms, and hands on a hot stove while the girl screamed in pain. The family had set up the camera after suspecting something was wrong with their daughter, who Quilligana had been caring for about a year. She has been charged with first degree assault of a child under 10 years old and criminal mischief, with bail set at $1 million.

During a White House Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day Q&A session, a little girl named Anya Brodie asked Michelle Obama her age, and when Obama replied that she was 51 years old, the girl exclaimed "You look too young!" A flattered Obama asked Brodie to repeat her effortless compliment into the microphone and then invited her on stage for a big warm hug. The event included children of White House employees, kids from the Boys and Girls Club, and children from D.C. Child and Family Services.

Philip Garrod, a 43-year-old paramedic, was caught by a speed camera doing 105mph on his powerful Suzuki motorbike and fined £650 with six points for speeding. To avoid a driving ban, he fabricated a story about rushing to respond to a fake 999 emergency call involving an injured cyclist, even creating false patient records to support his lies. When ambulance service bosses investigated and found no record of any such emergency call, Garrod was struck off the medical register for misconduct and dishonesty.

Vin Los, a 24-year-old Canadian man with extensive body art including 24 tattoos on his face alone, has landed a modeling campaign for underwear brand Garçon Model despite many believing that face tattoos would make it impossible to find work. His crude, Sharpie-like tattoos cover his head, neck, arms, and chest (including tattooed-on chest hair) with phrases like "fame," "iconic face," and pop culture references that he says embody early 2010s culture. Vin, who dreams of becoming the most famous man in the world, believes his unique ink creates "a myth, a mystery" and has proven his success by transitioning from working at a supermarket to building a modeling career around his heavily inked appearance.

Sir Stirling Moss, the 85-year-old racing legend who won 212 races during his 14-year career, recently reunited with his refurbished Austin-Healey Sprite training car and demonstrated that he has lost none of his racing pedigree despite being over 50 years removed from professional racing. His career ended after a devastating crash at Goodwood on Easter Monday in 1962, one month after using the Sprite for training, when he had to be cut out of his Lotus and remained unconscious for six weeks. Now living in London and driving a small electric car instead of high-performance petrol cars, Sir Stirling credits his longevity to an unusual daily routine of 77 press-ups and half a bottle of Chardonnay.

Taylor Lynn Fast, 21, was arrested after her 17-month-old daughter Layla was found beaten to death with severe injuries and bruising throughout her body at their home in Festus, Missouri. Fast allegedly told police that a spider bite was responsible for the fatal injuries, claiming she didn't realize her daughter was dead, though paramedics determined Layla had been deceased for several hours. Police described the case as the worst child abuse they had ever seen, and Fast has been charged with endangering the welfare of a child.

Officer Jared Forsyth, 33, a member of the Ocala Police Department since 2012, was accidentally shot by a coworker during firearms training at the Lowell Correctional Institution gun range. Despite being rushed to the hospital in critical condition and undergoing surgery, Forsyth died from his injuries several hours later. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the accidental shooting incident.

Police have released an image of a suspect in connection with suspected arson attacks on three Melbourne Catholic churches linked to paedophile priests, including St Mary's Catholic Church in Dandenong where now-deceased Father Kevin O'Donnell allegedly molested children from 1958-1986, and St James Catholic Church in Brighton where paedophile priest Ronald Pickering sexually abused boys between 1960-1980. The fires occurred between March 30 and April 1, with St James Church being mostly destroyed and at least five victims of Pickering's abuse having committed suicide according to 2012 research. Australian actress Rachel Griffiths, a former parishioner of St James, expressed feeling "quite elated" about the church's destruction due to the traumatic history of abuse that occurred there.

Shaquille Omar Hallisey, a 20-year-old thug, was jailed for four years at Cardiff Crown Court after pleading guilty to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm for hitting stranger Matthew Leeke, 38, over the head with a bottle in Cardiff. The savage attack left Mr Leeke with a fractured skull, cuts requiring hospital treatment, and ongoing anxiety and headaches. Cardiff Crown Court heard that paramedics treated the victim's injuries before he was taken to hospital, where scans revealed the skull fracture from the unprovoked assault that occurred as Leeke was walking home alone.

A new study reveals that the average pet spends 21 hours a week watching TV, with owners admitting they spend hours watching with their animals and often leave the TV on for company when they're away. Over a third of pet owners say their animals watch three hours per day while home alone, with some extreme cases like a micro pig owner allowing 28 hours of TV viewing per week. Pets show clear preferences for animal-related programming, with "For the Love of Dogs" being their top favorite and "Springwatch" ranking as their third favorite show, while they tend to avoid reality shows like "Keeping Up With The Kardashians."

Three years ago, four sisters - Claire, Emily, Christine and Lily Vincenti - were dramatically removed from their mother's Australian home and returned to Italy to live with their father Tomasso Vincenti, after their mother Laura Garrett had taken them from their Italian home claiming abuse. The two eldest girls, Claire and Emily, now tell 60 Minutes that while they miss Australia and their mother, they have settled into happy lives in Italy with their father, attending school and speaking to their mother nightly. The sisters acknowledge they may have exaggerated their distress during the traumatic 2012 removal, saying their parents were "selfish" for putting them in the center of the custody battle.

Former teacher Mary Kay Letourneau and her student-turned-husband Vili Fualaau spoke to Barbara Walters on "20/20" about their controversial relationship that began when he was just 12 years old, leading to Letourneau's arrest and imprisonment for seven-and-a-half years during which she gave birth to their second daughter. After Letourneau was released from prison in 2004, the couple married in 2005 and have now been together for 10 years, raising their two teenage daughters who were born from their illegal affair.

Carl Froch's promoter discusses the boxer's future plans after Julio Cesar Chavez Jr's unexpected loss ruined their hoped-for Las Vegas fight, with James DeGale now emerging as the most likely opponent if he wins his upcoming title fight on May 23. Meanwhile, efforts to stage a Carl Frampton-Scott Quigg fight have collapsed after Frampton's team failed to respond to multiple offers, including a £1.5 million guarantee, leading to Quigg being scheduled to fight on July 18 instead. Anthony Joshua continues his busy schedule with upcoming fights against Rafael Zumbano Love on May 9 and Kevin Johnson on May 30.

Nine-year-old Annabel Beam fell 30 feet headfirst down a hollow tree in 2011 but miraculously survived without serious injury after emergency crews used a harness to rescue her. While unconscious, Annabel claims she visited heaven and sat in Jesus's lap, and remarkably, she awoke completely cured of a rare digestive disorder that had required extensive medication and hospitalizations since 2008. Her mother Christy Wilson Beam believes her daughter's religious experience during the accident was responsible for the miraculous healing, as Annabel can now eat solid food and no longer requires her previous medications.

Bradford Bulls have launched an investigation after three cars were broken into and vandalized in the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park during Sunday's Ladbrokes Challenge Cup fifth-round defeat by Hull KR at Odsal Stadium. The Championship club is working with Bradford Council, the sports centre, and West Yorkshire Police to identify those responsible, with stadium manager Mark Leadbeater noting that similar incidents have occurred recently in local car parks throughout the area. The Bulls are appealing for witnesses and pledging to ensure their car parks remain safe and secure for supporters on game days.

A mid-air brawl erupted on Oman Air flight 102 from London Heathrow to Muscat when one passenger allegedly attacked another with a shoe during a dispute over legroom after the first passenger moved seats on the not-full flight. The Oman Air cabin crew intervened to contain the situation, and upon landing at Muscat International Airport, one man was taken away for questioning by police. This incident is part of a broader trend of "legroom wars" on flights, with similar disputes recently causing diversions on Delta and United Airlines flights.

An Iranian military observation aircraft flew dangerously close to an armed U.S. Navy helicopter over the Persian Gulf this month, coming within 50 yards during two passes before the helicopter moved away. The incident troubled U.S. military officials because such unsafe maneuvers could escalate into serious military encounters, and it occurred while the U.S. and world powers are negotiating a deal to limit Tehran's nuclear program. U.S. commanders believe the aggressive action may have been ordered by a local Iranian commander rather than higher-ups, as Iranian forces have generally conducted operations professionally in recent months.

A survey of 2,000 British pet owners created a composite image of the "perfect dog" combining features from multiple breeds, including an English bulldog's coat, a King Charles spaniel's ears, a border collie's body size, and a labrador's snout. The research revealed regional preferences, with 41% of Londoners favoring small, lap-sized dogs due to space constraints, while those in East Anglia preferred larger breeds like Great Danes. Additionally, 33% of owners preferred traditional dog names like Rover and Bailey, and a quarter wished their perfect dog could live as long as they do rather than the typical 10-13 year lifespan.

Two British soldiers, Welsh Guard Jason Collins (22) and Scots Guard Shaun Smith (25), avoided jail time despite being caught on CCTV brutally attacking two civilians near their barracks, with Smith stamping 18 times on a victim's head while Collins repeatedly punched the other man. Although both soldiers were found guilty of actual bodily harm and could have faced up to 10 years in prison, the judge made what he called an "extraordinary" decision to show mercy, giving Smith a 12-month suspended sentence and Collins a 12-month community order after hearing glowing character references from their commanding officers. The victims criticized the lenient sentences, with one stating there was no justification for the unprovoked attack that left him with a shoe imprint on his forehead.

West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has defended Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson ahead of their Premier League clash on Saturday, despite Pearson being involved in several controversial incidents this season including an altercation with Crystal Palace midfielder James McArthur. Allardyce, who previously worked with Pearson at Newcastle, praised his former colleague as "his own man" and said he has done an "unbelievable job," while dismissing speculation about Pearson potentially being sacked despite Leicester sitting bottom of the Premier League table. The two teams will meet at the King Power Stadium, where Leicester will be looking to end a goal drought of over five hours.

Eighteen-month-old twins drowned in Arizona after their mother, Alexis Keslar, let go of their stroller while trying to fend off a bee on Friday, causing the stroller to roll into a canal with the boys belted inside. Keslar went into the water to rescue her sons but was unable to reach them due to the steep sides, deep water, and strong current that washed the stroller away. Despite emergency efforts that included slowing the canal flow and reducing water levels, the twins were found after more than an hour of searching and pronounced dead at a hospital.

Terry McCarty, who suffered third-degree burns to 70 percent of his body at age six when his brothers accidentally knocked over a bowl of burning kerosene, endured 58 operations and was hospitalized for 12 months before facing years of bullying due to his scarring. Despite living in constant fear and struggling to find work as an adult, McCarty overcame his trauma by becoming a firefighter in 2012, confronting his fears head-on during training exercises involving live fire. He later left firefighting to work with burned children and now plans to open his own foundation to support other burn survivors, refusing to "let fear take over" his life.

A fund-raising campaign by forces charity Help for Heroes has raised £10,000 in just four days to help Second World War veteran Robert Clark, one of the country's oldest war veterans, remain in his own home with a live-in carer after Brent Council refused to increase funding for his care. The council told Mr Clark he would have to move to a local care home despite him already spending £50,000 of his life savings on care costs, prompting the charity to set a new fund-raising target of £15,000 to allow Mr Clark to stay in the home he has lived in for over 50 years.

A Conservative Party office in Aberdeen, Scotland was vandalized with graffiti including a swastika and the word "scum" sprayed in white paint, with a "Q" (possibly standing for "quisling") added to the door. Scottish Conservative Councillor Ross Thomson posted images on Twitter, blaming "nationalists" for the vandalism and stating it showed people who "can't accept the referendum result." Labour offices nearby were also targeted with similar graffiti, and the incident follows previous defacing of buildings and polling stations during the Scottish Referendum campaign six months earlier.

Lucas Matthysse (37-3) won a majority decision against Ruslan Provodnikov (24-3) in a 12-round super lightweight bout on Saturday night, using his three-inch reach advantage to control the fight despite Provodnikov landing hard right hook-left hook combos and staggering Matthysse in the 11th round. Matthysse opened a cut near Provodnikov's left eye early in the second round and effectively countered the Russian's powerful left hook throughout the fight. After the victory, Matthysse said he wanted to rest with his family before potentially pursuing fights with Floyd Mayweather or Manny Pacquiao.

Ferrari team principal Maurizio Arrivabene revealed he uses a "carrot-and-stick" approach with Kimi Raikkonen amid speculation that Lewis Hamilton could replace the Finnish driver next season. Raikkonen responded with his best performance of the campaign at Sunday's Bahrain Grand Prix, finishing second behind race winner Hamilton and splitting the Mercedes duo of Hamilton and Nico Rosberg. Arrivabene praised Raikkonen's podium finish—his first in 26 races—but maintained he won't finalize the driver's contract renewal yet, preferring to keep Raikkonen motivated through uncertainty.

A study by Expert Market analyzing data from 108 world countries found that Jamaica has the world's highest percentage of female managers at nearly 60%, making it the country where you're most likely to have a female boss, followed by Colombia and Saint Lucia. The United States ranked within the top 20 countries at 15th place with 42.7% of managers being female, while Pakistan ranked worst with only 3% female managers. Despite some progress, the study reveals significant global disparities in female leadership representation across different regions.

Australian teenager Violeta Tupuola participated in the viral #kyliejennerchallenge by using a shot glass to create a vacuum that dramatically swelled her lips to duck-like proportions, causing her to freak out and wonder if she could use the same method on other body parts. The dangerous trend, inspired by Kylie Jenner's plump lips, involves teens placing their mouths over narrow vessels and sucking to create swelling that can last hours or days, often resulting in painful bruising and purple discoloration. Despite widespread participation on social media, most teens report negative results and express regret, while critics warn about the health risks of bursting blood vessels.

Defiant Rangers manager Stuart McCall urged his team to show an immediate response after suffering his first defeat since taking charge, as the Ibrox side crashed to a 3-0 loss at Queen of the South on Thursday night - their second Championship defeat of the season. The defeat at Palmerston gave Queen of the South a massive boost to their play-off hopes, but McCall insisted his players must bounce back in Sunday's home match against Raith Rovers. Despite the setback, Rangers remain third in the Championship table behind Hibernian on goal difference but with a game in hand.
