A police horse named Charly was vandalized with silver spray paint while patrolling Venice Beach on Tuesday, when a tagger managed to spray "RBS" and an arrow on the horse's flank without the handlers noticing. The cruel vandalism incident was posted on Instagram by a witness, and while the paint was easily removed, LAPD authorities are using the "RBS" tag to try to identify and track down the person responsible. Police have requested public help in finding the vandal, as locals expressed outrage over the disrespectful act against the animal.

Tony Fernandes, Queens Park Rangers chairman, expressed his despair after watching his team twice throw away leads in a 3-3 draw against Aston Villa at Villa Park, viewing the match on his iPhone from Malaysia at 2:45 AM. Despite the disappointment of surrendering their advantage twice, with Christian Benteke's hat-trick canceling out goals from Matt Phillips, Clint Hill, and Charlie Austin, Fernandes praised the fighting spirit of players like Clint Hill and manager Chris Ramsey. The draw moved QPR up to 18th place but they remain in the relegation zone ahead of their crucial home match against Chelsea.

Harry Kane topped this week's EA Sports Performance Index as the Premier League's best player after scoring his 30th goal of the season in Tottenham's 3-1 win over Newcastle United on Sunday. The 21-year-old striker, who has now netted 20 Premier League goals in his breakthrough season, earned a Game Index score of 55.1 and was followed by teammates Christian Eriksen in second place and Chelsea's Eden Hazard in third. The top 10 list featured several Tottenham players along with notable performances from Leicester's Esteban Cambiasso, who won seven tackles against Swansea, and Southampton's Morgan Schneiderlin.

A protective dad created a t-shirt featuring his muscly torso with the message "Stay Clear Boys, This is my dad!" to keep boys away from his young daughter. The image was first shared on Reddit under the headline "Dad security" and later posted to a Facebook page where it was liked by 370,000 Facebook users and shared over 45,000 times, though reactions were mixed with some applauding the move while others criticized it.

An unnamed New York woman was found dead Sunday morning around 8:20 AM after hanging herself from a third-floor fire escape on Utica Avenue in Crown Heights, with her body left dangling for more than an hour. Witnesses reported being traumatized by the scene, with one passerby initially thinking it was a fake Halloween prank. The woman's identity has not been released pending family notification, though neighbors described her as social but struggling with mental health issues.

Full back David Raven, a 30-year-old former Liverpool player who had been released by lower-league English clubs, scored the winner to help Inverness Caledonian Thistle knock Celtic out of the Scottish Cup semi-final at Hampden Park. Celtic's response was to write a complaint letter to the SFA about not being awarded a penalty, which the author criticizes as pathetic behavior from such a large club that spoiled Raven's career highlight. The article argues that this incident exemplifies the poor state of Scottish football, with low attendance, declining quality players, and the need for major structural reforms to revive the game.

Real Madrid has not beaten city rivals Atletico Madrid in their last seven encounters since winning the Champions League final in Lisbon less than a year ago, with Atletico winning four games and drawing three during this period. Notable victories for Atletico include a 4-0 win that marked Real Madrid's heaviest defeat in over four years, Copa del Rey success with Fernando Torres scoring crucial goals, and multiple league victories with players like Arda Turan and Raul Garcia scoring winning goals. The two teams recently drew 0-0 in the first leg of their Champions League quarter-final last week, setting up Wednesday night's second leg as another crucial encounter between the Madrid rivals.

Ile Louët, an impressive lighthouse island located in Morlaix Bay, Brittany, offers a unique secluded retreat where up to 10 guests can stay in a renovated 19th century lighthouse keeper's cottage for just €200 (£145) for two nights. The island, situated 1,148 feet from shore, requires boat transport and lacks modern amenities like hot running water, but provides spectacular ocean views and ultimate privacy for adventurous travelers. The property is fully booked for 2015, but enquiries for 2016 can be made through the local tourism office.

Boobesh Palani, a 26-year-old Indian student, died at Wellington Hospital after being rescued from Wellington Harbour by two teenage girls who heard his cries for help. Since his identity was initially unknown, police released images of Mr Palani lying in his hospital bed to help identify him, and through public appeals they were able to establish Mr Palani's identity so his friends and family could be with him during his final days. The rescue took place in shark-infested waters, with the brave teenagers risking their own lives to save the drowning man.

Scientists at the University of Bath and Yale University have developed a breakthrough molecular catalyst that can efficiently split water to generate clean hydrogen fuel, addressing the major problem that producing hydrogen currently requires huge amounts of energy. The newly designed catalyst significantly improves the energy efficiency of water electrolysis by making the oxygen-producing half of the reaction much more efficient, with "almost non-existent" energy loss. This breakthrough could enable hydrogen to be produced more economically from renewable energy sources like solar and wind power, making hydrogen-powered applications more viable and helping store intermittent renewable energy as storable hydrogen fuel.

Ed Miliband made his first appearance on the campaign trail in three days this morning in Bristol, after going to ground over the Easter weekend and spending Sunday and Monday with his family following a low-key Saturday campaign in his Doncaster constituency. While the Labour leader took time off, his political rivals including David Cameron, Nick Clegg, and Nigel Farage wasted no opportunity to drum up support with just a month to go before polling day. Cameron was particularly active, making campaign visits across all four UK nations and delivering a major economic speech on Bank Holiday Monday, while Miliband only posted an Easter message on Facebook.

Saudi airstrikes targeting a military base in Yemen's Ibb province on Tuesday accidentally hit a nearby school, killing at least three students and injuring several others, according to Yemeni officials. The ongoing Saudi-led bombing campaign against Iranian-backed Houthi rebels has destroyed much of Yemen's infrastructure and killed hundreds of civilians, including at least 74 children since fighting began on March 26. The U.S. is supporting Saudi Arabia by expediting weapons deliveries, sharing intelligence, and helping coordinate the military operation against the Houthis who have seized control of Yemen's capital Sanaa.

Julieane Jablonski, 38, was arrested and charged with providing marijuana to a minor and witness tampering after her 19-year-old son Austin Essig jumped out of a third-story window following consumption of a pot brownie, suffering non-life-threatening injuries. Police allege that Jablonski told her son to lie about where the marijuana came from after he was hospitalized, and Essig himself commented on the Fort Collins Police Department's Facebook page describing his "trip" from the brownie. This incident is part of a concerning pattern of pot users harming themselves in Colorado since recreational marijuana became legal, highlighting issues with high THC levels in edibles.

Divock Origi, the Belgium striker who was signed by Liverpool for £10 million after the 2014 World Cup and loaned back to Lille, said he is eagerly anticipating joining Liverpool after following the club's progress and seeing how young players like Raheem Sterling and winger Jordon Ibe have developed under manager Brendan Rodgers. Origi referenced the progress of these youngsters as evidence that he is joining the right club, believing that Liverpool's approach to developing young talent and the support of Liverpool's supporters will help elevate his game. Origi admits it has been a challenging season at Lille balancing league and Europa League demands, but believes the experience has made him mentally stronger and a better player for his upcoming move to Anfield.

ESPN sports reporter Britt McHenry was suspended for one week after a video surfaced showing her verbally attacking a parking lot attendant with classist and body-shaming comments, telling the woman to "lose some weight" and making derogatory remarks about her education and job. The incident is particularly hypocritical given that McHenry has publicly championed women's rights on her blog, encouraging women to "be comfortable in their own skin" and lecturing about sexist treatment of women. A petition has been launched calling for McHenry to be fired from ESPN, arguing that retaining her sends a message condoning cruel behavior toward lower-income Americans.

Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford has sold more than 1.4 million copies of her adult coloring book "Secret Garden," which features 96 pages of black-and-white drawings and has been translated into 22 different languages. The global trend of adults simply coloring in child's books has led to colouring-in groups forming worldwide, with adult coloring titles now outselling cook books in France. Basford attributes her success to people seeking analogue activities away from screens, and her second book "Enchanted Forest" is expected to be equally successful as adults embrace coloring as a therapeutic way to reduce stress and rediscover creativity.

The NHS spent millions on prescriptions for basic household items in 2014, including 404,500 prescriptions for suncream costing £13 million and 4.7 million prescriptions for indigestion pills costing £29 million, according to a damning analysis. Critics called the practice "ludicrous" as patients eligible for free prescriptions abuse the system by demanding scripts for items like toothpaste, Calpol, and Vaseline that are cheaply available over-the-counter, with GPs reporting patients come to surgery every week with "shopping lists" of toiletries and remedies. This wasteful spending occurs while the NHS faces an £8 billion budget shortfall and has been forced to ration routine treatments and stop funding life-extending cancer treatments.

Mark Vanhoenacker's book "Skyfaring" offers a timely perspective on aviation following the Germanwings tragedy where troubled co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed flight 9525, as the British Airways senior first officer shares his passion for flying and reveals the secrets of piloting, particularly his beloved Boeing 747s. The book provides reassurance that experienced pilots still find air travel magical and exhilarating, while offering fascinating insights into aviation jargon, crew dynamics, and the technical aspects of long-haul flights. Vanhoenacker's elegant writing covers everything from waypoint naming conventions (including references to Mr. Spock and Annie Lennox) to practical details like why pilots prefer 747s over Airbus planes, partly because the 747s have foot heaters.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew believes Manchester City can still catch Chelsea in the Premier League title race, despite being six points behind with Chelsea having a game in hand. Pardew pointed to City's previous dramatic title wins, including their last-second victory in 2012 when Sergio Aguero's injury-time goal secured their first Premier League title, and last season when they overtook Liverpool with one match remaining. The Palace manager emphasized that the Premier League title race is never over until the final whistle, as City's recent history proves.

Manchester United midfielder Michael Carrick, 34, has revealed his desire to pursue a career in Formula One motorsport when his playing days end, stating he's a massive F1 fan who has done track days and would love to drive an F1 car. The former West Ham and Tottenham star is enjoying a renaissance under Louis van Gaal this season as United secured a Champions League place, and he credits learning from legends like Ryan Giggs and Paul Scholes for helping him maintain his fitness and extend his career. Carrick also reflected on the challenge of moving to West Ham at age 15 from the northeast, calling it tough but the best decision he ever made as it helped shape his character.

Wood Green animal charity has partnered with cleaning app Handy to offer a unique cat fostering service where households can temporarily borrow cats to solve mouse infestations, as the cats' scent and presence naturally scare away rodents without needing to catch them. The charity has over 200 cats available for this service, providing litter trays and supplies while helping the cats find permanent homes. Separately, the article mentions that Amazon offers a goat rental service in the US for lawn maintenance, as goats can eat various types of vegetation including invasive plants.

At this year's Coachella festival in California, celebrities and festival-goers displayed increasingly outlandish fashion choices, with stars like Kylie Jenner wearing nude hot pants and festival-inappropriate lace-up heels, Paris Hilton sporting rose-petal cat ears, and Katy Perry donning a chunky tribal necklace. The weekend saw an abundance of exposed skin, neon accessories, gold lamé outfits, and bizarre costumes including one man in a full Peter Pan costume and another dressed as a mummy. Festival attendees embraced eccentric looks with excessively-adorned veils, heavy-duty hair accessories, and clashing prints, making this year's Coachella particularly notable for its extreme fashion statements.

The Queen's Sandringham estate has removed all 62 hunting trophies from public display, including stuffed rhino heads, tigers, and ivory tusks, replacing them with "trinkets and bric-a-brac" after questions were raised about the legality of some unworked items dating before 1947. The blood-red walls of the trophy room have been repainted white, and the Sandringham museum now makes pointed reference to how changing times have ended this "destructive era" of big game hunting, with cameras replacing guns to record sightings of magnificent animals. The removal was particularly significant for animal welfare crusader Prince William, who had previously denounced the illegal wildlife trade in ivory and endangered animal parts.

For the first time, prosecco sales in Britain have overtaken champagne sales, with £181.8 million in prosecco sales compared to £141.3 million for champagne in the previous year. While Britain has long seen prosecco as a second choice to champagne, the Italian sparkling wine's popularity has surged from just 2 million bottles consumed in 2009 to 28 million bottles by 2014. The key factors behind prosecco's success include its lower production costs due to tank fermentation (rather than bottle fermentation like champagne's classic method using Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Pinot Meunier grapes), its lighter and fruitier taste profile, and significantly lower prices compared to champagne.

Former Adelaide doctor Tareq Kamleh appeared in the latest ISIS propaganda video encouraging foreign medical professionals to join the terrorist organization, yet he remains registered to practice medicine in Australia until September 30 despite his public support for the death cult notorious for beheading non-Muslims. The Medical Board of Australia has refused to deregister him, though he faces up to 25 years in prison if he returns to Australia and is charged with supporting a terrorist organization. Former colleagues described Kamleh as sexually manipulative and immoral, claiming he had inappropriate relationships with patients and hospital staff before his apparent transformation to becoming a devout supporter of the Islamic State.

Two young siblings, 8-year-old Piper Kulk and 9-year-old William Kulk, were killed in a tragic car crash on NSW's Central Coast when their grandmother's car aqua-planed on a rain-soaked road and collided head-on with a ute while returning from the Royal Easter Show. Piper died on Sunday morning and William died later that evening, while their older brother Daniel, 12, and mother Chantelle remain hospitalized in stable condition. The crash also left passengers in the other vehicle with severe injuries, including broken bones and a fractured neck.

Former Italian police officer Dino Maglio has been found guilty of raping a 16-year-old Australian girl after luring her to his home through Couchsurfing.com, drugging her drink with a tranquilizer, and sexually assaulting her. Although Maglio claimed the sex was consensual, he was sentenced to six and a half years in prison, with investigators uncovering testimonies from 14 women who alleged similar drugging and sexual assault incidents at his home between 2013-2014. The case has raised serious safety concerns about the couch-surfing platform, which connects travelers with hosts offering free accommodation.

Ed Miliband says sexting is "not advised for politicians" while Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg describes sending sexy text messages as "risky if you are young, dodgy if you are older" in responses to a Cosmopolitan magazine quiz. Their cautious stance comes amid numerous political sexting scandals, including Tory MP Brooks Newmark who is standing down after two sexting scandals, top Tory official Iain Corby whose salacious messages on a gay dating service were revealed by The Mail on Sunday, and disgraced Co-op boss Paul Flowers who was exposed for sexually explicit text exchanges with a teenage rent boy.

Ian Walters, 51, is accused of murdering his wife Tracy Walters, 48, by deliberately crashing his car into a tree at 84mph on the M1 motorway last year after their marriage deteriorated due to sexual incompatibility and alleged abuse. The prosecution claims Walters purposely crashed to show his wife "who was in charge," while Walters denies murder and claims he may have fallen asleep at the wheel due to antidepressants. The couple had married in Cyprus in 2012, but Tracy had texted relatives about needing her husband arrested just an hour before the fatal crash.

Manchester Airport was forced to temporarily suspend flights for about 20 minutes today after a potential drone sighting raised fears that the unmanned aerial vehicle could collide with a passenger jet, causing disruption for hundreds of travelers. Departing flights were delayed and some incoming flights were diverted to other airports while a police helicopter searched the area around Manchester Airport, though no drone was ultimately found. The incident highlights the growing problem of radio-controlled drones flying too close to airports, which pose significant safety threats to commercial aviation.

China's cybercensors have developed a new cyberweapon called the "Great Cannon" that goes beyond their existing "Great Firewall" by launching powerful distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks against servers outside China's borders, including in the United States. According to a study by researchers from multiple universities, this weapon blasts targeted web servers by hijacking the browsers of unsuspecting internet users visiting Chinese sites like Baidu, turning them into unwitting participants in massive attacks that can generate billions of requests per hour. The Great Cannon has specifically targeted services like GreatFire.org and GitHub that help Chinese citizens circumvent censorship and access Western news sources, representing Beijing's escalated response to free-speech cyberactivists who have found ways around the Great Firewall.

Ciudad Real Airport in Spain, built in 2009 for over €1 billion to handle overflow from Madrid's Barajas airport and serve 5 million passengers annually, closed in 2012 after its parent company went bankrupt and is now being sold for just one pound. The ghost airport, which features a 4,000-meter runway that must be painted with yellow crosses to warn pilots they cannot land, saw its final commercial flight in 2011 and represents one of several failed airport projects across Spain. Despite the minimal sale price, new owners will need to pay off hundreds of millions in debt for the abandoned facility that was meant to symbolize modern Spain's prosperity.

NYPD Detective Patrick Cherry apologized on NBC 4 New York after being caught on video screaming at and abusing an Uber driver named Humayun, with the incident being viewed over three million times on YouTube. Cherry was stripped of his shield and gun and placed on administrative duty following the outburst, where he shouted at the driver, mocked his accent, and threatened arrest without cause after the driver honked at his unmarked car. NYPD Police Chief Bill Bratton condemned the behavior as unacceptable, stating that such discourtesy and anger makes all good cops' jobs harder.

Former Manchester United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar is convinced that manager Louis van Gaal will bring the glory days back to Manchester United, as the team heads to Chelsea on Saturday in top form after winning six successive matches. While van der Sar admits the Barclays Premier League trophy is probably beyond United's grasp this season with Chelsea heavily favored to win next month, he believes van Gaal's philosophy and potential summer signings will help the club challenge for the championship next year. United boss van Gaal has already begun planning for summer transfers, with players like Mats Hummels and Kevin Strootman on his radar to strengthen the squad.

Bournemouth drew 2-2 with Sheffield Wednesday in a dramatic match where they trailed to Kieran Lee's opener, equalized through Yann Kermorgant, then had Simon Francis sent off before Matt Ritchie put them ahead with a spectacular free-kick, only for Chris Maguire to convert a stoppage-time penalty for the visitors. Manager Eddie Howe was left frustrated, feeling Callum Wilson deserved a penalty when fouled by Lewis Buxton, and suggested referees might be reluctant to award Bournemouth more spot-kicks after they've already had 15 penalties this season. The draw was a missed opportunity for Bournemouth to maintain top spot in what has been described as an "absurd season" full of dramatic twists.

18-year-old Billy-Anne Huxham was reportedly abducted at knife-point by her ex-boyfriend, 32-year-old Carl Garry Chapman, from her Caboolture home, sustaining wounds to her leg and bruising to her face during the violent attack. Ms Huxham was found by police after she escaped her captor and contacted family members from a local restaurant. Chapman has been charged with multiple offences including assault, torture, and deprivation of liberty.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman has delivered a clear message to his players to start scoring goals after the Saints managed just seven goals in their last 10 league matches, resulting in only 14 points from a potential 30. Despite their recent struggles in front of goal, Southampton sits seventh in the Premier League with 53 points and are still fighting for European qualification. Koeman could recall winger Sadio Mane to the starting lineup for Saturday's home game against Hull City, potentially moving him to a central attacking role as striker Graziano Pelle continues to misfire.

Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado has been invaded by an estimated 3,000 to 4,000 goldfish that originated from someone dumping four or five pet goldfish into the water two to three years ago. The non-native goldfish have multiplied rapidly and now threaten the lake's ecosystem by competing with native species for resources and potentially spreading diseases. Colorado Parks and Wildlife officials are planning to remove the invasive goldfish using electrofishing, a method that stuns the fish with electrical current, similar to a successful operation that removed over 2,000 koi from nearby Thunderbird Lake in 2012.

Tim Howard has rejected claims that Europa League participation is responsible for what could be Everton's worst Premier League season in nine years, with Roberto Martinez's side potentially finishing in the bottom half for the first time since 2006. Despite playing 10 European games this season, Howard argued that Champions League teams face similar demands and that Everton simply haven't had luck go their way, as evidenced in their 1-1 draw with Swansea where Aaron Lennon's goal was cancelled out by a Jonjo Shelvey penalty. The Merseyside club is currently 25 points worse off than at the same stage last season, highlighting their dramatic fall from targeting Champions League qualification to chasing a top-half finish.

The Atlanta Hawks crushed the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night to match a franchise record with their 57th win, with Al Horford and DeMarre Carroll each scoring 20 points. However, the Hawks lost forward Paul Millsap to a right shoulder injury in the first half following a collision with Brooklyn's Earl Clark. In other Saturday NBA action, the Boston Celtics beat the Toronto Raptors in overtime, the Golden State Warriors defeated the Dallas Mavericks, and the Detroit Pistons rallied to beat the Miami Heat 99-98.

A new Ofcom study reveals that 4G mobile phone services in the UK are significantly slower than promised, delivering average speeds of 14.7 megabits per second compared to 5.9Mbit/s for 3G - only 2.5 times faster rather than the "five times faster" that mobile phone companies boasted when 4G launched in 2012. EE delivered the fastest average download speed at 18.6Mbit/s, followed by Vodafone at 16.4Mbit/s, while the Three network had the slowest 4G speeds at just 8.5Mbit/s. The study also found that 4G speeds are declining as more users join the networks, with average speeds dropping from around 19Mbit/s at launch to the current 14.7Mbit/s.

Jimmy Anderson was honored with a special silver cap for reaching 100 Test matches for England, joining an elite group of fast bowling centurions. Meanwhile, West Indies' best batsman Chris Gayle chose to play in the IPL rather than for his country, hitting 21 runs for Royal Challengers Bangalore, highlighting how players prioritize lucrative T20 competitions over Test cricket. The article also notes new helmet designs implemented after Phillip Hughes' death last year, with players like Ian Bell wearing updated headgear with improved protection.

Ellia Beasley, a 22-year-old with more than 20 tattoos, had "scream your heart out" lyrics from Lost Prophets' song "Rooftops" tattooed on her belly in 2012, but came to regret featuring the Lost Prophet lyrics after the band's lead singer Ian Watkins was convicted of child sex offences and sent to prison for 35 years in 2013. After being told by multiple tattoo artists that the bold lyrics couldn't be covered, she finally found tattooist Kevin Paul who successfully created a new tattoo design featuring a giant owl that completely obscured Watkin's depraved crimes-associated lyrics, taking ten and a half hours to have the tattoo drawn and completed.

Taxi driver Teng Jiazhi, known as "Uncle Teng," from Shenyang, China, has entered the Chinese record books by taking 30,000 selfies with his passengers over ten years, starting when tourists offered him tips but he asked for a photo instead. The 58-year-old driver picks up around eighty passengers daily and takes selfies with at least twenty of them, with passengers commenting that his smile always looks the same and brightens their journey. Uncle Teng uploads the thousands of selfie photos to social media and has become one of the most recognized faces in the region, using his infectious smile and conversations to help passengers with their troubles.

Mindy Kaling's brother Vijay Chokal-Ingam has written a controversial book titled "Almost Black" in which he claims he pretended to be black when applying to medical schools in 1998, successfully interviewing at eleven prestigious institutions including Harvard and Columbia before being accepted to St. Louis University School of Medicine. Kaling has distanced herself from her estranged brother, stating she was unaware of his deception and disapproves of the book, while critics argue that Chokal-Ingam's experiment is insulting to what black people endure and undermines the necessity of affirmative action in addressing ongoing racism. Chokal-Ingam admits he never completed his medical degree and describes experiencing harassment while posing as a black man, but uses his experience to attack affirmative action policies rather than acknowledge the structural inequalities they address.

Julie McKenzie experienced severe nagging back pain that her GP initially attributed to scoliosis, but when she sought a second opinion and received an MRI scan, doctors discovered a malignant tumour in her coccyx that required surgical removal. The case highlights how chronic back pain is often dismissed as "non-specific low back pain" when it could indicate serious conditions like spinal tumours, which affect around 1,000 people annually and can be either benign or malignant. Despite successful tumour removal and being declared cured, Julie still experiences back pain from arthritis, but experts emphasize that early investigation through MRI scans after eight weeks of persistent pain could prevent missing treatable conditions.

Ryan Burns of Eureka, California, investigated continuous beeping sounds and discovered a disgruntled French Bulldog repeatedly honking a car horn after being left alone in the vehicle. Burns filmed the pooch standing with its front paws pressed on the horn and uploaded the video, which has been viewed over one million times. The dog's 15-year-old owner later came forward, claiming the pet wasn't left alone for long and had access to food and water on the cool day.

Photographer Anthony Barbour, 33, from Liverpool, has turned typical British locations including parks, villages and beaches into surreal individual "planets" using mind-bending 360-degree photography techniques. He spends hours in one spot taking 50 pictures while slowly rotating three times to capture his surroundings from floor to sky, then uses Photoshop to stitch them together, with his work showcasing locations like Sefton Park and Liverpool One shopping centre. Barbour finds photography serves as an artistic escape while dealing with a recent diagnosis of Ulcerative Pan Colitis, an autoimmune disease.

Waheed Ahmed, the 21-year-old son of Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed (who has been pictured with Ed Miliband), was arrested on suspicion of terrorism offences after being stopped at the Turkish-Syrian border with eight relatives while allegedly trying to enter Syria. The university student was detained at Birmingham Airport upon his return to the UK, while four other family members were arrested at Manchester Airport. All six people arrested have now been released without charge, with police stating no evidence was found of any imminent threat to UK communities.

A 32-year-old Massachusetts man, Carlos Colina, is facing murder charges after another man's remains were found in a duffel bag in Cambridge on Saturday. Police discovered the human remains of 26-year-old Jonathan Camilien in multiple locations, including along a walkway and in an apartment building near police headquarters. Colina, who knew the victim, was previously arraigned on assault and improper disposal of a body charges and will face murder charges on April 14.

In-form winger Aaron Murphy scored twice as Huddersfield secured a convincing 38-14 Super League victory over Catalans Dragons in a seven-try romp that ended their three-match losing streak. The 27-year-old former Wakefield Wildcats star has now scored six tries in his last five appearances, with his second try coming from a Danny Brough kick on 37 minutes as Huddersfield led 22-8 at halftime. Huddersfield responded strongly after falling behind early, scoring three tries in 10 minutes at the end of the first half to take control of the match.

A gang of at least three suspects attempted to carjack a driver at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning, and when he refused and ran away, they poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were still inside the vehicle. Although no one was injured in the incident, the car's front end was completely torched and destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the case as arson while the suspects remain at large.

According to Twitter-auditing tools, Hillary Clinton's robust 3.6 million Twitter followers include a significant number of fake accounts, with only 44 percent considered real people who are active on the social media platform and at least 15 percent completely fake. This contrasts sharply with President Barack Obama's Twitter followers, where just 4 percent are considered fake after the White House worked to purge fake accounts following a 2013 report. Clinton also faces questions about her Facebook followers, with over 46,000 listing Baghdad as their hometown, raising concerns about purchased social media engagement similar to issues that plagued the State Department during her tenure as Secretary of State.

Andrea Dossena, a 33-year-old former Liverpool player who once cost the club £7 million and scored memorable goals against Real Madrid and Manchester United, has been arrested on suspicion of shoplifting at Harrods in Knightsbridge on Tuesday. The Italian defender, who now plays for League One strugglers Leyton Orient, was bailed pending further enquiries along with a 31-year-old woman also arrested in connection with the incident. Leyton Orient released a statement acknowledging the incident but declined to comment further while the matter is being handled by authorities.

Animal Rescue Corps workers rescued 97 dogs from deplorable conditions in a windowless barn in Manchester, Tennessee, where the animals had been living in complete darkness surrounded by their own waste, with 10 dead dogs found piled in a wheelbarrow. The dogs, which included various breeds like Golden Retrievers, Shih Tzus, and Yorkshire Terriers, showed extreme fear after their prolonged suffering, but when brought outside they turned their noses to the sky to absorb sunlight and oxygen. The property owner, 64-year-old Caroline Irby, was charged with 10 counts of animal cruelty, and neighbors described her as seeming nice with no indication she was a dog hoarder.

Michael Easy, a 29-year-old from Southampton, was jailed for a second time after going on the run and taunting police by posting Facebook photos of himself in a platinum wig and Dame Edna-style glasses. The court heard Easy breached a restraining order by leaving a party with his former girlfriend, and he also assaulted two male prison officers at Winchester Prison, causing facial swelling to both guards. Easy was sentenced to a total of four months in jail for the restraining order breach and the assaults on prison staff.

Harold Ekeh, an 18-year-old Long Island senior who emigrated from Nigeria 10 years ago, has been accepted to all eight Ivy League schools plus five other prestigious universities after submitting college applications. Harold says his success stems from describing his family's struggle with emigrating to America in his essay, inspired by his parents' resilience as they worked to provide opportunities for their children. He is currently leaning toward Yale, which accepts only 6.3 percent of applicants, making him the second Long Island student in consecutive years to achieve acceptance to every Ivy League college.

David Cameron and his wife Samantha have revealed in intensely personal interviews that they were "falling apart" from the pressure of caring for their son Ivan, who was born with Ohtahara Syndrome, a rare brain disorder that left him wheelchair-bound and suffering from severe epileptic fits. The couple described how caring for Ivan, who died at age six in 2009, pushed their relationship to "breaking point" within the first year, with Samantha calling it their "worst nightmare" and saying many marriages don't survive such challenges. The interviews were conducted around what would have been Ivan's 13th birthday, while David Cameron also took a break from the campaign trail to be photographed feeding an orphaned lamb at a farm in his constituency.

BBC listeners have complained that the last minutes of radio dramas and shows like Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour are being cut off on the iPlayer service, calling the problem "irritating," "annoying," and "frustrating." The BBC blames the issue on its automatic recording system, which gets confused when live sections of radio stations cause programme start and end times to shift. After audience complaints were raised through Radio 4's Feedback programme, the BBC has apologized and is now adding two minutes to the end of all recordings to prevent shows from losing their vital final moments.

Today's CNN Student News program covers international headlines from Switzerland, Kenya, and the Pacific Ocean, along with California's drought restrictions, religious holidays, and U.S. National Parks topics. The show provides a transcript for students and teachers, plus a weekly newsquiz covering current events like elections, space missions, and global conflicts. Students and teachers can request their schools to be featured on the CNN Student News Roll Call by commenting with their school information, with selections made from previous show comments.

Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge faces a fitness battle to be ready for Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after being ruled out of Monday night's Premier League clash against Newcastle United due to an injury sustained against Blackburn Rovers. Manager Brendan Rodgers confirmed that Sturridge's fitness will be monitored throughout the week ahead of the Wembley showdown, as the FA Cup represents Liverpool's last chance for silverware this season. Meanwhile, Manchester United's 4-2 victory over Manchester City has given Liverpool hope of closing the gap to just four points behind fourth-placed City in the race for Champions League qualification.

Thomas Buckett, now 21, faces a £150,000 legal bill after unsuccessfully suing Staffordshire County Council following a school break-in incident in 2010 when he was 16. Buckett plunged 15ft through a glass skylight onto a concrete floor while breaking into a school tuck shop with friends, sustaining life-changing head injuries including ten skull fractures and spending two weeks in a coma. The court ruled against the family's claim that the council should have done more to secure the premises, ordering them to pay the substantial legal costs.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho believes he is continuously improving in every aspect of his job, having won league titles in all four countries he has managed (Portugal, England, Italy, and Spain). However, Mourinho admits his one problem is his inability to be anything but truthful when addressing the media, which regularly gets him in trouble with the Football Association. The former Real Madrid manager was fined £25,000 earlier this season for claiming there was a "campaign" against his side following controversial refereeing decisions.

Two black candidates were elected to the Ferguson City Council on Tuesday, tripling African-American representation to half of the six-member council in the St. Louis suburb where two-thirds of residents are black. This was the first municipal election since white police officer Darren Wilson fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown in August, which sparked violent protests and led to a federal investigation that found widespread racism in the city government. Voter turnout more than doubled from the previous election to 29.4%, as the community sought change through the ballot box rather than continued street protests.

Chelsea will face Paris Saint-Germain in a pre-season friendly on July 25 in North Carolina, marking a rematch against the French team that knocked Jose Mourinho's side out of the Champions League this season on away goals. The Blues will play three games in the United States as part of the International Champions Cup, including matches against New York Red Bulls on July 22 and Barcelona, before returning to face Fiorentina at Stamford Bridge on August 5. Chelsea, currently 10 points ahead of Arsenal and closing in on the Premier League title, will use these fixtures to prepare for defending their probable championship in the 2015/16 campaign.

Burnley manager Sean Dyche has defended struggling striker Danny Ings, who hasn't scored since February 11 and is linked with moves to Manchester United or Liverpool, by insisting the entire team must share the goalscoring burden to keep the club in the Premier League. Meanwhile, Everton defeated Burnley 1-0, with manager Roberto Martinez stating he won't decide until the season ends whether to make Aaron Lennon's loan move from Tottenham permanent. Burnley remains bottom of the table after scoring just one goal in their last seven matches, putting pressure on the 23-year-old Ings and his teammates in their fight against relegation.

English photographer John Chapple has traveled worldwide creating stunning panoramic landscape images using a specialized film camera, capturing diverse scenes from major US cities like Los Angeles and Santa Monica to Australian beaches and English countryside. Despite failing art in school, the self-taught Chapple uses a unique Linhof Technorama 617s III camera that produces large 6x17 centimeter negatives, and he revealed in a 2012 interview that becoming a father motivated him to document the world's changing landscapes for future generations. Chapple dreams of making a living from his landscape photography while currently balancing it with his work as a news and showbusiness photographer.

FEMAIL examines controversial celebrity handbags, highlighting Madonna's new black crocodile "dealer" purse with its seemingly drug-related slogan that has caused a stir on social media. The article also covers Rihanna, who has carried multiple provocative bags including gun-themed clutches and cannabis leaf designs, with the singer seeming to embrace controversial accessories. Other examples include designer James Piatt's weapon-inspired bags, Grayson Perry's anatomically explicit designs, and problematic luggage stickers created by Vancouver designers featuring disturbing imagery.

ABC's World News Tonight with David Muir has officially overtaken NBC's Nightly News in the ratings war for the first time in more than five and a half years, ending NBC's 288 consecutive week winning streak. The ratings shift comes two months after NBC anchor Brian Williams received a six-month suspension for misleading viewers about his Iraq War coverage, with well-liked veteran Lester Holt serving as substitute anchor during Williams' absence. ABC attracted 84,000 more viewers than NBC for the week ending April 3, though it remains unclear what impact this ratings win will have on Holt's future role at the network.

Robert Downey Jr has been accused of making a racist remark during an interview when he responded to Oscar-winning Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's claim that superhero movies were "cultural genocide" by saying "I think for a man whose native tongue is Spanish to be able to put together a phrase like 'cultural genocide' just speaks to how bright he is." The comments sparked a furious backlash on Twitter with many calling it racist and ignorant. This controversy adds to other issues during the Avengers: Age of Ultron press tour, including Chris Evans and Jeremy Renner being forced to apologize for calling co-star Scarlett Johansson's character a "slut," and Downey Jr walking out of a separate Channel 4 interview when asked about his past drug abuse.

A leaked police affidavit reveals that an anonymous prisoner who shared a police van with Freddie Gray claims the 25-year-old was "banging against the walls" and "intentionally trying to injure himself" before dying from spinal cord injuries. Gray's family attorney rejected the implication that Gray severed his own spinal cord, questioning the accuracy of police reports, while six police officers involved in Gray's arrest remain suspended pending investigation. Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts said Gray appeared capable of walking when stepping into the van, but Gray died a week later at the hospital after being found unconscious on the van floor with a partially severed spinal cord.

Never-before-seen photos from Sir Paul McCartney's 2002 wedding to Heather Mills have emerged, showing the former Beatle's daughters Stella and Mary looking decidedly glum in the wedding party picture, reflecting their disapproval of their father's choice of partner following the death of his first wife Linda. The secret wedding reception at Castle Leslie in Ireland was attended by 300 guests who were flown from Heathrow Airport to an undisclosed location, and the photos reveal Sir Paul performing a mock striptease for his bride during the celebration. The images, belonging to McCartney's late housekeeper's family, are being auctioned and serve as a portent of the bitter divorce that would follow when the couple separated in 2006.

Sebastian Vettel celebrated Ferrari's first Formula One victory in 35 races after winning the Malaysian Grand Prix, ending the team's nearly two-year drought since their last win in May 2013. The four-time world champion returned to a hero's welcome at Ferrari's Maranello factory, where the team revived long-standing victory traditions including raising a Ferrari flag at the entrance gate and holding a celebratory lunch for all factory workers. Vettel expressed determination to ensure this won't be a one-off success, though he acknowledged Mercedes remains very strong as Ferrari looks to build on their competitive package in upcoming races.

Iona Costello, 51, and her daughter Emily, who went missing last month from Long Island, have been found safe and well at a hotel in New York City's Upper West Side. The disappearance occurred amid a legal battle with Iona's late husband George's adult children over his will, after George died of a heart attack in 2012. The case involved a complicated family situation, including Iona's stepson George Costello Jr, who has a history of drug arrests and was jailed in Florida around the time of their disappearance, and her brother-in-law John Costello, who faces vehicular manslaughter charges.

A tragic incident occurred on a rubber dinghy carrying around 100 African refugees across the Mediterranean when a Nigerian Christian's prayers sparked violence from Muslim migrants, resulting in 12 Christians being thrown overboard and drowning. Italian police arrested 15 people suspected in the killings, which happened amid a massive refugee crisis where 10,000 refugees fleeing war and persecution in Africa have been rescued by Italian ships in the past week, though over 900 have died or gone missing this year. The incident highlights the desperate and dangerous conditions faced by migrants, including another recent rescue of 70 refugees where a six-month-old baby and others suffered severe burns from a gas explosion at a Libyan holding center before being forced onto boats without medical treatment.

Four-month-old baby Evan Summerfield from Devon died from meningococcal septicaemia just 12 hours after laughing for the first time, devastating his parents Shannon Summerfield, 17, and Kris Adams, 19. Despite being rushed to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth when he developed a rash from head to belly-button, doctors were unable to save Evan after he was diagnosed with bacterial meningitis. The family has set up a fundraising page for his funeral costs, with extra donations going to the Meningitis Research Foundation to help prevent other families from experiencing similar tragedy.

A 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan named Krista Dotzenrod from Minnesota managed to catch a foul ball directly in her cup of beer during Saturday afternoon's game between the Cubs and San Diego Padres. After making the incredible catch, Dotzenrod chugged the beer with the ball still inside to celebrate, delighting fans around her. The Cubs won the game 7-6 in 11 innings, and Dotzenrod's lucky catch quickly gained attention on social media.

Erik Meldik pranked his girlfriend Dominika Petrinova by telling her that her beloved dog Sam had accidentally been put in the washing machine, causing her to burst into tears before he revealed it was just a joke. In revenge, Petrinova decided to get back at her boyfriend with a painful prank of her own - she glued waxing strips to a chair and tricked the naked and blindfolded Meldik into sitting on it. Erik Meldik screamed in pain and cried as he found himself stuck to the chair by his genitals and had to rip himself free, leaving skin and hair behind in the process.

Hull City are targeting QPR centre-back Nedum Onuoha, who is also interesting Everton and West Ham United as several clubs look to sign the 28-year-old defender. Onuoha is among players expected to leave QPR if the club faces relegation, despite recently playing in their crucial 4-1 win over relegation rivals West Bromwich Albion. Hull City are also showing interest in West Bromwich Albion striker Victor Anichebe, who is likely to be sold this summer.

London's newest single-item restaurant, Oshun Café, has opened serving £6 bowls of Brazilian superfood acai berries, with four variations including Oshun Native (made with acaí pulp, banana and honey), Oshun Tang (made with courgette, lime, sour cherries and acai pulp), Oshun Kong (featuring acaí pulp, banana, lemongrass, ginger, coriander and honey), and Oshun Maya (with acaí pulp, raw cacao, cinnamon, orange and avocado). This follows a trend of specialized eateries in the UK, including the Porridge Cafe serving 25 types of porridge, the first cereal cafe featuring 120 cereals opened by twins Alan and Gary Keery, upcoming Melt Room serving toasted "melts," and Black Milk Cereal Dive opening in Manchester.

The partially-submerged ruins of St Ivan Rilski Church are all that remain of the Bulgarian settlement of Zapalnya, where residents were forced to leave their homes in the 1960s when the Communist regime built a dam that swallowed the town. The church, built in 1895, now stands as a ghostly figure in the Zhrebchevo reservoir in south-east Bulgaria, about 175 miles east of the capital Sofia, after the surrounding homes were destroyed when the area was flooded in 1965. According to Radio Bulgaria, the church was once the heart of life in the valley for a town that had existed since before the 13th century and was known for rose oil production during the Ottoman Empire.

Real Madrid demolished Granada 9-1 in La Liga, with Cristiano Ronaldo scoring five goals including a seven-minute hat-trick, while Karim Benzema added two goals and Gareth Bale also found the net. The massive victory helped Real Madrid bounce back from their El Clasico defeat to Barcelona, with James Rodriguez returning to the starting lineup and contributing to the dominant performance. Granada managed only a consolation goal through Robert Ibanez in what became the biggest win of the La Liga season.

Everton hosts Southampton in a Premier League clash at Goodison Park, with both teams facing injury concerns as Everton striker Romelu Lukaku will undergo a late fitness test for a hamstring problem while Southampton midfielder Steven Davis is doubtful due to a groin injury suffered on international duty. Everton has struggled recently, failing to score in three of their last four Premier League matches against Southampton, while the Saints are looking to equal their best ever points tally in a single Premier League season with a potential victory.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer for the Japan international. While Chelsea would likely loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, the 22-year-old wants to carefully consider joining a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has acknowledged awareness of Muto, noting that commercial interests, including their recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, play a role in the club's transfer policy.

John Wild was found guilty of racially abusing former Wales goalkeeper Jason Brown during a football match last October and received a three-year banning order along with community service and compensation orders. While Kick It Out welcomed the successful prosecution, Brown criticized the organization, along with the FA and PFA, for not providing adequate support during the incident, claiming they "did nothing about it." Kick It Out responded by detailing their involvement, stating they met with Brown immediately after the incident and offered support, but Brown did not respond to follow-up attempts to assist him.

Scott Turner Schofield, an author and performer known for his one-person shows that address transgender issues, has landed a recurring role on the popular daytime soap opera "The Bold and the Beautiful," making him the first transgender man to have such a role on daytime television. Schofield will be playing Nick, a mentor character to Maya Avant (played by Karla Mosley), who is struggling with her gender identity in the show's current storyline. This groundbreaking casting comes just days after Bruce Jenner's high-profile interview with Diane Sawyer, marking another significant moment for transgender representation on television.

Researchers warn that children should not be encouraged to play rugby at school due to serious injury risks, with as many as 1 in 8 players suffering injuries severe enough to miss at least seven training sessions or matches, including fractures, concussion, and spinal damage. Professor Allyson Pollock argues that the UK has inadequate child injury surveillance systems and calls for comprehensive injury monitoring before increasing rugby participation in schools, suggesting safer alternatives like touch rugby instead of contact rugby where most injuries occur during scrums and tackles.

Tiger Woods gave a golfing lesson to 7ft 6in former NBA star Yao Ming at Nike's headquarters in Shanghai, China, where the retired Chinese basketball star and former Houston Rockets centre towered over golf's former world No 1 as Woods helped him work on his swing. Meanwhile, Woods has confirmed his return to the PGA Tour at the Players Championship on May 7, allaying fears about a wrist injury he suffered at Augusta during the Masters.

Andy Murray advanced to the Miami Open semi-finals after defeating 21-year-old Austrian Dominic Thiem 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, despite getting a scare when Thiem pushed the match to 4-4 in the second set before Murray ultimately prevailed. The world No. 4 also addressed the controversy surrounding Aljaz Bedene's switch to British citizenship, telling fellow British players like James Ward and Kyle Edmund that they should use Bedene's arrival as motivation to improve their rankings rather than complain about it. Murray's fiancée Kim Sears was spotted watching from the stands wearing her engagement ring as Murray prepared for his upcoming wedding next week.

Vincent Kompany, the Manchester City captain who has won two Premier League titles, revealed that his mother prevented him from joining Manchester United when he was 17 years old after Sir Alex Ferguson made an inquiry about the young defender who was breaking through at Anderlecht. Kompany admits his mother insisted he finish his education before moving to England, and he eventually joined the Premier League in 2008 with Manchester City instead. The revelation comes ahead of Sunday's Manchester derby at Old Trafford, where Kompany says the rivalry has shifted from being heavily in United's favor to now being almost 50-50 between the two clubs.

Leading author Margaret Atwood, 75, dismissed the Duchess of Cambridge as an 'uneventful' dresser who is told what to wear by advisers, saying Kate hasn't lived up to the fashion icon reputation of Princess Diana. Despite Atwood's criticism that Kate "dresses quite uneventfully," the Duchess's clothing choices continue to have massive commercial impact, with items like a £35 ASOS dress selling out within half an hour and a £46 Seraphine dress she wore in her first official family portrait with William and Prince George selling out in just two hours.

Martyn Uzzell, a 51-year-old experienced cyclist, died instantly after being thrown from his bike by a four-inch deep pothole during a charity ride from Land's End to John O'Groats, landing in the path of a car. Despite police reporting the pothole as a hazard a month before the incident, North Yorkshire County Council failed to repair it after inspections deemed it non-urgent. His widow Kate Uzzell has now received a six-figure payout from the council, though they refuse to apologize and accept no liability for the preventable death.

Cristiano Ronaldo scored five goals for the first time in his career as Real Madrid demolished Granada 9-1 on Sunday, with the Portuguese star's historic performance dominating Spanish sports newspapers and keeping their title hopes alive. Meanwhile, league leaders Barcelona maintained their four-point advantage at the top by defeating Celta Vigo 1-0 thanks to French defender Jeremy Mathieu's diving header.

Holland manager Guus Hiddink criticized his own supporters as a "disgrace" for booing Spain midfielder Andres Iniesta during Holland's 2-0 friendly victory over Spain on Tuesday night at the Amsterdam Arena. The Dutch fans jeered Iniesta when he entered the match in the 76th minute, likely due to his famous goal against the Netherlands in the 2010 World Cup final. Goals from Stefan de Vrij and Davy Klaassen secured the morale-boosting win for Hiddink's side, though the manager was more focused on condemning the disrespectful treatment of the world-class Spanish player.

Hillary Clinton's trusted aide Huma Abedin was spotted enjoying a family day out in New York with her husband, disgraced former congressman Anthony Weiner, and their two-year-old son Jordan at a Mexican restaurant called Tortaría. This outing came just days after Abedin and Clinton made headlines during their Iowa campaign stop at Chipotle, where they were criticized for not leaving a tip. The family meal represents a brief moment of normalcy before the intensity of Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign ramps up, with other candidates like Republican hopeful Marco Rubio also making similar stops at Mexican restaurants to court voters.

Football Shirt Friday, now in its third year, encourages people to wear football shirts during Bowel Cancer Awareness Month in April to support The Bobby Moore Fund for Cancer Research UK, honoring the memory of 1966 World Cup-winning captain Bobby Moore who died from bowel and liver cancer in 1993 at age 51. Celebrities including Rob Lee and Clare Balding showed their support on social media by donning their favorite kits to raise awareness and funds for bowel cancer research. People can participate by wearing any football shirt and donating at footballshirtfriday.org.

Former light-heavyweight champion Quinton 'Rampage' Jackson returns to the UFC after two years with Bellator to face Fabio Maldonado at UFC 186 in Montreal, following a stressful legal battle that allowed him to compete. The fight will take place at a catchweight of 215lbs, with Jackson expressing his preference for exciting stand-up battles over wrestlers who "lay on top" of opponents. Jackson emphasized that both fighters agreed to the catchweight to ensure they could perform as healthy, strong competitors rather than killing themselves to make a lower weight limit.

A pregnant woman and her partner were rescued from the English Channel after their trimaran capsized near Dungeness Point, Kent, leaving them clinging to the overturned vessel in the water. The woman's partner heroically dove under the capsized boat to retrieve an emergency flare, which helped alert rescuers to their location after a member of the public spotted them about a mile from shore and raised the alarm. Both were wearing lifejackets and were quickly rescued by coastguard and RNLI crews, though they were cold and shaken by the ordeal.

Cassandra C., a 17-year-old who was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma and given an 85% chance of survival with treatment, completed her chemotherapy at Connecticut Children's Medical Center on Monday after being forced to remain in the hospital since December under state custody. The teen had initially run away after two days of treatment, not wanting to put "poison" into her body, but a judge ordered her into state custody to ensure she received life-saving treatment. Now in remission and having completed her treatment, the temporary custody order has ended and she has been released from the hospital.

Pierre Collins, a 33-year-old father, was arrested Monday on suspicion of second-degree murder in the death of his 10-year-old son Barway Edward Collins, whose body was found in the Mississippi River over the weekend. The Minnesota boy had been reported missing nearly a month ago, and police identified Pierre Collins as the primary suspect based on electronic evidence showing he was in the area when his son disappeared. Collins had previously appeared at vigils pleading for his son's safe return, but authorities say he has not been completely truthful with investigators.

Following Saturday's devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake that killed over 4,000 people in Nepal, mass cremations are taking place along the Bagmati river in Kathmandu as families desperately try to honor their dead according to Hindu tradition. The sacred Pashupatinath Temple is overwhelmed, receiving 500 bodies per day compared to the usual 30, while cremation grounds struggle with shortages of wood needed for the thousands of pyres and limited space for the ceremonies. Meanwhile, rescue efforts continue to search for survivors beneath the rubble as authorities cope with shortages of food, water, and medical supplies, along with growing concerns about disease outbreaks.

A horse named Cody got stuck in thick mud after wandering into a bog in Belvedere, south-east London on Friday afternoon. Animal rescue experts and crew members spent more than an hour working to free the distressed horse, with some climbing into the watery ditch to help ease Cody to safety. Despite being covered in mud and shaken by the ordeal, Cody was unharmed and taken back to stables to be examined by a veterinarian.

Karen Bell, 42, from Hull, was jailed for 12 months after pleading guilty to blackmailing a man she met on the free dating website Plenty of Fish. Bell threatened to post footage online of their sexual encounters unless he paid her money, initially demanding £25 but eventually receiving £55 total. The court heard that Bell claimed her son had secretly filmed their sex tryst and would publish the videos on Facebook and local websites if the victim didn't pay.

Chelsea forward Didier Drogba has been awarded the Barclays Spirit of the Game trophy for his inspired charity work through the Didier Drogba Foundation in Africa, which aims to inspire the next generation of African footballers. The 37-year-old, who scored against Leicester on Wednesday, grew up playing football in the streets of Ivory Coast and now works to give children opportunities through education and healthcare support. The foundation has raised £400,000 to complete a medical clinic in Abidjan and fund mobile clinics to help those who cannot travel to receive medical care.

Senior Islamist party official Mohammad Qamaruzzaman was executed in Bangladesh after being convicted of crimes against humanity for his role in the 1971 independence war, where he led a militia group that killed around 120 unarmed farmers. The execution took place after he refused to seek presidential clemency and the Supreme Court rejected his final appeal against the death sentence he received in May 2013. Bangladeshi security personnel escorted an ambulance carrying his body from Central Jail, while his political party Jamaat-e-Islami denounced the execution and called for protests.

The article follows a journalist's exploration of Washington D.C. through the lens of the hit US political TV series House of Cards, which features Francis Underwood played by Kevin Spacey. The writer visits key political venues like the Capital Grille where real senators dine and plot, tours the Capitol building atop Capitol Hill, and explores locations connected to US President Barack Obama such as Ben's Chili Bowl restaurant. The piece also highlights Washington's major tourist attractions including the Smithsonian museums, the Washington Monument, and the National Archives, while drawing parallels between the dark political machinations depicted in House of Cards and the real-world power dynamics of America's capital.

Leo Bernal, an 8-year-old boy from Culver City, California, was released from the hospital Friday, five days after being shot in the head by an armed home intruder who opened fire in his bedroom. Doctors had to open his skull to remove the bullet, leaving him with 23 staples in his scalp, though he is expected to recover. Leo's mother said her son is now scared to return home after the traumatic Sunday night attack, in which the gunman fired 14 shots into the child's room while his family was present.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, police said. The attack occurred in Khost city as protesters were heading to join a rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility so far.

The third World Happiness Report, released by the Sustainable Development Solutions Network for the United Nations, ranks the world's happiest countries based on factors like life expectancy, social support, generosity, freedom, low corruption, and GDP per capita. Switzerland topped the list in 2015, followed by Iceland, Denmark, Norway, and Canada, with the report encouraging governments to measure and improve their citizens' well-being. The concept originated from Bhutan's "Gross National Happiness" measure, leading to the UN's designation of March 20 as World Happiness Day in 2012.

Four-year-old Austin West drowned last Saturday after falling into a pool while chasing a bumblebee, with the shock of cold water and his chronic asthma causing him to go under. When Austin's grandfather Jeff West tried to set up a GoFundMe campaign to raise money for funeral costs, he discovered that scammers had already created multiple fake fundraisers using the boy's name. The fake campaigns have since been removed, and the West family has set up legitimate fundraising efforts including a GoFundMe page seeking $10,000 and a T-shirt campaign to cover expenses.

National Front founder Jean-Marie Le Pen, 86, withdrew from France's regional elections after his daughter Marine, the party's current leader, accused him of "political suicide" for making racist and anti-Semitic remarks, including calling the Holocaust—in which Nazis murdered six million Jews—"a detail of history" and praising France's wartime collaborator Marshal Petain. Le Pen now wants his 25-year-old granddaughter Marion Marechal-Le Pen to replace him as a candidate, which she has agreed to pursue. Opinion polls suggest Marine Le Pen is likely to reach the second round of France's 2017 presidential elections, though not expected to win.

Andrew Getty, the 47-year-old grandson of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, died Tuesday afternoon at his Los Angeles home from what appears to be natural causes or an accident. Getty was the son of Gordon Getty, who has a net worth of $2.1 billion and is one of three sons of J. Paul Getty, once considered the world's richest man. Court records show Andrew Getty had recently filed for a restraining order against a woman, with a hearing scheduled for the following week.

Getty Images photographer Matthew Lewis won the Wisden–MCC Cricket Photograph of the Year 2014 with his stunning image of West Indies player Dwayne Bravo taking a spectacular full-length catch to dismiss Australia's James Faulkner during the ICC World Twenty20 competition in Bangladesh. The short-list featured diverse cricket photography from around the world, showcasing both professional stars and amateur players, including dramatic moments like England bowler Stuart Broad being hit in the face by a ball that broke his nose, and England batsman Michael Carberry's bat snapping in two during a defensive stroke. The collection demonstrates cricket's global reach through images ranging from children playing on a Bangladesh rubbish tip to players competing in extreme conditions on Mount Kilimanjaro.

A new Reddit thread asking users to submit the most horrendous baby names they've encountered attracted over 18,000 comments in just 24 hours, with FEMAIL compiling the worst examples. The submissions included shocking names like "Orgasm" (submitted by a midwife's daughter), "Obamaniqua," "I'munique," "Britney Shakira Beyonce," and "Like" (named after Facebook), among other creative but questionable parental naming choices. The thread revealed numerous examples of poor parental judgment in baby naming, from alternative spellings like "Airwrecker" for Erica to combinations like "Hellzel" (mixing Hazel with Hells Angels).

The number of hayfever sufferers in the UK is predicted to reach 20 million this summer, up a third from last year, with five million people expected to experience symptoms for the first time due to warmer weather and high pollen counts. The hayfever season is becoming longer, typically stretching from April to the end of August, with grass pollen being the main culprit causing symptoms like streaming eyes, sneezing, and throat irritation. Experts recommend that sufferers prepare by stocking up on antihistamines and other treatments before the season starts, as pollen counts can surge suddenly under the right weather conditions.

Raheem Sterling, the 20-year-old Liverpool forward, has rejected a new £100,000-per-week contract offer from Liverpool and will wait until summer to decide his future, with two years remaining on his current £35,000-per-week deal. The article traces Sterling's remarkable rise from his tough childhood in Jamaica and north London to becoming a key player for both Liverpool and England, including his journey through QPR's academy before joining Liverpool in 2010 for £500,000. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers now faces the challenge of convincing Sterling to sign what could be one of the biggest deals in the club's history, as the young player has demonstrated his value both on the pitch and in contract negotiations.

TV star Karren Brady, who is an Apprentice judge and Baroness, agreed to help David Cameron announce 16,000 new apprenticeships today at a National Grid training centre, though she ended up in a supporting role helping the Prime Minister with his jacket. The announcement includes deals with major companies like Morrisons (9,000 apprentices) and National Grid (500 new apprentices), building on the 2.2 million apprenticeships already created since 2010. Cameron pledged that a future Conservative government would create three million more high-quality apprenticeships over the next five years if the Tories win the election.

Extreme skier Oscar Hübinette performed a death-defying ski run down the icy slopes of the active Tolbachik volcano on Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula, while photographer Fredrik Schenholm captured the dramatic scene with lava bubbling furiously behind him. The 12,000-foot volcano, which erupted in November 2012 after lying dormant since 1976, created an incredible contrast between the -25°C air temperature and the 1,000°C+ lava temperature. The Kamchatka Peninsula is home to 160 volcanoes, with 29 still active, making this one of the most dangerous and spectacular extreme skiing stunts ever documented.

Newcastle head coach John Carver says he will use a "whip" to motivate his players ahead of Sunday's Tyne-Wear derby against Sunderland, after the Magpies have lost the last four matches against their North-East rivals. Carver admits that Sunderland wanted victory more than Newcastle in those previous encounters and is determined to ensure his team doesn't get out-worked again. Meanwhile, Sunderland will be looking to keep their winning record going under new manager Dick Advocaat in what will be his second game in charge.

The Scottish Football Association failed in their appeal to increase the punishment for Rangers goalkeeper Steve Simonsen, who received a one-game ban for breaching the SFA's zero-tolerance gambling rules by betting on 50 football matches over a year. The SFA's compliance officer had argued that Simonsen's original punishment was "unduly lenient," but an appellate tribunal rejected the appeal to extend his suspension. Simonsen had not bet on any games involving his own club's competitions, distinguishing his case from previous more severe punishments given to players who bet on matches in which they were directly involved.

Newcastle goalkeeper Tim Krul was criticized by pundits including Jamie Carragher for congratulating Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe on his brilliant goal at half-time during their derby match, with critics arguing such sportsmanship was inappropriate during an intense local rivalry. The author defends Krul's gesture by comparing it to the famous 1970 World Cup embrace between Pele and Bobby Moore after Brazil's 1-0 victory over England, arguing that football has become too "leeched of humanity" if players can't acknowledge great technique and show basic sportsmanship. The piece suggests there's a double standard at play, questioning whether the criticism would have been as harsh if it had been an English player like Defoe congratulating a foreign goalkeeper instead.

President Barack Obama and his wife Michelle paid more than $93,000 in federal taxes on an adjusted gross income of over $477,000, according to their 2014 tax returns released Friday by the White House. The Obamas lowered their tax bill by claiming nearly $160,000 in itemized deductions, including $70,712 in charitable donations to 33 different charities, donating nearly 15 percent of their income. The couple's tax returns, which include their Illinois state income tax return, show an effective tax rate of 19.6 percent.

Saracens have announced that 31-year-old Argentina centre Marcelo Bosch has signed a contract extension at the club, following his heroic last-minute penalty kick that secured a 12-11 European Champions Cup quarter-final victory over Racing Metro. Bosch, who joined Saracens from Biarritz in 2013, has been praised by rugby director Mark McCall for his hard work and improvement since arriving at the club. The contract extension follows similar deals announced earlier this week for locks George Kruis and Maro Itoje.

High-powered human rights lawyer Amal Clooney held a press conference in Washington DC today calling for the release of imprisoned former president of the Maldives, Mohamed Nasheed, who was sentenced to 13 years in prison under anti-terror laws. Clooney, who is part of Nasheed's international legal team, said she will not rest until her client walks free and announced plans to appeal to the US government to pressure the Maldives for his release. Human rights activists have condemned Nasheed's imprisonment as politically motivated, calling his trial a "sham" and "travesty of justice."

Paula Radcliffe, who won the London Marathon three times and set the marathon world record in 2003, completed her final professional marathon on Sunday after battling back from injuries that threatened to end her career. The 41-year-old mother-of-two, who never won an Olympic medal despite being favored at multiple Olympics, underwent foot surgery in 2012 that doctors feared might prevent her from ever running again. After the surgery worked and she was able to return to running, Radcliffe ran the 26.2 mile London Marathon one last time with the masses rather than the elite field, bringing down the curtain on her inspirational career.

Aaron Ramsey has scored 25 goals for Arsenal since last season, with his recent goal against Burnley being dedicated to his late grandmother Eileen who passed away a few weeks ago. The Welsh midfielder reflected on his dramatic extra-time winner in the 2014 FA Cup final against Hull City that ended Arsenal's nine-year trophy drought, describing it as overwhelming and a dream come true. As Arsenal prepares for their FA Cup semi-final against Reading under manager Arsene Wenger, Ramsey expressed optimism about the team's improved form and their chances of adding more silverware, while acknowledging they cannot take any opponent lightly.

Teenager Lily Sharp from the UK played an elaborate prank on her mother by faking her own kidnapping through text messages, starting with innocent texts about a decorator before escalating to demanding a £4000 ransom while pretending to be the kidnapper. Lily's panicking mother became increasingly frantic and even called the police before Lily finally revealed it was all a trick by sending a photo of herself at home. While her mother was not amused by the cruel joke, Lily's screenshots of the conversation went viral on Twitter with thousands of retweets and favorites.

More than 10,000 migrants and refugees have arrived at Italy's islands from North Africa since last weekend according to the Italian Coast Guard, with over 140,000 migrants arriving from the North African coast in 2011 after Gadhafi's overthrow removed controls on migrant flows from Libya. Italy launched a €9M-a-month rescue program called Mare Nostrum in 2013 that saved over 160,000 migrants, but ended it in 2014 due to EU criticism that it was encouraging more migrants to make the dangerous journey, leading to the smaller EU Frontex operation that has far less capacity to rescue migrants at sea.

Sam Allardyce responded to West Ham co-owner David Sullivan's criticism that the team's last 12 games have been "exceedingly disappointing," telling Sullivan not to judge the season based solely on their 2015 form, which has seen them collect just 11 points. Despite the poor recent results, Allardyce feels the overall season has been a success as West Ham have already surpassed last year's point total with seven games remaining. Meanwhile, Enner Valencia is available for selection against Stoke City after recovering from a bizarre toe injury suffered at home.

A new study by Lancashire's Edge Hill University found a direct link between anxiety and exam performance, saying pupils who worry about their exam performance are more likely to do badly than those who are less anxious.
