As the school exam season approaches, Michael Ribton, principal at Burlington Danes Academy, advises parents to engage actively by putting revision timetables on the fridge, testing children on material, and ensuring proper nutrition and exercise. The article also features student Fatima Sharif's revision tips and introduces techniques like "Spaced Learning," which consists of three identical inputs divided by brain gym activities to help students retain information quickly.

Scotland international centre Matt Scott has been ruled out for the rest of the season after undergoing a second shoulder operation in a year, putting his World Cup participation in doubt and dealing a major blow to Edinburgh's European Challenge Cup semi-final hopes against Newport Gwent Dragons. Scott, who has 25 caps for Scotland, sustained his latest injury while on Scotland duty against Ireland in the final Six Nations match last month, and his absence could leave Scotland coach Vern Cotter with a significant gap to fill at centre for the World Cup. Edinburgh hooker Ross Ford remains optimistic about their semi-final chances despite the setback, calling a potential Challenge Cup victory his biggest achievement and a major boost for Scottish rugby.

The New York Post's Page Six alleged Sunday that chef Bobby Flay's divorce from actress Stephanie March was caused by his ongoing affair with his 28-year-old assistant Elyse Tirrel. According to the report, the 50-year-old Flay has been having the affair for three years, which March discovered after Thanksgiving 2014. However, Flay's business partner dismissed the claims, saying he would know about any affair with an employee, while Flay's representative suggested the allegations were leaked to renegotiate their prenuptial agreement.

Emma Louise Connolly, the girlfriend of Made in Chelsea's Ollie Proudlock who started dating him in October last year, models Ann Summers' first bridal wear lingerie collection. The collection includes lingerie and loungewear in ivory and nude palettes, priced between £14 and £85, and is available in sizes 8-12 and 32A-38DD. Items in the collection range from curve-skimming dresses to intricate nightgowns and silk and lace sets designed for brides.

The UN's World Meteorological Organization removed the name "Isis" from the official list of future Pacific hurricane names for 2016, deeming it inappropriate due to its association with the ISIS militant group that stands accused of committing brutal atrocities against civilians. The name, originally derived from an ancient Egyptian goddess, was replaced with "Ivette" on the WMO list. The Hurricane Committee also noted that the 2014 eastern North Pacific hurricane season was well above normal with 20 tropical storms forming, of which 14 became hurricanes and eight reached major hurricane strength, making the hurricane total the second highest on record for the basin.

Game of Thrones fans leaked the first four episodes of season five online before the show's official premiere, with the episodes being downloaded over 550,000 times by early Sunday morning after appearing on torrent sites Saturday night. HBO confirmed the leaked episodes originated from within an approved group that received review copies, and the company is investigating how the breach occurred. The series remains the most illegally downloaded show in the world, with episodes from the first four seasons being pirated more than seven million times between February and April 2015, representing a 45% increase from the previous year.

A new ComRes poll for ITV News reveals that 54% of voters want Nicola Sturgeon kept out of the next UK government and 59% oppose the SNP playing any role in running the country, despite the SNP being positioned to make major gains in Scotland that could rob Ed Miliband of an overall majority. Sturgeon today launched her party's manifesto setting out demands including extra spending, an end to austerity, and scrapping Trident as the price for propping up a Labour government, while Prime Minister David Cameron warned that an SNP-Labour deal would be a "match made in hell" for the British economy.

Jeremy Scott's spring/summer 2015 Moschino collection caused an internet sensation when he sent models down the Milan runway in Barbie doll inspired dresses to Aqua's "Barbie Girl," prompting journalist Olivia Phillips to test how the look translates to real life by wearing the collection on the streets of Dubai. Weighed down by dramatic eyelashes and sporting high heels, Phillips discovered that the Barbie-inspired outfits made everyone smile, opened doors for her, and turned her into a temporary social media sensation, though she admits the obvious, Instagram-perfect aesthetic fits perfectly with today's filtered existence. Despite some awkward moments that made her feel like "Insanity Barbie," Phillips concluded that Scott's whimsical collection proves life is too short to wear boring clothes.

Chelsea are planning a victory parade through the streets around Stamford Bridge for May 25 if they win the Premier League title, with the team currently nine points clear at the top with six games remaining. A letter from Hammersmith and Fulham council has been delivered to local residents outlining the planned victory parade route, which would start at Stamford Bridge and travel along Fulham Road before ending at Eel Brook Common around 1pm. The parade is contingent on Chelsea winning the Premier League, with Jose Mourinho's side facing Arsenal at the Emirates on Sunday as they look to secure their first title since 2010.

Jack Henry Doshay, 22, the son of a prominent San Diego businessman, was arrested last week for allegedly attempting to kidnap a 7-year-old girl from Skyline Elementary School in Solana Beach. Doshay appeared in court on Friday and pleaded not guilty to charges of kidnapping, false imprisonment with violence, and child cruelty, while his parents were notably absent from the courtroom. He was allegedly arrested at a residential facility where he was receiving treatment for depression, and if convicted, faces up to 11 years in prison.

Sri Lanka's sports minister Navin Dissanayake has humbly requested that Kumar Sangakkara reconsider his retirement from limited overs cricket and continue playing for another year, following Sri Lanka's disappointing quarter-final defeat at the Cricket World Cup. Sangakkara, who scored four successive centuries and finished with 541 runs in his last World Cup tournament, bid farewell to one-day cricket on March 18 after the loss to South Africa. The sports minister believes Sangakkara might change his mind now that former test cricketer Sidath Wettimuny has been appointed to head a new interim body to run the sport.

Nicola Sturgeon declared that raising the retirement age is unfair to Scottish pensioners because they die younger than those in other parts of the UK, with the SNP demanding the retirement age be frozen in a move that would cost billions of pounds. Miss Sturgeon also called for the flat rate pension to increase from £113 to at least £160 per week, arguing that Scotland's lower life expectancy (about 76 years for men and 80 for women) means Scottish pensioners lose out compared to England and Wales where life expectancy is nearly 79 for men and 83 for women. The SNP positioned these demands as potential conditions for supporting a Labour government in the event of a hung Parliament.

Kentucky Judge Olu Stevens is facing calls to be removed from the bench after he criticized a couple's victim impact statements during the sentencing of Gregory Wallace, who robbed their home at gunpoint in front of their 3-year-old daughter. The couple stated in their victim impact statements that their daughter now lives in "constant fear of black men" and called for Wallace to be sent to prison, but Judge Stevens accused the parents of fostering racist stereotypes in their child and granted Wallace five years' probation instead. Stevens defended his decision, saying Wallace deserved the opportunity to redeem himself due to his lack of prior violent convictions, while maintaining that the victim impact statements were offensive and played no role in his sentencing decision.

Mysterious cardboard signs with apologetic love messages like "please forgive me" and "I love you" have appeared throughout the affluent Surrey village of Milford, sparking speculation across the community about the author's identity and the reason behind this contrite gesture. While most people say sorry with flowers or romantic dinners, this lovelorn individual chose a public declaration of love written in black marker pen on lampposts and street signs. The article notes this isn't the first time someone has taken to the streets to apologize, referencing a similar incident in Manchester where a man wore a sandwich board saying he was exceedingly sorry.

Five Chinese feminists have been detained by police for over a month facing charges of "picking quarrels and provoking trouble" after they were arrested while preparing to distribute leaflets about sexual harassment on public transport before International Women's Day. The women face up to five years in jail if formally charged, with their case highlighting China's tight controls on political activists under President Xi Jinping's administration. The detention has prompted international condemnation, including from U.S. Vice President Joe Biden and Secretary of State John Kerry, leading China to lodge a formal protest with Washington over what it considers interference in its internal affairs.

More than 10,000 Australians and New Zealanders gathered at Turkey's Gallipoli peninsula for a dawn service marking the 100th anniversary of the bloody Gallipoli landings on April 25, 2015. The ceremony honored the soldiers who fought and died during the eight-month World War I Gallipoli campaign that began on April 25, 1915, with political leaders including Australian PM Tony Abbott, New Zealand PM John Key, and British royals Prince Charles and Prince Harry in attendance. The commemorative service remembered the approximately 130,000 men who died during the campaign, including thousands of Australian and New Zealand troops who became known as the Anzacs.

Fernando Torres scored his first ever league own goal during Atletico Madrid's 2-2 La Liga draw against Malaga on Saturday, inadvertently heading a corner into his own net to pull Malaga level just before half-time. Antoine Griezmann scored twice for Atletico to help salvage the draw, while Torres continues to struggle for goals since his January return, having scored just four times for the club. The result keeps Atletico in third place in La Liga.

Danny Lennon's interim appointment as Scotland Under 21 coach has officially ended after he led the team to a 2-1 victory against Hungary last month. Reports indicate that Lennon will be named as Alloa Athletic boss on Tuesday, having agreed to a deal with the Scottish Championship club until summer 2016. The Scottish FA thanked Lennon for his professionalism during his short-term role and wished him success in his next challenge at club level.

The wreckage of a bus and train used to film the famous crash scene in the 1993 movie "The Fugitive" lie abandoned in the Great Smokey Mountains in North Carolina, where Harrison Ford's character escaped from a prison transport moments before it collided with an oncoming train. Director Andrew Davis used 13 cameras to film the $1.5 million action sequence, with three cameras destroyed in the process, creating one of the most memorable Hollywood action scenes using real vehicles with minimal CGI. The trashed prison bus and train have since become a popular tourist attraction over 20 years after filming.

Greg Gibbins, a 28-year-old rugby league player, died after suffering a fatal knife attack outside a pizza store on Easter Monday, going into cardiac arrest after being seriously stabbed in what police described as an unprovoked attack. A 25-year-old friend who tried to help also suffered stab wounds during the confrontation, while a 20-year-old man has been charged with murder in connection to the incident. Police believe the attack may have been related to an earlier incident where Gibbins had helped a woman who was being harassed, with friends and family paying tribute to the victim as a "top bloke" on social media.

A new Reddit thread asked users who purchased mail-order brides from Russia and the Philippines to share what surprised them most when they started living with their spouses. The discussion, which garnered over 10,000 comments, revealed that many men ordered these foreign brides because they struggled socially, with costs ranging from $10,000 to $50,000. Users reported mixed experiences regarding sexuality and relationships, with some noting their brides would "offer sex" and perform household duties but lacked emotional connection, while others found their partners more open about sexuality compared to typical relationships.

Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart described Sunday's 4-2 derby defeat to Manchester United at Old Trafford as "one of my worst days in a Manchester City shirt," effectively ending City's bid to retain their Premier League title. The loss left City four points behind rivals United and 12 points behind league leaders Chelsea, with Hart acknowledging that his team was outplayed after taking an early lead before United's Ashley Young and others scored to secure the victory. Hart expressed frustration at his team's poor form since the new year and admitted he was at a loss to explain why City has struggled, taking only 18 points from a possible 39 in recent matches.

Northern Territory mother and labourer Noeleen Foster spotted a phallic-shaped cloud during her work break last week in Zuccoli, 25km southeast of Darwin, and was shocked to capture the suggestively shaped formation. Ms Foster, who loves photographing clouds, said she couldn't believe her eyes when she saw the X-rated cloud and noted that even mother nature has a sense of humor. This isn't the first famous phallic cloud to make headlines, as a similar naughty cloud was captured by a nature photographer in Derbyshire, England last year.

Loren Mathieson filmed her pet Boston Terrier, Gizmo, performing a gravity-defying paw-stand walking stunt at home after he put on new booties. The footage shows Gizmo taking steps forward before planting his front feet and launching his back legs vertically in the air, walking on his front paws until he reaches the laughing Mathieson and eventually steps back down to four paws. Mathieson said Gizmo performed the circus-like trick because he was unsure how to walk in his new boots, and the video has been viewed over 80,000 times.

Porto, the only undefeated team in the Champions League this season, will face Bayern Munich in their quarter-final first leg at Dragao on Wednesday, with Porto manager Julen Lopetegui set to clash with his former Barcelona teammate Pep Guardiola. Despite Porto's impressive defensive record and unbeaten run, Lopetegui warns that his team still has room for improvement as they continue to integrate new players from the summer. Both teams enter the match as the tournament's most prolific scoring sides, with Porto having scored 24 goals while conceding only 5 in their Champions League campaign.

Nine-year-old Frankie Franz, a talented young centre midfielder and academy player with Dagenham and Redbridge Football Club, successfully emulated Barcelona star Martin Montoya by scoring an audacious 27-yard goal into a basketball hoop after watching the Spanish defender pull off the same trick shot in a video recorded at Barcelona's training ground. The schoolboy amazingly netted the difficult shot on his first attempt and reportedly succeeded again immediately after, leaving his family stunned by his achievement. Frankie dreams of one day turning out for Real Madrid or Barcelona, following in the footsteps of players like Montoya who inspired his remarkable feat.

Financially-troubled CSKA Sofia's Latvian goalkeeper Maksims Uvarenko has not been paid for three months since joining the Bulgarian club in January, forcing him to ask his parents to send money to pay his rent. Despite the lack of salary and financial hardships, Uvarenko praised the CSKA fans as "unique" and expressed being impressed by their passionate support. The debt-ridden club has issued desperate pleas to fans for emergency financial backing to avoid expulsion from Bulgaria's top division.

Pete Bennett, who won Big Brother in 2006 at age 24, revealed on the Jeremy Kyle show that he squandered his £100,000 prize money on ketamine and is now homeless. The article provides an overview of what happened to all Big Brother winners from the first series through season 15, showing how fame can make or break contestants' careers and lives. Winners' post-show paths varied dramatically, from Builder Craig Phillips who became a successful property developer, to transgender chef Luke who found happiness and career success, while others like Pete Bennett struggled with addiction and homelessness.

Crisis-hit Parma pulled off a major upset by defeating Serie A leaders Juventus 1-0, with Jose Mauri scoring the decisive goal on the hour mark. Despite being declared bankrupt last month and sitting in last place, Parma's goalkeeper Antonio Mirante made crucial saves to help secure the victory against Juventus, who had rested several key players ahead of their Champions League quarter-final. The result inflicted only Juventus' second league defeat of the season, though they maintain a commanding 14-point lead at the top of Serie A.

Photographer Simon Brann Thorpe created the "Toy Soldiers" project in Western Sahara's desert, posing real soldiers from the Polisario Front independence movement as green plastic figurines to create a fresh perspective on how we consume images of war. Thorpe worked with 50-60 soldiers at a time in the harsh desert conditions, positioning them on platforms made from oil drums at historic battle locations between Morocco and the Polisario Front. Through this elaborate five-week production, Thorpe hopes to raise awareness about the Western Sahara conflict, which receives virtually zero media coverage despite 2015 marking the 40th anniversary of the war's outbreak, and to question how images of war will be consumed in the future.

A shocking incident occurred in Bhiwandi, a suburb of Mumbai, where a seven-year-old boy was raped and set on fire by two youths when he went to buy food. The boy suffered 30 per cent burns to his body but managed to escape, and is currently being treated at Thane Civil hospital. Police have registered a case under sections including attempt to murder and sodomy, and are working to identify and catch the accused in this incident that is being investigated.

Jurgen Klopp confirmed at an emotional press conference that he will leave Borussia Dortmund at the end of the season after seven years in charge, stating that "Borussia Dortmund actually needs a change" and that the team deserves a coach who is "absolutely one hundred per cent right" for them. Klopp's departure has put England's top Premier League clubs on alert, with Manchester City, Liverpool, and Arsenal among those potentially interested, though Klopp insisted he has had no contact with other clubs but is open to offers. The highly-rated German manager, who won two Bundesliga titles and led Dortmund to the 2013 Champions League final, made the announcement following a difficult season where Dortmund struggled near the bottom of the table.

Sean McCabe, a 30-year-old father-of-three from Wales, was diagnosed with stage four Hodgkin Lymphoma and told he had just two months to live, prompting him to plan his own funeral at St David's Church and write goodbye letters to his children. In an extraordinary turn of events, his cancer went into remission, and he has now rebooked the same church for his wedding to his fiancée Lisa Williams. The couple, who have been together for 12 years and have three children together, are set to marry in July 2015, transforming what could have been a tragic ending into a celebration of life and love.

An eight-year-old boy died a day after his family's car plunged into Los Angeles harbor in San Pedro, while his 13-year-old brother was pulled dead from the water at the scene. Their parents survived and are in stable condition at the hospital after the vehicle driven by the father veered off the edge and landed upside down in 30-foot water. Firefighter Miguel Meza has been hailed as a hero for jumping into the murky water to help with rescue efforts, though the cause of the incident remains unknown and is under investigation.

Qatar's investment arm Constellation Hotels has strengthened the Gulf state's grip on London's real estate by purchasing a 64 percent stake in hotel company Coroin, which owns iconic luxury hotels including Claridge's, The Berkeley, and The Connaught, in a deal reportedly worth up to £1.6 billion. This acquisition adds to Qatar's impressive property portfolio in London, which already includes landmark buildings such as The Shard, Harrods, Canary Wharf, and the London Stock Exchange through various Qatari investment entities including Qatar Holding and Qatari Diar Real Estate Investment. The Qatari royal family has also been expanding their London presence, converting three properties in Regent's Park into what will become the UK's first £200 million residential palace.

Three children - one-year-old Bol and four-year-old twins Madit and Anger - died when their Sudanese mother, 35-year-old Akon Guode, crashed a Toyota Kluger into a lake at Wyndham Vale in Melbourne's outer west on Wednesday afternoon. The children's mother was released from police custody after being interviewed as part of the homicide investigation, while a fifth child, five-year-old Awel, survived the crash and remains in serious condition at Royal Children's Hospital. The children's father has defended the mother, calling her a "good mother" and saying he believes she is innocent, while police continue investigating whether the incident was deliberate or accidental.

Scientists at MIT claim that the common computer keyboard could be a powerful new tool in battling Parkinson's disease, as researchers believe a person's keystrokes may reveal a huge amount of information about their motor skills. The team has developed an algorithm that analyzes "key hold time" to detect early Parkinson's disease with promising results from preliminary studies of about two dozen patients, potentially allowing diagnosis years earlier than current methods. This approach could also be applied to other diseases producing motor impairments, with researchers now working on smartphone apps to gather similar data from mobile devices.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers held a press conference to preview Saturday's match against Arsenal, but the focus shifted to Raheem Sterling's contract situation after the 20-year-old gave an unauthorized BBC interview stating he wasn't ready to sign a new £100,000-a-week deal with Liverpool. Rodgers insisted that Sterling "is not going anywhere in the summer" and emphasized that Liverpool is "one of the superpowers of football" that doesn't need to sell its best players, while acknowledging the interview surprised the club as it was conducted without permission. The manager remained "relaxed" about the contract talks, stating that Sterling has two and a half years left on his current deal and that the focus should remain purely on football.

Stoke City manager Mark Hughes has dismissed reports linking goalkeeper Asmir Begovic with a summer move to Spanish giants Real Madrid, stating he would "take that one with a pinch of salt." Hughes remains optimistic that the Bosnia international, who has been one of the Premier League's most consistent keepers, will sign a new contract with the 10th-placed Potters this summer, with talks scheduled in the coming weeks. The manager is also hopeful Stoke will complete the signing of teenage Barcelona winger Moha El Ouriachi, adding to their recent acquisitions of Bojan Krkic and Marc Muniesa from the Catalan club.

Aston Villa defeated Tottenham 1-0 in a crucial Premier League encounter, with Christian Benteke scoring the winning goal with a header in the 35th minute to continue his excellent form. Villa manager Tim Sherwood celebrated emphatically against his former club, as the victory gave Villa a significant boost in their fight for Premier League survival while effectively ending Tottenham's Champions League hopes. Despite Tottenham's efforts in the second half, led by striker Harry Kane, Villa's defense held firm with goalkeeper Brad Guzan and the backline protecting their lead, though they finished with 10 men after Carlos Sanchez was sent off late in the match.

Gerard T. "The Frenchman" Ouimette, a 75-year-old former mob enforcer with ties to New England crime boss Raymond Patriarca, died Sunday in a federal prison in North Carolina after being diagnosed with lung cancer. Ouimette was convicted of extortion in 1996 and sentenced to life in prison without parole under the federal "three strikes" law, having controlled a criminal network responsible for gambling, loansharking, extortion, and murder. According to his nephew Kevin Ouimette Lynch, Ouimette spent a total of 46 years behind bars and died in his sleep at the medium-security facility in Butner, North Carolina.

Danny Cipriani is taking a short break in Dubai after helping Sale Sharks to a 23-6 victory against Gloucester, where he contributed 13 points from the boot. With Sale currently seventh in the Aviva Premiership standings, Steve Diamond's side will face four crucial final games against London Irish, Harlequins, Newcastle and Exeter as they look to secure a top-six finish and qualification for next season's European Champions Cup. Cipriani has been integral to Sale's improved form this season and was rewarded with a call-up to England's 6 Nations squad, making impressive cameos from the bench and scoring a try against Italy.

Owen Farrell, the Saracens and England international fly-half, hopes to return for Saracens' European Champions Cup semi-final against Clermont Auvergne on April 18 after being sidelined since suffering a knee ligament injury against the same opponents in January. Farrell missed the entire RBS 6 Nations tournament due to the injury, but reports his knee is feeling good after completing full training including running, kicking, and tackling. A final decision on his fitness will be made after this week's training sessions.

North Charleston Police Officer Michael Slager, 33, is being held in isolation at Charleston County jail after being charged with murder for shooting 50-year-old Walter Scott during a traffic stop over a broken tail light on Saturday in South Carolina. Court records reveal that while Scott was $7,500 behind on child support payments and had been jailed three times previously for missed payments, there was no active warrant for his arrest when he fled from Officer Slager during the stop. The incident was captured on video showing Slager shooting Scott in the back as he ran away, contradicting the officer's initial account of the events.

Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino has expressed confidence that goalkeeper Michel Vorm can overcome his Capital One Cup final disappointment and effectively deputize for the injured Hugo Lloris when Spurs face Burnley on Sunday. France international Lloris is sidelined with a knee injury sustained during Tottenham's 4-3 victory over Leicester, meaning Dutchman Vorm will step in despite being left out of the League Cup final against Chelsea last month. Pochettino praised Vorm's professionalism and attitude, noting that Tottenham head into the match in good form having lost just once in their last four Premier League games.

Uber customer Jaime Hessel was hit with a shocking $16,000 bill for a 35-minute, 7-mile car ride from her East Williamsburg apartment to Midtown East, during which the UberX driver was distracted by phone calls, cut across traffic lanes, and drove in a bus lane. After Hessel immediately emailed Uber Support to complain about the original $56.40 charge and poor service, the cab-hailing app sent her a bizarre follow-up message stating she owed over $16,000, though Uber later said this was a clerical error and she was never actually charged the outrageous sum.

A cloud formation resembling the global Wi-Fi symbol appeared in the sky over Xiangtan city in Hunan Province, central China last week, prompting jokes about the world's largest "Wi-Fi cloud." The unusual cloud was spotted by a student from Hunan University of Science and Technology, and photos of what appeared to be nature's giant Wi-Fi symbol went viral on Chinese social media. This is not the first time China has witnessed strange cloud formations, as the country has previously seen UFO-shaped clouds and other unusual atmospheric phenomena in various provinces.

Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere met Brazil legend Pele at the launch party of 10Ten Talent, where he had the opportunity to interview the three-time World Cup winner who scored 77 goals in 92 games for Brazil. Pele described Brazil's performance at the 2014 World Cup as a "disaster," particularly their humiliating 7-1 semi-final defeat to Germany, calling it something "only God can explain." However, Pele praised how Brazil's Premier League players like Oscar and Ramires have bounced back this season, showing no ill-effects from the World Cup disappointment.

Italy is dealing with a surge of desperate migrants crossing the Mediterranean Sea, with the Italian coast guard rescuing 8,480 migrants from Friday to Monday and receiving SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. Save the Children fears that 400 migrants could be missing after survivors reported that a ship carrying 550 people capsized about 80 miles off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not yet found evidence to confirm this particular boat capsized. Italy has registered more than 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015, with at least 480 migrants dying while crossing the Mediterranean due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.

Saracens flanker Jacques Burger has been cited for alleged foul play during last Sunday's European Champions Cup quarter-final victory over Racing Metro, with European Professional Club Rugby alleging that the Namibia international struck Racing scrum-half Maxime Machenaud midway through the match. Burger will face a disciplinary hearing on Thursday with Welshman Simon Thomas as the independent judicial officer, potentially facing a ban ranging from two weeks to 52 weeks. Despite the citation, Saracens advanced to the Champions Cup semi-finals with their 12-11 victory and will face Clermont Auvergne next.

Chile's Calbuco Volcano erupted for the third time since last week on Thursday, prompting the evacuation of about 1,500 people and maintaining a 20-kilometer exclusion zone around the crater. The latest eruption was described as spectacular but less severe than the previous two eruptions on April 22 and 23, which spread ash to Argentina and blanketed the region with volcanic debris up to 2 feet deep in some areas. New advisories warn that airborne ash could reach altitudes of 12,000 feet, adding to concerns about contamination and safety in the popular tourist region of southern Chile.

Six people - five men and one woman - were arrested at Dover port on suspicion of Syria-related terrorism offences, according to West Midlands Police. Four of the men in their 20s are from Birmingham, while a 26-year-old man and 23-year-old woman of no fixed abode were also detained and are currently being questioned at a West Midlands police station. The arrests come amid ongoing investigations and searches at Birmingham addresses, occurring just a day after nine Britons were detained in Turkey for allegedly attempting to cross into Syria.

Philadelphia Union secured their first Major League Soccer victory of the season with a dramatic 2-1 win over New York City FC, thanks to Vincent Nogueira's stoppage-time goal after NYC goalkeeper Josh Saunders collided with a player in the box. Former Spain international David Villa had equalized for City with a classy goal, tapping in a rebound in the 55th minute. In other MLS action, Houston Dynamo broke their scoring drought with a convincing 3-0 victory over Montreal Impact, with Giles Barnes opening the scoring from a Brad Davis free kick.

Charmain Adusah, a 41-year-old pregnant British woman, was found dead face down in a hotel bathtub in Ghana by hotel staff after lying there for four days. Her husband, Eric Isaiah Adusah, a 28-year-old evangelical preacher whom she married last September following a whirlwind romance, is being held on suspicion of murdering her after allegedly leaving the hotel hurriedly on the day she is believed to have died. Mr Adusah had told hotel managers his wife was ill and didn't want to be disturbed before reportedly flying back to London, only to return to Ghana after her body was discovered.

Ethan Czahor, a former aide to Jeb Bush who was fired after his offensive old tweets became public, has launched an app called "Clear" that helps users identify and delete social media posts that might cause problems with employers. The app uses IBM's Watson supercomputer to analyze tweets and gives users a safety rating between 0-100, while researchers have developed algorithms that can identify potential trolls in 80% of cases by analyzing posting patterns and language use. Last year Twitter made it easier to search through years of old tweets, making such embarrassing posts more discoverable and highlighting the need for tools like Clear to help users manage their digital footprints.

Justin Rose finished second at the Masters with a 14-under-par total that ranks among the six best scores in Masters history, helping to kickstart his season after struggling in previous tournaments. Rose wants to follow Rory McIlroy's example from last year, when McIlroy had a dominant summer winning streak, and hopes to use this momentum for the big tournaments ahead from April to September. Despite starting the final round four shots behind eventual winner Jordan Spieth and never getting closer than three shots, Rose gained confidence from his performance and expressed hunger to return to contention soon.

An unidentified college student at the Texas-based country music festival Chilifest avoided punishment for underage drinking after beating three police officers in a game of Rock Paper Scissors. The incident, captured on Vine and viewed over 500,000 times, shows the student winning with "rock" against an officer's "scissors" choice, prompting cheers from onlookers and allowing her to walk away without a ticket. The video has gone viral across social media platforms, with many expressing surprise at the officers' leniency given that police at Chilifest are typically known for strictly enforcing underage drinking violations.

Victoria Police are searching for 14-year-old Sally Gordon-Smith, who went missing after last being seen leaving her school in Keilor East around 3pm on Friday afternoon. Police confirmed she was still missing early Saturday morning and expressed concern due to her young age. Authorities have described her as caucasian with brown shoulder-length hair and have appealed for anyone who has seen Ms Gordon-Smith to contact them immediately.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew has denied interest in signing goalkeeper Tim Krul from his former club Newcastle, expressing disappointment about transfer rumors linking him to raiding his old team. Pardew insists he is happy with current Palace goalkeeper Julian Speroni and has had no contact with Newcastle, Krul, or his representatives about a potential transfer. The manager emphasized his satisfaction with his current squad while acknowledging Palace's plans for summer transfer activity.

British photographer John Daniels, 61, from Surrey, has captured adorable studio photographs of puppies and other young animals for a picture-perfect photo shoot to celebrate National Pet Day. The experienced animal photographer uses clean white backgrounds and comedy props to create heart-warming images, including unusual animal pairings like puppies with ducks and kittens, with subjects ranging from four fluffy dogs lined up in crates to tiny pups posing in teacups. Daniels prefers studio work over outdoor shoots to prevent little animals from escaping or becoming frightened, and notes that many animals come back for multiple sessions as they seem to remember what to do.

Hilary Border, 54, stole £20,000 from her 83-year-old dementia-stricken mother Dorothy while serving as her power of attorney, using the money for herself instead of paying care home fees. Care home staff tried to contact Border over an outstanding £16,000 debt before reporting her to police when payments became late or stopped entirely. Border was sentenced to 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, and spared jail despite the judge calling her actions "wicked" for betraying her vulnerable mother's trust.

David Suchet, best known for playing Poirot, is fighting for better NHS treatment for his grandson Todd, who was diagnosed with the rare genetic illness Tuberous Sclerosis Complex shortly after birth. The actor criticizes NHS "disorganization" for preventing access to available drugs that could help manage his grandson's incurable condition, which can cause tumors, epilepsy, and learning difficulties. Suchet has launched the #Fight4Treatment campaign to advocate for better access to rare disease medications through the NHS.

Yorkshire have signed India international batsman Cheteshwar Pujara until the end of May after cancelling the contract of Younis Khan, who was originally set to be Yorkshire's overseas signing for 2015 but chose to pursue Pakistan international commitments instead. Yorkshire director of cricket Martyn Moxon announced the signing of Pujara, who previously scored 219 championship runs for Derbyshire and will play until Australian Aaron Finch is free from Indian Premier League commitments. The 27-year-old Indian Test cricketer expressed excitement about joining Yorkshire and wearing the same white rose that Sachin Tendulkar once did.

US Army Staff Sgt Julian McDonald of Columbus, Ohio, has adopted 4-year-old Layka, a Belgian Malinois military dog who saved his life during their eighth overseas tour in Afghanistan in 2012. Layka was shot four times at point-blank range by a Taliban fighter with an AK-47 and required emergency surgery that resulted in the amputation of her front leg, but she completed the mission and helped save McDonald's team. After fighting for two years to adopt her, McDonald welcomed Layka into his Ohio home where she has adapted well to civilian life and become best friends with his son Liam.

For years medical experts have warned about the dangers of excess salt consumption, with current dietary guidelines recommending Americans limit intake to 2,300 milligrams per day, but new research is now questioning this conventional wisdom and warning instead about the dangers of too little salt. Scientists are saying that the average American salt consumption rate of about 3,500 milligrams per day carries no significant risk, with some arguing that healthy people can safely consume up to 6,000 milligrams daily while consumption below 3,000 milligrams may actually raise health risks. This new research challenges the long-held belief that excess salt contributes to tens of thousands of American deaths each year, creating disagreement even within organizations like the American Heart Association about whether current salt guidelines are valid.

A DEA report released by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform revealed that several DEA agents were taking part in alleged sex parties with prostitutes funded by drug cartels in Colombia starting as early as 2001, with lawmakers stating there were "literally dozens of parties." A separate Justice Department report found that at least 7 of 10 agents admitted to sleeping with prostitutes on overseas assignments between 2005-2008, leading to suspensions of 2-10 days, while investigators found a wide range of sex-related offenses across multiple agencies including the FBI, DEA, ATF and US Marshals Service. During a congressional hearing, lawmakers grilled DEA Administrator Michele Leonhart over the misconduct, with officials calling the allegations "stunning" and emphasizing the significant security risks posed by such behavior.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy named Burt Hazeltine was shot three times while directing school buses on US 90 near Louisiana Street in Paradis, just west of New Orleans, after refusing to stop traffic to allow 56-year-old Paul Devillier to make a turn. The shooting occurred when Devillier returned to confront Hazeltine and opened fire after the deputy spotted a gun on his dashboard, hitting him in the face, elbow, and eye. Hazeltine was transported to Interim LSU Hospital Thursday afternoon in stable but guarded condition, while Devillier was arrested shortly after the incident.

Lord Janner, a suspected paedophile and peer, signed a letter on April 9 requesting to remain in the House of Lords just a week before being ruled unfit to face 22 child sex charges due to Alzheimer's disease. Director of Public Prosecutions Alison Saunders announced that Janner would escape prosecution despite sufficient evidence, sparking outrage from abuse campaigners who question how he can be deemed fit to remain a legislator but unfit for trial. The controversy deepens as Janner's alleged victims, who accused him of abusing boys at care homes, and child abuse experts argue this appears to be an establishment cover-up.

Turkey has blocked access to Twitter and YouTube after the platforms refused a court request to remove pictures of prosecutor Mehmet Selim Kiraz, who was held hostage during a deadly armed siege last week by members of the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C). The 46-year-old prosecutor died in hospital after the six-hour standoff ended with security forces storming the courthouse, during which his two captors were also killed. Turkish authorities imposed the social media blocks because the images of the siege were being widely shared and had "deeply upset" the prosecutor's wife and children.

David and Victoria Beckham have won a planning battle against their neighbor over proposals to install air-conditioning in five rooms of their £31.5 million west London mansion, including a luxury gym and wine cellar. Despite one neighbor's objections about potential noise and impact on the historic Victorian character, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council approved the plans, stating the air-conditioning would have minimal impact on the Grade II listed building. The couple purchased the Holland Park property in 2013 and are restoring it to become their main UK residence, with estate agents estimating the completed property could be worth up to £42 million.

California Governor Jerry Brown ordered a 25 percent overall cutback in water use by cities and towns on Wednesday as the state and its nearly 40 million residents face a fourth summer of drought with no relief in sight. The crackdown comes as photos show the ongoing drought has already taken its toll on California's once lush landscape of green yards, golf courses, and swimming pools, with state reservoirs containing only a year's worth of water and wells in some areas going dry due to falling groundwater levels. The mandatory restrictions target urban water usage after previous voluntary conservation efforts achieved only half of the requested 20 percent reduction.

Universal's "Furious 7," the final film featuring the late Paul Walker, is expected to make box office history with a projected $115 million opening weekend at the North American box office, which would mark the top April opening domestically of all time. The movie is getting the widest release in Universal's history across roughly 4,003 theaters and is opening day-and-date globally on 10,500 screens, with CGI and voice effects used in scenes featuring Walker's detective character after his death, with his brothers Caleb and Cody serving as stand-ins. If successful, it could achieve the largest three-day opening since "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" in 2013, surpassing the current April record held by "Captain America: The Winter Soldier."

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas continued his poor second-half-of-season form during Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland on Tuesday, where he captained his country but struggled to make an impact. After a brilliant start to the season that saw him collect 15 Premier League assists by mid-January and appear set to break Thierry Henry's record of 20, Fabregas has managed just one assist in his last five games, raising concerns about his durability. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping for a late-season resurgence from his key midfielder as the Blues look to secure the Premier League title in their remaining nine games.

Victims of a horrific U.S. medical experiment conducted in Guatemala from 1945-1956 are suing Johns Hopkins University for $1 billion, claiming the university approved and helped plan a study that deliberately infected approximately 700 people with syphilis to test drugs and study the disease. The victims, who included orphans, soldiers, prisoners, and mental patients, were unknowingly infected by doctors, with some individuals dying from syphilis and others passing the disease to their children who were born with severe disabilities including blindness and brain defects. The experiment was run by Dr. John Cutler, who also conducted the infamous Tuskegee syphilis experiment, and was only acknowledged by the U.S. government in 2010, leading to this lawsuit after a previous suit against the government was dismissed on legal technicalities.

Hip-hop star Nelly was arrested on drug charges in Tennessee after a state trooper stopped his private bus on Interstate 40 for missing transportation stickers and noticed the odor of marijuana emitting from the vehicle. During the search of the bus carrying Nelly and five other passengers, troopers found methamphetamine, marijuana, drug paraphernalia, several handguns, and small bags commonly used for drug sales. The 40-year-old rapper was charged with felony drug possession, simple marijuana possession, and possession of drug paraphernalia before posting bond and being released from jail.

A Japanese woman got sweet revenge on her cheating boyfriend by submerging his entire Apple collection, including an iMac (which starts at £899), iPhone, iPad, and accessories, in a bathtub full of water. The woman scorned took photos of the soaked gadgets and sent them to her unfaithful partner, ensuring total water damage that would be irreversible. When the man posted the images on Twitter, the story went viral with over 15,400 retweets, generating mixed reactions but mostly support for the woman's creative form of revenge.

Jurgen Klopp conceded that Bayern Munich deserved their 1-0 victory over his Borussia Dortmund side, with Robert Lewandowski scoring the decisive goal against his former club. The charismatic Dortmund manager admitted his side lacked punch in the final third and that Bayern were better in crucial moments, though Dortmund captain Mats Hummels disagreed with his coach's assessment. The victory extended Bayern's lead at the top of the Bundesliga table to 10 points.

President Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Jamaica since Ronald Reagan in 1982, where he was warmly received by crowds and Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller, who publicly declared her love for him. During his visit, Obama signaled that he would soon remove Cuba from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism, following a State Department recommendation, as he prepared for a historic meeting with Cuban President Raul Castro at the Summit of the Americas in Panama. Secretary of State John Kerry also met with Cuban Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez for lengthy discussions, marking significant progress in U.S.-Cuba diplomatic relations after more than 50 years of estrangement.

Pope Francis reminded the world of the Vatican's status as a state and his role as a moral diplomat during his traditional Easter Mass address, where the Pontiff lamented the suffering of people in conflicts currently making headlines around the world. He called for peace and asked that humanitarian aid get to those in need, specifically mentioning Iraq, Syria, the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, Libya, Iran, Yemen, Nigeria, South Sudan, Kenya, and Ukraine. The Pope also addressed economic oppression and ended his "urbi et orbi" speech by consoling the marginalized and wishing everyone a happy Easter.

Russian supermodel Irina Shayk, 29, stars in Linda Farrow eyewear's Spring Summer 15 campaign alongside male model Jarrod Scott in a steamy video shot around an LA pool. The behind-the-scenes film shows Irina emerging from water in plunging metallic swimsuits while modeling various sunglasses styles, including standout gold plated round frame specs that retail for $1,105. The campaign, titled "Wanderlust," features the newly single model (who recently split from Cristiano Ronaldo) and Scott in intimate poolside scenes showcasing the luxury eyewear collection's metallic and liquid gold styles.

Polish prince Janek Zylinski, son of a Polish war hero who fought the Nazis in 1939, has challenged Ukip leader Nigel Farage to a sword fight over his attacks on immigration. Zylinski posted the challenge online after declaring he had "had enough" of Farage's discrimination against Polish people, specifically citing Farage blaming migrants for traffic jams on the M40. The prince brandished his sword in a video and suggested they meet in Hyde Park to resolve the matter, though he also offered an alternative "duel of words" if Farage's sword skills were rusty.

The Calbuco volcano in southern Chile erupted unexpectedly for the first time in over four decades, forcing the evacuation of 4,000 people and covering nearby towns in thick ash despite being over 18 miles away from the volcano. The two spectacular eruptions shot ash more than six miles into the atmosphere, with experts warning that equally violent eruptions at Calbuco have historically continued for up to a week. Calbuco is one of Chile's 90 active volcanoes and is considered among the most dangerous, with its last major eruption occurring in 1961.

Barcelona defender Dani Alves, whose contract runs out on June 30, is in a contract dispute with the club as they want to keep him beyond this season due to their transfer ban, but only on reduced terms with a complex deal structure. Manchester United has reportedly offered him a straightforward three-year deal, presenting the possibility of a Premier League swansong, though Alves remains hopeful Barcelona will make him an improved offer to stay at the Nou Camp where he has won multiple titles including two Champions League trophies. Barcelona would be foolish to let the successful right-back leave given their lack of adequate replacement options and transfer restrictions.

Kate Temple, a 33-year-old hairdresser, was sentenced to 20 months in prison after she admitted to inflicting grievous bodily harm by biting off a chunk of victim Shelley Williams' ear with her teeth during a fight at a charity hog roast event. The attack occurred after Williams accused Temple of having an affair with her partner and threw a drink over her, leaving Williams covered in blood and requiring reconstructive surgery. Temple initially denied the attack to police and was refused service at the bar after the incident, but later pleaded guilty to the charges.

Jenson Button believes McLaren has made significant progress and now has their rivals in sight ahead of the Chinese Grand Prix, after showing improved competitiveness in Malaysia despite both he and teammate Fernando Alonso retiring from that race. The British driver is optimistic about McLaren's ability to fight with midfield teams like Force India, Sauber, and Lotus, though he acknowledges the team still has work to do on both downforce and the Honda power unit. Button notes that while high temperatures in Malaysia suited their car, the cooler conditions expected in Shanghai could present new challenges for tire temperature generation.

Claudia Martins, a 33-year-old Portuguese woman, has been convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility for killing her newborn baby daughter after giving birth alone at her sister's flat in Bristol, having kept her pregnancy secret from family and friends. Martins suffocated the infant by stuffing toilet paper down her throat, then hid the body in a suitcase for three days until police discovered it following a smell complaint. While she was acquitted of murder charges, the jury convicted her of manslaughter after hearing evidence that she deliberately killed the baby despite her claims that the child was stillborn.

AP McCoy will ride Paul Nicholls-trained Mr Mole in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, with the horse installed as one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner field. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, as he previously shocked the racing world by announcing his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February. Mr Mole faces competition from Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre in the prestigious race.

A woman who cannot swim nearly drowned in Cambridge's River Cam after falling from a punt when her boat hit another vessel, requiring rescue by friends and punt staff who pulled her to safety. The incident occurred during Britain's warmest day of the year so far, with temperatures reaching nearly 21°C, as families flocked to parks and beaches to enjoy the balmy Easter weather. Forecasters predict the unseasonably warm temperatures will continue throughout the week, with quiet weather expected and highs potentially reaching 21°C again by Friday.

Marlon Samuels' disciplined century (103) in the second Test against England exemplifies the character that new West Indies coach Phil Simmons is trying to instill in his team, as the batsman chose the challenging path of Test cricket over easier IPL opportunities. The article argues that while the recent Test matches may seem slow to some viewers, with England bowling 130 overs and matches extending to five days, this type of demanding Test cricket provides far greater satisfaction and mental challenges than shorter formats. The author believes West Indies, like England's team in 2000, must first learn to stay in games and take Tests into five days before they can progress to becoming a consistently winning side.

North Charleston police officer Michael Slager shot and killed Walter Scott, leaving him handcuffed on the ground with five bullet wounds to the back, while seven fellow officers responded to the scene. Despite police reports claiming officers administered CPR to Scott, bystander video evidence contradicts these accounts, showing officers only checking Scott's pulse and standing over his body, raising accusations that the shooting would have been covered up without the video footage. The incident has sparked allegations of a pattern of police cover-ups, with critics arguing that Slager's initial claims of self-defense during a Taser struggle were fabricated, as the video shows him placing the Taser near Scott's body after the shooting.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied suicide attempts after Italian media reported she tried to take her own life, instead stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was treated in hospital. Ms Moric posted photographs on her Instagram account showing heavy bruising on her arms, explaining she fell and hit her head during a domestic accident while her boyfriend was away in Naples. She reassured her 40,000+ followers that the suicide claims were incorrect and that she only needed rest to recover from her injuries.

Patrice Evra helped Juventus reach their first Champions League semi-final since 2002-03 after a 0-0 draw with Monaco at the Stade Louis II on Wednesday night, progressing 1-0 on aggregate from their quarter-final clash. The French defender described Juventus's defensive approach as playing "the Italian way - it's solid, it's ugly, but it works" while preventing Monaco players like Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from creating chances. Meanwhile, injury meant Paul Pogba sat out the Monaco clash, and Evra urged his compatriot not to rush his return from a hamstring injury that has sidelined him for 50 days.

A little girl was playfully beating her chest at gorillas through a glass enclosure at Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo in Nebraska when a massive silverback gorilla charged at the window and threw his entire weight against the pane, causing the glass to crack on impact. The terrified family fled to safety after the incident, which was captured on video and has received over 126,000 views on YouTube. Mountain gorillas can weigh up to 485 pounds, and Henry Doorley Zoo is famous for its gorilla breeding program, including producing the first gorilla test tube baby in 1995.

Classic FM presenter John Suchet is mourning the loss of his wife Bonnie, who died peacefully on April 15, 2015, at age 73 following a decade-long battle with dementia. Suchet, 71, had been open about his wife's condition since her 2006 diagnosis, becoming an advocate for dementia awareness and writing about their experience, while also caring for her until she was moved to residential care in 2010. The couple had a passionate relationship that began when they were both married to others and became neighbors, with Suchet describing Bonnie as "the love of my life" and their bond as "made in heaven."

Ben and Shelby Offrink, who met in a college study group in Michigan, are both battling aggressive cancers while raising two young daughters. Shelby was diagnosed with a rare spinal glioblastoma that left her paralyzed from the waist down after surgery removed 75% of the tumor, and the cancer has now spread to her brain with three inoperable tumors. Despite facing terminal diagnoses—six months for Shelby and a year for Ben, whose Hodgkin's lymphoma returned after 15 years—both refuse to give up and are seeking clinical trials and advanced treatment options to continue their fight for their family.

Spanish papers report that Real Madrid boss Carlo Ancelotti faces a "blessed problem" of fitting seven attacking stars into six positions in his preferred 4-3-3 formation, with James Rodriguez favored over Isco for the best starting line-up due to his superior stats (12 goals and 11 assists compared to Isco's five goals and six assists). Meanwhile, Italian media focuses on internal struggles at Inter Milan, while Juve boss Massimiliano Allegri prepares for the Coppa Italia semi-final. In France, L'Equipe celebrates PSG's pulsating 3-2 win over title rivals Marseille on Sunday as evidence of Ligue 1's improvement and competitiveness.

Floyd Mayweather took time out of his training session at the Mayweather Boxing Club to pose for a picture with Motown legend Gladys Knight, just four days before his highly anticipated "Fight of the Century" against rival Manny Pacquiao on May 2 at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. Knight posted the picture on Twitter, calling Mayweather "the champ," while Mayweather thanked her for coming to support him at the gym. The blockbuster fight is expected to earn Mayweather £120 million and is being called the biggest event in boxing history.

Ed Miliband has hired a leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind to help him overcome anxiety and improve his communication skills, as he has constantly lagged behind Prime Minister David Cameron in personal rating polls. The consultants claim to work with politicians using neuroscience and business psychology to build leadership skills, with services including coaching on looking "authentic" and building alliances that could help Mr Miliband prepare for potential post-election negotiations with leaders like SNP's Nicola Sturgeon. This comes despite Labour already employing former Obama adviser David Axelrod on a six-figure salary, with one Labour MP questioning the value of the expensive consulting arrangements.

Raymond Townsend, a married manager at US Limousine on Long Island, was found liable for sexual harassment after firing dispatcher Geralyn Ganci, 32, for refusing to have sex with him, even sending her a text explicitly stating she lost her job because she "refused to have sex with the General Manager." Townsend subjected Ganci to over a year of inappropriate sexual messages and advances, including texts describing masturbating while thinking about her and requests to come to his house when his wife was away. A federal court ordered Townsend and US Limousine to pay more than $700,000 in damages and legal fees to Ganci following the sexual harassment lawsuit.

Bayern Munich playmaker Thiago made his first appearance in over a year on Saturday, coming on as a substitute in their 1-0 win against Borussia Dortmund at the Westfalenstadion after recovering from a serious knee injury suffered in March 2014. The Spain international admitted it was an emotional moment and thanked the club, fans, and teammates for their support during his recovery. Despite feeling tired after just 10 minutes of play, Thiago expressed his joy at returning to football and his continued goal to win games and titles for Bayern Munich.

David Cameron accused the BBC of peddling "bollocks" after presenter Andrew Marr incorrectly claimed during the Andrew Marr Show that the Prime Minister had said foxhunting was his favourite sport, when Cameron had actually only expressed support for country sports in general. The Tory leader turned the clock back to ape John Major's election soapbox campaign style by climbing on a wooden pallet to address party faithful, though he was heckled by someone claiming "the NHS is dying." Marr later admitted his mistake on Twitter, calling it a "cock up not conspiracy," while Cameron clarified that tennis, not foxhunting, is his favourite sport.

Gwyneth Paltrow participated in the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, which urges participants to live on a food stamp budget of $29 for one week (based on the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Thrifty Food Plan), after being nominated by celebrity chef Mario Batali. Paltrow showcased her purchases of leafy greens, dried beans, and rice on social media to raise awareness about the difficulties of buying food on such a limited budget. The challenge was created in response to Congress cutting food stamps twice since 2013, aiming to help people understand the struggles families face when trying to afford food while on food assistance.

Dozens of staff at Manchester United's Old Trafford Megastore, including the club's official mascot Fred the Red (who has represented the Red Devils since 1994), are uncertain about their job security as Nike's agreement with the club expires on July 31. The uncertainty stems from Manchester United's world-record £750m kit deal transition, with Nike employees worried about re-employment while Nike claims they are in constant communication with the club and conducting staff consultations. The situation comes just before the new Premier League season begins on August 8, adding pressure to resolve the employment issues at the popular megastore.

Liverpool edged past Blackburn Rovers in their FA Cup sixth round replay to reach their 24th Cup semi-final, with Philippe Coutinho eventually breaking the deadlock after 161 goalless minutes across both matches. Blackburn put up a strong defensive performance, keeping dangerous players like Raheem Sterling quieter than most Barclays Premier League teams would manage, and came close to equalizing when goalkeeper Simon Eastwood was denied a late goal in stoppage time. Despite the challenge from a well-organized Blackburn side that doubled up on Liverpool's key threats, Coutinho's winner proved decisive in sending Liverpool through to Wembley.

A heart-warming video created by Pandora to celebrate Mother's Day 2015 shows six blindfolded children successfully identifying their mothers from a group of six women using only touch and scent. The emotional experiment demonstrates the unique bond between mother and child, as each youngster moves along the line of anxious mothers, touching their hands, hair, and faces until they recognize their own and embrace them. The viral video has been viewed 2.8 million times and even caught the attention of celebrities like Ashton Kutcher.

Salford assistant coach Ian Watson, 38, is poised to come out of playing retirement to help his team after they lost four players to suspension and several more to injury. If Watson plays against Castleford on Sunday, he would become the oldest player currently in Super League, having previously made 41 Super League appearances as a half-back with Salford in 1997 and 2002. The move comes as Salford are down to just 17 fit players following their recent Challenge Cup defeat.

21-year-old Jordan Spieth shot a stunning opening round of 64 to become the youngest first-round leader in Masters history, finishing with a spectacular birdie putt on the 18th hole to take a three-shot lead. Justin Rose made the early running with an impressive 67, tying with Charley Hoffman and Ernie Els who also posted superb 67s. Meanwhile, Rory McIlroy appeared relaxed but struggled initially before recovering to finish at one-under-par 71, as he continues his quest to complete the career grand slam.

Alastair Cook must focus on leading England to victory in a crucial three-Test series against the West Indies beginning Monday, despite the distracting turmoil surrounding English cricket including management changes and Kevin Pietersen's recent century for Surrey. The England captain and coach Peter Moores cannot afford any slip-ups in what should be their least challenging assignment, as defeat would be unthinkable given the pressure already mounting from England's poor World Cup performance and ongoing speculation about the team's future direction. Cook has appeared relaxed and in good form during practice, but knows he faces a Test series he must win to secure his position.

The Pentagon announced Tuesday that it will exhume and attempt to identify the remains of nearly 400 sailors and Marines killed when the USS Oklahoma capsized during the December 7, 1941 Pearl Harbor bombing after being hit by nine torpedoes. Of the 429 servicemen killed onboard, only 35 were initially identified, with the rest buried as unknowns at Hawaii's National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific. The military can now proceed with identification efforts due to advances in forensic science and DNA technology, aiming to identify up to 388 servicemen within five years and provide closure to families nearly 75 years after the attack.

YouTube entertainer Yousef Saleh Erakat disguised himself as a homeless man in a new video experiment where he offered money to strangers on the street, rather than asking for it. Most people reacted negatively and angrily when the seemingly homeless man tried to give them $10 bills, with many refusing the money and responding with hostility. Erakat explains that he wanted to "flip the script" to explore whether society's acceptance of the wealthy giving to the poor is based on genuine help or perceived social hierarchy, finding that only two people in the video responded kindly to his offers.

18-year-old Longwood University student Anjelica "AJ" Hadsell has been missing since March 2 while home for spring break, prompting police to search a pond near Carrsville, Virginia for her cell phone based on a new tip. AJ's stepfather Wesley Hadsell was arrested on charges including breaking and entering after he allegedly broke into a home where he believed his stepdaughter might be held, claiming he found her jacket there. AJ's grandmother Katherine Hadsell has criticized police for "doing nothing" to find the missing teen, while authorities continue investigating without naming any suspects in the month-long disappearance.

Australian researchers have developed a drone running companion called Joggobot, designed to fly in front of joggers to help maintain pace and provide motivation during runs. The quadcopter technology was tested with 13 runners who found it effective as a "pace keeper," and researchers concluded that robotic systems could be used to support various physical activities including cycling, rowing, and cross-country skiing. While runners appreciated the consistent pacing, some expressed safety concerns when the drone deviated from its path, though the technology shows promise for future fitness applications using robots as exercise companions.

Matthew Bird from New Zealand quit his $70,000 a year job as an agricultural adviser to become a mechanic earning $38,000 annually to avoid a $600-a-month hike in child support payments that would have increased his obligation from $1,300 to $1,900 per month. Under New Zealand's amended child support formula that took effect in April, Bird now pays $554 a month instead of the expected $1,900, saying he's happy to accept the meagre wage to reduce his financial burden by two-thirds.

British man Navinder Singh Sarao, 36, was accused this week of causing the 2010 Wall Street "flash crash" that wiped nearly a trillion dollars from global share prices, but US authorities had suspected him of making illicit trades as early as 2009. Despite being warned by officials at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in 2009, Sarao allegedly continued his illegal trading activities for six years, using automated software to manipulate markets from his home computer in London. Experts are expressing shock that it took authorities so long to bring charges against Sarao, who allegedly made £26 million from his illegal trades and now faces both civil and criminal charges.

Canadian expat Lisa Webb, who moved to France in 2009 and writes the blog "Canadian Expat Mom," was initially worried her vegetable-phobic three-year-old daughter would starve when she first sent her to French school. However, Lisa was amazed to discover that French schoolchildren eat sophisticated three-course meals with proper cutlery at tables, consuming dishes like roast beef and turkey cordon bleu that would typically be served in fancy restaurants. This contrasted sharply with her experience in Canada, where kids ate fast food or packed lunches quickly in the gym, and she observed that French children politely ate whatever was served to them without complaint.

A survey of 1,000 people conducted by personal budgeting software company YouNeedaBudget.com found that 64 per cent of adults think they spend far more money when go shopping with friends compared to making purchases alone. The study revealed that shopping with friends encourages people to overspend due to peer pressure, showing off, and getting carried away by excitement, leading them to end up buying things they wouldn't ordinarily purchase. Despite 85% of participants setting budgets, 95% admitted they usually spend more than originally planned, with food and clothing being the top categories for overspending.

Ellie Grant, 22, appeared on ITV's This Morning with her deaf fiancé to discuss how she suddenly developed Tourette's syndrome at age 21, a neurological condition affecting the brain and nervous system that causes involuntary tics. During the interview, Grant left presenter Phillip Schofield speechless when she blurted out "silver fox" (his nickname) due to a verbal tic, while discussing how her condition causes severe physical and verbal outbursts that continue even through the night. The couple explained how they found love despite their challenges, with her fiancé simply turning off his hearing aid when her tics become disruptive.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American citizen who became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation in Pakistan. Gadahn, who converted to Islam in 1995 and joined al Qaeda in Pakistan three years later, was not specifically targeted in the operation that also killed another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq. The same operation tragically resulted in the deaths of two hostages, including American Warren Weinstein who had been abducted by al Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011.

Formula One driver Jenson Button completed the 2015 London Marathon in an impressive time of 2 hours, 52 minutes and 30 seconds, finishing just behind former Olympic rower James Cracknell. The 35-year-old McLaren driver told the BBC he was "chuffed to bits" with his performance and praised the "amazing atmosphere" of running alongside 36,000 other participants. Button was running on behalf of Cancer Research charity and described the experience as "really really emotional," celebrating the collective spirit and effort of all the runners at the event.
